PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a complete recodification of the ordinances of the Warrenton, Virginia, of a general and permanent nature. 
    Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1981 Code, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the town council. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the Comparative Tables appearing in the back of this volume, the reader can locate any section of the 1981 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
    The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Footnotes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state laws have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this volume. 
Numbering System 
    The numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and municipal codes. Each section number consists of two component parts separated by a dash, the figure before the dash referring to the chapter number and the figure after the dash referring to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the first section of Chapter 2 is numbered 2-1 and the ninth section of Chapter 3 is 3-9. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter and at the same time new sections or even whole chapters can be inserted in their proper place simply by using the decimal system for amendments. By way of illustration: If new material consisting of three sections that would logically come between sections 3-3 and 3-4 is desired to be added, such new sections would be numbered 3-3.1, 3-3.2 and 3-3.3 respectively. New chapters may be included in the same manner. If the new material is to be included between Chapters 4 and 5, it will be designated as Chapter 4.5. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject, the next successive number being assigned to the article or division. 
Indices 
    The indices of the Code have been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of the headings being couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by municipal officers and employees. There are numerous cross references within each index which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which he is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this Code to which the attention of the user is especially directed is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing for the Code. With this system, the Code will be kept up-to-date periodically. Upon the final passage of amendatory ordinances, they will be properly edited and the appropriate page or pages affected will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the Code, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
    Successfully keeping this Code up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the volume. As revised sheets are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publishers that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    The publication of this Code was under the direct supervision of Milton E. Lefkoff, Supervising Editor, and Ronald McLaughlin, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publishers are most grateful to Mr. Carroll J. Martin, Jr., Town Attorney, and Mr. Donald A. Smith, Town Manager, for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this Code. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publishers have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the Town readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the Town's affairs. 
MUNICIPAL CODE CORPORATION 
Tallahassee, Florida 
ADOPTING ORDINANCE 
ORDINANCE NO. 1997-02 
An Ordinance Adopting and Enacting a New Code for the Town of Warrenton, Virginia, Providing for the Repeal of Certain Ordinances Not Included Therein, Providing for a Penalty for the Violation Thereof; Providing for the Manner of Amending Such Code; and Providing When Such Code and This Ordinance Shall Become Effective. 
    Be It Ordained by the Town Council for the Town of Warrenton, that the Code for the Town of Warrenton, Virginia Be Amended, Re-stated and Re-adopted in its Entirety As Follows: 
• 
The Code entitled "The Code of the Town of Warrenton, Virginia," published by Municipal Code Corporation consisting of Chapters 1 through 17, each inclusive, and the Zoning Ordinance and Subdivision Ordinance published by the Town of Warrenton, and any amendments contained in this ordinance, are hereby re-adopted and re-codified as follows: 
Chapter  1. General Provisions. 
Chapter  2. Administration. 
Chapter  3. Animals and Fowl. 
Chapter  4. Buildings. 
Chapter  5. Cemetery. 
Chapter  6. Dealers in Precious Metals and Gems. 
Chapter  7. Fire Prevention and Protection. 
Chapter  8. Garbage, Trash and Weeds. 
Chapter  9. Licenses. 
Chapter 10. Motor Vehicles and Traffic. 
Chapter 11. Offenses-Miscellaneous. 
Chapter 12. Police Department. 
Chapter 13. Solicitors. 
Chapter 14. Streets and Sidewalks. 
Chapter 15. Taxation. 
Chapter 16. Taxicabs. 
Chapter 17. Water and Sewers. 
Chapter 18. Zoning Ordinance. 
Chapter 19. Subdivision Ordinance. 
• 
All ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before March 11, 1997, and not included in the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein are repealed. 
• 
The repeal provided for above shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this ordinance. 
• 
Unless another penalty is expressly provided, every person convicted of a violation of any provisions of the Code, or any ordinance, rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof, shall be guilty of a Class 1 misdemeanor; however, any lesser penalty provided by state law for a like offense shall apply. Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided, shall apply to the amendment of any Code section whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the town may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief, and revocation of licenses or permits. 
• 
Future additions or amendments to the Code, when passed in the form as to indicate the intention of the council to make the same a part of the Code, shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. 
• 
Ordinances adopted after March 11, 1997, that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the Code shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code. 
    This ordinance shall become effective upon adoption. 
Voting For: Lewis, Reynolds, Foley, Mann, Rice, Tarr, Walker 
Against: _____ 
Adopted this 11th day of March, 1997. 
      Evelyn J. Weimer, Recorder   ADOPTING ORDINANCE 
ORDINANCE NO. 1988-1 
An Ordinance Adopting and Enacting a New Code for the Town of Warrenton, Virginia; Providing for the Repeal of Certain Ordinances Not Included Therein; Providing a Penalty for the Violation Thereof; Providing for the Manner of Amending Such Code; and Providing When Such Code and This Ordinance Shall Become Effective. 
Be It Ordained by the Council of the Town of Warrenton, Virginia: 
    Section 1. The Code entitled "The Code of the Town of Warrenton, Virginia," published by Municipal Code Corporation consisting of Chapters 1 through 17, each inclusive is adopted. 
    Section 2. All ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before June 2, 1987, and not included in the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein are repealed. 
    Section 3. The repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this ordinance. 
    Section 4. Unless another penalty is expressly provided, every person convicted of a violation of any provisions of the Code or any ordinance, rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof, shall be guilty of a Class 1 misdemeanor; however, any lesser penalty provided by state law for a like offense shall apply. Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided shall apply to the amendment of any Code section whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the town may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief, and revocation of licenses or permits. 
    Section 5. Additions or amendments to the Code, when passed in the form as to indicate the intention of the council to make the same a part of the Code, shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. 
    Section 6. Ordinances adopted after June 2, 1987, that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the Code shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code. 
    Section 7. This ordinance shall become effective January 5, 1988. 
Passed and adopted by the town council this 5th day of January, 1988. 
      J. Williard Lineweaver, Mayor         Evelyn J. Weimer, Recorder   Certificate of Adoption 
    I hereby certify that the foregoing is a true copy of the ordinance passed at the regular meeting of the council of the Town of Warrenton, Virginia held on the 5th day of January, 1988. 
      Evelyn J. Weimer, Recorder

PART I - CHARTER[1] 
    An act to provide a new charter for the Town of Warrenton in the County of Fauquier, Virginia, and to repeal Chapter 189, Acts of Assembly, Extra Session, 1902-03-04, approved April 30, 1903, which provided a charter for the Town of Warrenton, and all amendments thereof. 
    Be it enacted by the General Assembly of Virginia: 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- The charter is derived from section 1 of Chapter 47 (page 77 et seq.) of the 1964 Acts of the General Assembly and is set out herein as it appeared in the 1981 Warrenton Town Code. A uniform system of capitalization has been used. Amendments have been added and are indicated by history notes appearing in parentheses () at the end of the amended sections. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is derived, unamended, from Acts 1964, Chapter 47. Any words appearing in brackets [] were added by the editor for clarity. Certain section catchlines and article titles, appearing in boldface type, were amended in the 1981 codification for editorial purposes and should not be construed to restrict, limit or affect the contents of the sections and articles. 
Sections 2 and 3 of Acts 1964, Chapter 47, read as follows: 
 "2. Chapter 189, Acts of Assembly, Extra Session, 1902-03-04, approved April 30, 1903, and all amendments thereof, are hereby repealed. 
 3. An emergency exists and this act is in force from its passage." 
The act was approved on February 19, 1964. 

ARTICLE I. - CREATION 

Sec. 1-1. - Incorporation. 
    The inhabitants of the territory comprised within the limits of the Town of Warrenton, as the same are now or may hereafter be established by law, shall continue to be a body politic and corporate under the name of the Town of Warrenton and as such shall have perpetual succession, may sue and be sued, contract and be contracted with, and may have a corporate seal which it may alter at its pleasure. 
Sec. 1-2. - Boundaries. 
    The boundaries of the town shall be the boundaries of the Town of Warrenton, its predecessor as established by Chapter 189, Acts of Assembly, Extra Session 1902-03-04, as confirmed by section 1, of Chapter 18 of the Acts of the General Assembly of 1912, approved January 31, 1912, as modified and enlarged by the decree of the circuit court of Fauquier County, entered on December 11, 1959, in the annexation proceedings styled Town of Warrenton v. County of Fauquier, Virginia, which decree is recorded in the clerk's office of the circuit court of Fauquier County, Virginia in Common Law Order Book "X" at pages 376-377-378; and as modified and enlarged by the decree of the circuit court of Fauquier County, entered on December 7, 1979, in the annexation proceedings styled Meadow Run, Ltd. v. Fauquier County and Town of Warrenton, which decree is recorded in the clerk's office of the circuit court of Fauquier County, Virginia, in D.B. 391 at page 358. 
Editor's note- By a decree of the circuit court, dated December 7, 1979, 46.3905 acres of land were annexed to the town, effective January 1, 1980. 
ARTICLE II. - CORPORATE POWERS 

Sec. 2-1. - General powers. 
    The Town of Warrenton shall have and may exercise all powers which are now or may hereafter be conferred upon or delegated to cities and towns under the constitution and laws of the commonwealth, and all other powers pertinent to the conduct of municipal government, the exercise of which is not prohibited by the constitution and laws of the commonwealth, and which in the opinion of the council are necessary to promote the general welfare of the inhabitants of the town. It is intended that the town shall possess all powers which, under the constitution, it would be competent for this charter to enumerate specifically, and no enumeration of particular powers shall be held to be exclusive, but in addition to this general grant. 
    The powers which are now or may hereafter be conferred upon or delegated to the town under the constitution and laws of the commonwealth and this charter shall be construed liberally when such powers are exercised by the town and in case of doubt as to the existence of a power such doubt shall be resolved in favor of the town. 
Sec. 2-2. - Financial powers generally. 
    The Town of Warrenton shall have the power to raise annually by taxes and assessments in said town such sums of money as the council thereof shall deem necessary for the purposes of the town, and in such manner as the council may deem expedient in accordance with the constitution and general laws of the commonwealth and of the United States, and to expend the money of said town for all lawful purposes. 
Sec. 2-3. - Special assessments. 
    The Town of Warrenton shall have the power to impose special or local assessments for local improvements and to enforce the payment thereof, subject to the limitations prescribed by the constitution and laws of the commonwealth as may be in force at the time of the imposition of such special or local assessments. 
Sec. 2-4. - Borrowing power. 
    The Town of Warrenton may incur indebtedness by issuing its negotiable bonds and notes for the purposes and in the manner provided in the constitution and general laws of the commonwealth. 
(Acts 1968, Ch. 75, § 1) 
Sec. 2-5. - Eminent domain. 
    The Town of Warrenton is hereby empowered to acquire by condemnation or otherwise, property, real or personal, or any interest or estate therein, either within or without its corporate limits, for any of its proper purposes, and may sell, lease, manage, and control such property as its interests require, and in such manner as [the] council deems expedient. 
Sec. 2-6. - Enactment, etc., of ordinances. 
    The Town of Warrenton shall have the power to enact and enforce ordinances to carry into effect all powers granted by this charter. 
Sec. 2-7. - Adoption of certain provisions of title 15.1 of the Code of Virginia. 
    The powers set forth in sections 15.1-835 through 15.1-907 of Chapter 18 of Title 15.1 of the Code of Virginia as in force on January 1, 1968, are hereby conferred on and vested in the Town of Warrenton. 
(Acts 1968, Ch. 75, § 1) 
Editor's note- Code of Virginia, Title 15.1, Ch. 18, now begins with section 15.1-837. 
ARTICLE III. - THE COUNCIL GENERALLY 

Sec. 3-1. - Composition; members to be qualified voters. 
    The Town of Warrenton shall be governed by a town council which shall be composed of seven (7) members who shall be qualified voters of the town. 
Sec. 3-2. - Election and terms of members. 
    The members of the council in office at the effective date of this charter amendment will hereby continue in office until June thirtieth [,] nineteen hundred eighty-seven. On the first Tuesday in May, nineteen hundred eighty-seven, there shall be elected seven (7) councilmen, five (5) of whom shall be elected from wards and two (2) at large. The ward councilmen shall serve for a term of one (1) year and the at-large councilmen for a term of three (3) years. On the first Tuesday in May, nineteen hundred eighty-eight, the five (5) ward councilmen will run for terms of four (4) years. On the first Tuesday in May, nineteen hundred ninety, the two (2) at-large councilmen will run for terms of four (4) years. On the first Tuesday in May nineteen hundred ninety-two, the five (5) ward councilmen will run for terms of four (4) years. Thereafter all councilmen shall be elected for terms of four (4) years to fill vacancies caused by expiration of terms of office as hereinabove provided. 
(Acts 1971, Ex. Sess., Ch. 78, § 1; Ord. of 12-16-86, § 3-2) 
Editor's note- The wording of the above section has been corrected as instructed by the town. 
State Law reference- Council of town as judge of election, etc., of members, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-830. 
Sec. 3-3. - When councilmen take office. 
    All councilmen shall take office on the first day of July next following their election. 
(Acts 1971, Ex. Sess., Ch. 78, § 1) 
Sec. 3-4. - Compensation. 
    The council may by ordinance authorize the payment of an annual salary to councilmen, subject to such limitations as may be imposed by the general laws of the commonwealth. 
State Law reference- Salaries of town council members, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-827.1. 
Sec. 3-5. - Filling vacancies. 
    Vacancies on the council shall be filled for the unexpired portion of the term by a majority vote of the remaining members of the council, if such vacancy shall occur two (2) years or less before the date of expiration of such terms. If the vacancy shall occur more than two (2) years before the expiration of the term, the vacancy shall be filled by a majority vote of the remaining members of the council only until the next councilmanic election, at which election the qualified voters shall elect a person to serve as councilman for the remaining two (2) years of the term. 
Sec. 3-6. - Vesting powers of town. 
    All powers of the Town of Warrenton as a body politic and corporate shall be vested in the town council. 
Sec. 3-7. - Appointment, etc., of town attorney. 
    The council may appoint a town attorney whose term of appointment, duties, and compensation shall be prescribed by the council. 
Sec. 3-8. - Appointment, etc., of recorder. 
    The council may appoint a recorder whose term of appointment, duties, and compensation shall be prescribed by the council. 
ARTICLE IV. - COUNCILMANIC PROCEDURES, ETC 

Sec. 4-1. - Regular meetings. 
    The council shall meet in regular session at least once each month. 
Sec. 4-2. - Special meetings. 
    The council shall provide for the calling of special meetings by the mayor, the town manager, or any four (4) members of the council, and shall prescribe the method of giving notice thereof, provided such notice shall contain a statement of the specific item or items of business to be transacted, and no other business shall be transacted at such meetings except by the unanimous consent of all the members of council; provided, however, that a special meeting may be held at any time without notice if all members of the council attend said meeting or waive notice thereof. 
State Law reference- Giving notice of time and place of meetings, Code of Virginia, § 2.1-343. 
Sec. 4-3. - Quorum. 
    A majority of the members of the council shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
Sec. 4-4. - Prerequisites to passage of ordinances, etc. 
    No ordinance, resolution, motion or vote shall be adopted by the council except at a meeting open to the public and unless it shall have received the affirmative votes of the majority of the members present. 
State Law reference- Virginia Freedom of Information Act, Code of Virginia, § 2.1-340 et seq.; executive or closed meetings, Code of Virginia, §§ 2.1-341, 2.1-344. 
Sec. 4-5. - Reconsideration, etc., of vote at special meeting. 
    No vote shall be reconsidered or rescinded at any special meeting unless at such special meeting there are present as large a number of members as were present when such vote was taken. 
Sec. 4-6. - Financial interest as limitation on voting power. 
    No member of the council shall participate in the vote on any ordinance, resolution, motion, or other proceeding in which he, or any person, firm, or corporation for which he is attorney, officer, director, employee, or agent has a financial interest other than as a minority stockholder of a corporation or as a citizen of the town. 
State Law reference- State and Local Government Conflict of Interests Act, Code of Virginia, § 2.1-639.1 et seq. 
ARTICLE V. - THE MAYOR 

Sec. 5-1. - Election and term. 
    The mayor in the office at the effective date of this charter amendment will hereby continue in office until July one, nineteen hundred seventy-eight. On the first Tuesday in May, nineteen hundred seventy-eight, and every four (4) years thereafter, there shall be elected from the town at large a mayor, who shall be a qualified voter of the town and who shall serve for a term of four (4) years. The mayor shall take office on the first day of July next following his election. 
(Acts 1971, Ex. Sess., Ch. 78, § 1; Acts 1977, Ch. 133, § 1) 
Sec. 5-2. - Duties generally. 
    The mayor shall preside over the meetings of the council and shall have the same right to speak therein as councilmen; however, he shall not have the right to vote except in the case of a tie, in which event he shall be entitled to cast one (1) vote. He shall be recognized as the head of the town government for all ceremonial purposes, the purposes of military law and the service of civil process. 
Sec. 5-3. - Compensation. 
    The council may by ordinance authorize the payment of an annual salary to the mayor, subject to such limitations as may be imposed by the general laws of the commonwealth. 
State Law reference- Salary of mayor, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-827. 
ARTICLE VI. - THE TOWN MANAGER[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Town manager, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-795. 

Sec. 6-1. - Establishment of position; responsibilities; qualifications; term. 
    There shall be a town manager who shall be the chief executive officer of the town and shall be responsible to the council for the proper administration of the town government. He shall be chosen by the council without regard to his political beliefs and solely on the basis of his executive and administrative qualifications. He shall be appointed for an indefinite period and shall hold office during the pleasure of the council. 
Sec. 6-2. - Appointment and removal of officers and employees. 
    The town manager shall appoint for an indefinite term the heads of all departments and all other officers and employees of the town. The manager shall have the power to remove any officer or employee appointed by him. 
Editor's note- See §§ 3-7 and 3-8, above. 
Sec. 6-3. - Duties and powers generally. 
    The town manager shall also have the following duties and powers: 
(a)  To see that all laws and ordinances are enforced. 
(b)  To exercise supervision and control over all administrative departments and divisions. 
(c)  To attend all regular meetings of the council, with the right to take part in the discussion, but having no vote. 
(d)  To recommend to the council for adoption such measures as he may deem necessary or desirable. 
(e)  To execute all contracts on behalf of the town. 
(f)  To prepare and submit to the council the annual budget. 
(g)  To keep the council advised as to the present and future needs of the town and as to all operations of its government. 
(h)  To perform all such other duties as may be prescribed by the charter, or be required of him by the council. 
ARTICLE VII. - FINANCIAL ADMINISTRATION GENERALLY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Public Finance Act, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-170 et seq. 

Sec. 7-1. - Fiscal year. 
    The fiscal year for the Town of Warrenton shall begin on July first, and end June thirtieth of the following year. 
State Law reference- Uniform fiscal year, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-159.8. 
Sec. 7-2. - Procedure as to budget, etc. 
    Not later than the first day of May annually, the town manager shall prepare and submit to the council a budget presenting a financial plan for conducting the affairs of the town for the ensuing fiscal year. Such budget shall be set up in the manner provided for law and shall include such information as the council by ordinance or resolution may require. Hearings on the budget shall be held and notice thereof given and the budget adopted in accordance with the general laws of the commonwealth, provided that the tax levy for each fiscal year shall be made, and the budget for each fiscal year shall be adopted prior to the first day of the fiscal year for which made or adopted. 
State Law reference- Municipal budgets, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-160 et seq. 
ARTICLE VIII. - ANNUAL AUDIT 

Sec. 8-1. - Generally. 
    After the close of each fiscal year the council shall cause to be made an independent audit of the accounts, books, records and financial transactions of the town by the auditor of public accounts of the commonwealth or by a firm of independent certified public accountants to be selected by the council. The report of such audit shall be filed within such time as the council shall specify and one copy thereof shall be always available for public inspection in the office of the town manager during regular business hours. 
State Law reference- Audit of local government records, etc., by auditor of public accounts, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-167. 
ARTICLE IX. - MUNICIPAL COURT[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- The provisions of this article were deleted pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 16.1-70.1, which abolished courts of limited jurisdiction. 

ARTICLE X. - CONTINUATION AND REPEAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 10-1. - Repeal of former charters. 
    All former charters and amendments thereto for the Town of Warrenton, Virginia, are hereby repealed. 
Sec. 10-2. - Succession of town to rights and duties. 
    The Town of Warrenton shall succeed to all the rights, duties, obligations, and contracts of the former Town of Warrenton. 
Sec. 10-3. - Continuance in force of ordinances. 
    All ordinances of the former Town of Warrenton not inconsistent with this charter shall remain in full force and effect until amended or repealed by the town council. 
Sec. 10-4. - Continuity of terms of officers. 
    The officers of the Town of Warrenton who were in office immediately prior to the adoption of this charter shall remain in office until the expiration of their several terms and until their successors have been duly elected and qualified. 
Sec. 10-5. - Severability. 
    In the event that any portion, section, or provision of this charter shall be declared illegal, invalid, or unconstitutional by final judgment of any court of competent jurisdiction such judgment shall not invalidate any other portion, section, or provision hereof, but all parts of this charter not expressly held to be invalid shall remain in full force and effect.

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Incorporation of town, § 1-1; boundaries of town, § 1-2; enactment of ordinances, § 2-6; continuation and repeal provisions, Art. X. 
State Law reference- Adoption and enforcement of municipal ordinances, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-13. 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated and cited as "The Code of the Town of Warrenton, Virginia." Such Code may also be cited as "The Warrenton Town Code." 
(Code 1981, § 1-1) 
State Law reference- Authority of town to codify and recodify its ordinances, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-37.3. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances of the town, the following rules shall be observed, unless otherwise specifically provided or unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the council. 
    The rules of construction given in sections 1-13.1 to 1-15, Code of Virginia, shall govern, so far as applicable, the construction of all other words not defined in this section, in other sections of this Code or in other ordinances of the town. 
    Bond. When a bond is required, an undertaking in writing shall be sufficient. 
State Law reference- "Bond with surety" defined, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.1:1. 
    Charter. The word "charter" shall mean the charter of the town as it now exists or as it may be amended in the future. 
    Code. Whenever the term "Code" or "this Code" is used without further qualification, it shall mean The Code of the Town of Warrenton, Virginia, as designated in section 1-1. 
    Code of Virginia. The words "Code of Virginia" shall mean the Code of Virginia of 1950, as it now exists or as it may be amended in the future. 
    Computation of time. Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done, a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be had, the day on which such notice is given or such act is done shall be counted in computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be had shall not be counted. 
State Law reference- Computation of time, Code of Virginia, §§ 1-13.3, 1-13.3:1. 
    Council. The word "council" shall mean the council of the Town of Warrenton. 
State Law reference- "Council" defined, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.5. 
    County. The word "county" shall be construed as if the words "of Fauquier" followed it. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
State Law reference- Gender, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.7. 
    Health department. The words "health department" shall mean the health department of Fauquier County. 
    Health director. The words "health director" shall mean the health director of the Fauquier County health department or his authorized agent. 
    In the town. The words "in the town" shall mean any territory jurisdiction of which, for the exercise of its regulatory power, has been conferred on the town by public or private law. 
    Joint authority. Words purporting to give authority to three (3) or more public officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such officers or other persons. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.1. 
    May. The word "may" is permissive. 
    Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.13. 
    Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons or things, as well as to one (1) person or thing; and a word importing the plural number only may extend and be applied to one (1) person or thing, as well as to several persons or things. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.15. 
    Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which by law an affirmation may be substituted for an oath. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.16; when affirmation may be made, Code of Virginia, § 49.9. 
    Officers; boards; etc. Whenever reference is made to a particular officer, department, board, commission or other agency, such reference shall be construed as if followed by the words "of the Town of Warrenton, Virginia." 
    Or; and. "Or" may be read "and," and "and" may be read "or," if the sense requires it. 
    Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety of the whole or a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The word "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, companies, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. 
State Law reference- "Person" defined, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.19. 
    Preceding; following. The words "preceding" and "following" shall mean next before and next after, respectively. 
State Law reference- "Following" defined, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.6; "preceding" defined, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.23. 
    Shall. The word "shall" is mandatory. 
    Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of a street between the curb line, or the lateral lines of a roadway where there is no curb, and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    Signature; subscription. The word "signature" or "subscription" includes a mark when a person cannot write. 
    Standard time. Whenever particular hours are referred to, the time applicable shall be official standard time or daylight saving time, whichever may be in current use in the town. 
State Law reference- Standard eastern time, daylight saving time, Code of Virginia, § 1-15. 
    State; commonwealth. The words "state" and "commonwealth" shall be construed as if the words "of Virginia" followed. 
State Law reference- "State" defined, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.26. 
    Street. The word "street" shall include public avenues, boulevards, highways, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts, bridges and the approaches thereto and all other public thoroughfares in the town and shall mean the entire width thereof between abutting property lines and a sidewalk or footpath. 
    Swear; sworn. The word "swear" or "sworn" shall be equivalent to the word "affirm" or "affirmed" in all cases in which by law an affirmation may be substituted for an oath. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.28; when affirmation may be made, Code of Virginia, § 49-9. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Town. The words "the town" shall mean the Town of Warrenton, in the State of Virginia. 
State Law reference- "Town" defined, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.29. 
    Written; in writing. The word "written" or "in writing" shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.32. 
    Year. The word "year" shall be construed to mean a calendar year; and the word "year" alone shall be equivalent to the expression "year of our Lord." 
(Code 1981, § 1-2) 
State Law reference- "Year" defined, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.33. 
Sec. 1-3. - Provisions considered as continuations of existing ordinances. 
    The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as those of the 1981 Code and all ordinances adopted subsequent to the 1981 Code and included herein, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. 
(Code 1981, § 1-3) 
Sec. 1-4. - Severability. 
    The provisions of this Code or the application thereof to any person or circumstances which are held invalid shall not affect the validity of other provisions or applications of this Code which can be given effect without the invalid provisions or applications. 
(Code 1981, § 1-4) 
State Law reference- Severability of statutory provisions, Code of Virginia, § 1-17.1 
Sec. 1-5. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part thereof, nor unless expressly so provided shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(Code 1981, § 1-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions applicable to Code of Virginia, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.9. 
Sec. 1-6. - Notice to town attorney of appeals to circuit court. 
    In any case arising under any provision of this Code or other ordinance of the town where there is a conviction and an appeal allowed to the circuit court of the county, the court trying such case shall immediately notify in writing the town attorney of such appeal and request him to represent the town in such appeal before the circuit court of the county. 
(Code 1981, § 1-6) 
Sec. 1-7. - General penalty; continuing violations. 
(a)  Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance or resolution of the town or any rule or regulation or order promulgated by any officer or agency of the town under authority duly vested in him or it, any act is prohibited or is declared to be unlawful or an offense or misdemeanor or the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or an offense or misdemeanor and no specific penalty is provided for the violation thereof, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any such ordinance, resolution, rule, regulation or order shall be punished as follows: 
(1)  For Class 1 misdemeanors, confinement in jail for not more than twelve (12) months and a fine of not more than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00), either or both. 
(2)  For Class 2 misdemeanors, confinement in jail for not more than six (6) months and a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), either or both. 
(3)  For Class 3 misdemeanors, a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(4)  For Class 4 misdemeanors, a fine of not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(5)  A misdemeanor for which no punishment or no maximum punishment is prescribed by statute or ordinance shall be punishable as a Class 1 misdemeanor. 
(6)  Where a provision of this Code prescribes punishment by stating that the offense is a misdemeanor or that it is punishable as provided for in section 1-7, the offense shall be deemed to be a Class 1 misdemeanor. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any provisions of this section to the contrary, no penalty for violation of any such provision, ordinance, etc., shall exceed the penalty prescribed by general law for a like offense. 
(c)  Unless otherwise provided, each day any violation of this Code or of any ordinance, resolution, regulation, rule or order shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1981, § 1-7; Ord. No. 1996-1, 2-13-96; Ord. No. 1997-02, 3-11-97) 
State Law reference- Penalties for violations of municipal ordinances, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-901; bond of persons convicted to prevent additional violations, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-902; injunctive relief against continuing violation of ordinance, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-905; classification of criminal offenses, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-9; punishment for conviction of misdemeanor, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-11; punishment for misdemeanor where no penalty prescribed, Code of Virginia, §§ 18.2-12, 18.2-13. 
Sec. 1-8. - Miscellaneous ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect: 
(1)  Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code; 
(2)  Any prosecution, suit or proceeding pending or any judgment rendered before the effective date of this Code; 
(3)  Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the town or authorizing the issue of any bonds of the town or any evidence of the town's indebtedness or any contract or obligation assumed by the town; 
(4)  Any right or franchise conferred by ordinance or resolution; 
(5)  Any appropriation or budget ordinance; 
(6)  Any ordinance levying or imposing taxes, fees or other charges; 
(7)  Any ordinance providing for any public improvement; 
(8)  Any ordinance making any assessment; 
(9)  Any ordinance naming, renaming, opening, relocating, accepting, closing or vacating any streets or alleys; 
(10)  Any ordinance relative to position classification, salaries, wages or compensation or bonds of town officers or employees and of members and employees of town boards or commissions; 
(11)  Any ordinance relative to zoning or to zoning map changes; 
(12)  Any ordinance relative to building lines or setback lines; 
(13)  Any ordinance relative to subdivisions; 
(14)  Any ordinance relative to soil erosions and sedimentation control; 
(15)  Any ordinance relative to industrial costs for wastewater treatment; 
(16)  Any ordinance annexing territory to the town; 
(17)  Any ordinance adopted for purposes which have been consummated; 
(18)  Any ordinance which is temporary, although general in effect, or special, although permanent in effect; 
and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1981-2, § 3, 2-3-81) 
State Law reference- Repeal of law not to affect liabilities, Code of Virginia, § 1-16. 
Sec. 1-9. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by town personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the town council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances adopted during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been replaced shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections_______ to_______" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
State Law reference- Authority of town to supplement Code, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-37.3. 
Sec. 1-10. - Copies of Code and supplements to be available for public inspection. 
    At least three (3) copies of this Code and at least three (3) copies of every supplement thereto shall be kept in the office of the town recorder and shall there be available for public inspection during normal business hours. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-37.3.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Town depositories. 
    The funds of the town shall be deposited to the credit of the town by the finance director in such banks as the council may direct, and such banks shall give bond or deposit collateral securities as provided in the Virginia Security for Public Deposits Act (Code of Virginia, section 2.1-359 et seq.). 
(Code 1981, § 2-1) 
Cross reference- Licenses, Ch. 9; taxation, Ch. 15. 
State Law reference- Authority of institutions holding public deposits to secure such deposits, Code of Virginia, § 2.1-368; definitions applicable to the Virginia Security for Public Deposits Act, Code of Virginia, § 2.1-360. 
Sec. 2-2. - Deposit of town money in depository account; withdrawals. 
(a)  All funds received by the town shall be deposited to the credit of the town in qualified public depositories as the same are authorized under the Virginia Security for Public Deposit Act, Chapter 23, Section 2.1-359 et seq., of the Code of Virginia, in special accounts authorized thereunder. 
(b)  Any such funds may, at the discretion of the finance director or deputy finance director, be invested in local government investment pools authorized under Section 2.1-234.8 of the Code of Virginia and the town's investment policy as adopted by the town council. 
(c)  All disbursements of funds deposited by the town shall be made directly or from funds invested as authorized under subsection (b). All disbursements are to be made by bank check or electronic funds transfer. 
(d)  The finance director or deputy finance director shall prepare a statement of disbursements which shall include therein the name of the payee and the amount of each disbursement. Each disbursement shall be in payment of properly prepared vouchers which have been certified for payment by the town manager. The statement of disbursements shall identify the source of funds from which the disbursement is to be made and be signed by either the finance director or the deputy finance director and signed by the town manager. 
(e)  Bank checks or electronic funds transfer authorizations for disbursements approved under the previous subsections shall be signed by either the finance director or the deputy finance director, whoever did not sign the statement of disbursements identified in the previous subsection. 
(Code 1981, §§ 2-2, 2-3; Ord. No. 1995-5, 5-9-95; Ord. No. 1998-08, 6-9-98) 
State Law reference- Deposit of public funds pursuant to the Virginia Security for Public Deposits Act, Code of Virginia, §§ 2.1-366, 2.1-367; liabilities, Code of Virginia, §§ 2.1-363, 2.1-370. 
Secs. 2-3-2-20. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-21. - Wards. 
    The following wards in the town are provided for, established and laid off: 
(1)  First Ward: Beginning at the intersection of the corporate limits and Business Route 17; thence in a clockwise direction following the corporate limits in a northerly direction to the northernmost point of the corporate limits thence following the corporate limits in an easterly direction crossing Hastings Lane, then crossing Route 672 to Route 15-29; thence following the eastern corporate limits in a southerly direction on the Eastern Bypass, Alternate U.S. Routes 29 and 15 to the point where it crosses under Academy Hill Extended; thence following Academy Hill Extended in a westerly direction to its intersection with Walker Drive; thence following Walker Drive in a northerly direction to its intersection with Blackwell Road; thence in a southerly direction on Blackwell Road to its intersection with Alexandria Pike; thence following Alexandria Pike in a southerly direction to its intersection with King Street; thence following King Street in a northerly direction to its intersection with Winchester Street; thence following Winchester Street in a northerly direction to its intersection with Broadview Avenue and Route 17; thence following Route 17 in a northerly direction to its intersection with the corporate limits, the point beginning.

thence following James Madison Highway in a northerly direction to its intersection with Falmouth Street and East Shirley Avenue; thence following East Shirley Avenue in a northwesterly direction to its intersection with Madison Street; thence following Madison Street in a southeasterly direction to its intersection with Falmouth Street; thence following Falmouth Street in a northerly direction to its intersection with East Street; thence following East Street in an easterly direction to its intersection with East Lee Street; thence following East Lee Street in an easterly direction to its intersection with Walker Drive; thence following Walker Drive in a northerly direction to its intersection with Academy Hill Road; thence following Academy Hill Road in a southwesterly direction to its intersection with Horner Street; thence following Horner Street in a westerly direction to its intersection with Fifth Street; thence following Fifth Street in a southerly direction to its intersection with Main Street; thence following Main Street in a westerly direction to its intersection with Third Street; thence following Blackwell Road in a northerly direction to its intersection with Walker Drive; thence following Walker Drive in an easterly direction to its intersection with Academy Hill Extended; thence following Academy Hill Extended in an easterly direction to the eastern corporate limits at the Eastern Bypass, Alternate U.S. Routes 29 and 15; thence following the eastern corporate limits in a southerly direction on the Eastern Bypass, Alternate U.S. Routes 29 and 15 across its intersection with Route 643, Meetze Road Interchange to its intersection with the center point of Turkey Run, the point of beginning. 
(3)  Third Ward: Beginning at the corner of Falmouth and Madison Streets in a clockwise direction; thence following Madison Street in a westerly direction to its intersection with East Shirley Avenue; thence following East Shirley Avenue in a southeasterly direction to its intersection with Falmouth Street and James Madison Highway; thence following James Madison Highway in a southerly direction to its intersection with the new corporate limits between the Town of Warrenton and the County of Fauquier, established by the Circuit Court of Fauquier County on May 8, 2001; thence following the new southwestern corporate limit in a northwesterly direction to its intersection with Culpeper Street, thence following Culpeper Street in a northeasterly direction to its intersection with East Shirley Avenue; thence following East Shirley Avenue in an easterly direction to its intersection with Green Street; thence following Green Street in an northeasterly direction to its intersection with Franklin Street; thence following Franklin Street in a northerly direction to its intersection with Third Street; thence following Third Street in a northern direction to Beckham Street; thence following Beckham Street in a westerly direction to its intersection with Culpeper Street; thence following Culpeper Street in a northerly direction to its intersection with Main Street; thence following Main Street in a westerly direction to its intersection with Alexandria Pike; thence following Alexandria Pike in a northerly direction to its intersection with Horner Street; thence following Horner Street in an easterly direction to its intersection with Third Street; thence following Third Street in a southerly direction to its intersection with Main Street; thence following Main Street in an easterly direction to its intersection with Fifth Street; thence following Fifth Street in a northerly direction to its intersection with Horner Street; thence following Horner Street in an easterly direction to its intersection with Academy Hill Road; thence following Academy Hill Road in a northeasterly direction to its intersection with Walker Drive; thence following Walker Drive in a southerly direction to its intersection with East Lee Street; thence following East Lee Street in a westerly direction to its intersection with East Street; thence following East Street in a westerly direction to its intersection with Falmouth Street; thence following Falmouth Street in a southerly direction to its intersection with Madison Street, the point of beginning. 
(4)  Fourth Ward: Beginning at the intersection of Culpeper Street (Route 802) and the south corporate limits in a clockwise direction; thence following the corporate limits of the town in a northerly direction to the intersection of Frost Avenue (Route 211); thence following in a westerly direction along the northern boundary of Frost Avenue (Route 211) to the new corporate limits between the Town of Warrenton and the County of Fauquier, established by the Circuit Court of Fauquier County on April 24, 2003; thence following the new corporate limits in a northerly direction to the intersection of Lower Waterloo Road (Route 680); thence following Lower Waterloo Road (Route 680) in an easterly direction to its intersection with Old Waterloo Road (Route 678); and thence running in a westerly direction with the corporate limits and Old Waterloo Road (Route 678) to its intersection with the west corporate limits; thence running in a northeasterly direction with the corporate limits to its intersection with Business Route 17; thence following Business Route 17 in a southerly direction to its intersection with Foxcroft Road; thence following Foxcroft Road in a southwesterly direction to its intersection with Bear Wallow Road; thence following Bear Wallow Road in an easterly direction to its intersection with Broadview Avenue; thence following Broadview Avenue (Route 15-17-29) in a southerly direction to its intersection with Frost Avenue (Route 211) and West Shirley Avenue; thence continuing in a southerly direction along West Shirley Avenue to Culpeper Street (Route 802); thence following Culpeper Street (Route 802) in a southwesterly direction to the southern corporate limits, the point of beginning.

(Ord. of 11-6-86, § 21.1; Ord. of 4-7-87, § 21.1; Ord. No. 1991-14, 12-10-91; Ord. No. 1993-18, 11-9-93; Ord. No. 2002-02, 2-12-2002; Ord. No. 2004-01, 2-10-2004; Ord. No. 2011-04, 12-13-11) 
Charter reference- Number of wards, § 3-2. 
State Law reference- Election districts, Code of Virginia, § 24.1-36 et seq.; requirements for election districts and precincts, Code of Virginia, § 24.1-40.7 et seq. 
Sec. 2-22. - Voting or polling place. 
    The voting places for the wards established by section 2-21 shall be as follows: 
(1)  Ward 1: Warrenton Manor Apartments. 
(2)  Ward 2: Warrenton Presbyterian Church. 
(3)  Ward 3: Warren Green Building. 
(4)  Ward 4: Warrenton Police Station. 
(5)  Ward 5: Warren Green Building. 
(Ord. of 11-6-86; Ord. of 4-7-87, § 21.2; Ord. No. 1991-14, 12-10-91; Ord. No. 1993-18, 11-9-93; Ord. No. 2002-02, 2-12-2002; Ord. No. 2002-09, 10-8-2002; Ord. No. 2004-01, 2-10-2004; Ord. No. 2011-04, 12-13-11) 
State Law reference- Polling places in towns, Code of Virginia, § 24.1-92. 
Sec. 2-23. - Campaign finance disclosure. 
    Code of Virginia, Chapter 9.3, Campaign Finance Disclosure Act of 2006, of title 24.2, Elections, as amended, shall be applicable to elections for town offices in the town pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 24.2-945, as amended. 
( Ord. No. 2014-04, 12-9-14 ) 
Secs. 2-24-2-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TOWN COUNCIL[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Town council generally, Art. III. 
State constitution reference- Procedures of local governing body, Art. VII, § 7. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-36. - Generally. 
    The council shall appoint from its membership a vice-mayor, who shall exercise the powers and perform the duties of the mayor during any absence or disability of the mayor. 
(Code 1981, § 2-32) 
Charter reference- Duties of mayor, § 5-2. 
Sec. 2-37. - Orders, etc., by members of council. 
    No member of the town council shall give any orders or authorize any work to be done for or on behalf of the town between meetings of the council without the approval and supervision of the town manager or, in the absence of the town manager, without the approval and consent of the town council. 
(Code 1981, § 2-4) 
Charter reference- Power of council to prescribe duties for town manager, § 6-3. 
Sec. 2-38. - Special committees. 
    The mayor shall have authority, when he deems it necessary, to appoint special committees of the council. Such appointments shall be subject to the approval of the town council. 
(Code 1981, § 2-5) 
Sec. 2-39. - Special meetings. 
    The mayor, the town manager or any four (4) members of the council may call special meetings of the council at any time, after twelve (12) hours' written notice to each member served personally or left at his usual place of business or residence. Such notice shall contain a statement of the specific item or items of business to be transacted. Such meeting may be held at any time without notice, if all members of the council attend such meeting or waive notice thereof. 
(Code 1981, § 2-12) 
Charter reference- Special meetings, § 4-2; reconsideration, etc., of vote at special meeting, § 4-5. 
State Law reference- Giving notice of time and place of meetings, Code of Virginia, § 2.1-343. 
Secs. 2-40-2-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PROCEDURES GENERALLY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- Councilmanic procedures, etc., Art. IV. 
State Law reference- Power of council to adopt rules for the regulation of its proceedings, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-826. 

Sec. 2-51. - Application of rules of procedure of House of Delegates. 
    The proceedings of the council, except as its own rules of procedure or this Code may otherwise provide, shall be conducted according to the same rules of procedure as those used by the House of Delegates of the state. 
(Code 1981, § 2-6) 
State constitution reference- Power of each house of General Assembly to settle its rules of procedure, Art. IV, § 7. 
Sec. 2-52. - Suspension of rules. 
    No rule of procedure of the council shall be suspended except with the concurrence of five (5) of the members. 
(Code 1981, § 2-7) 
Sec. 2-53. - Order of proceedings. 
    The order of the proceedings of the council, at a council meeting, shall be as follows: 
(1)  Call to order. 
(2)  Invocation. 
(3)  Visitors. 
(4)  Reports and communications from town officers, including financial statements and reports of committees. 
(5)  New business. 
(6)  Unfinished business. 
(7)  Communications and correspondence. 
(Code 1981, § 2-8) 
Sec. 2-54. - Consideration of petitions. 
    After the purport of a petition of new business has been briefly stated by the member offering it, the council may consider it or otherwise dispose of it. 
(Code 1981, § 2-9) 
State constitution reference- Right to petition, Art. I, § 12. 
Sec. 2-55. - Adjournment in absence of quorum. 
    If a quorum of the members of the council shall fail to attend within half an hour after the appointed time of meeting, those present may adjourn to such time as they deem proper and the recorder shall enter the names of those present and those absent on the journal. 
(Code 1981, § 2-10) 
Charter reference- Quorum, § 4-3. 
State Law reference- Giving notice of time and place of meetings, Code of Virginia, § 2.1-343. 
Sec. 2-56. - Permission required for member to absent self from meeting. 
    After a member of the council, at any meeting of the council, has been recorded as present, he shall not absent himself from such meeting until adjournment without the permission of the presiding officer. 
(Code 1981, § 2-11) 
Charter reference- Powers and duties of mayor as presiding officer, § 5-2. 
Secs. 2-57-2-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ORDINANCES AND RESOLUTIONS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Charter reference- Power of town to enact and enforce ordinances, § 2-6; prerequisites of passage of ordinances, etc., § 4-4. 
State Law reference- Adoption and enforcement of municipal ordinances, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-13. 

Sec. 2-71. - Form and reading of ordinance; advertisement of ordinances; recording of vote. 
(a)  Form of ordinance. No ordinance shall be passed unless it has been introduced in writing at a meeting of the council. The object of each such ordinance shall be expressed in its title. For a proposed ordinance to be adopted, a reading shall be undertaken of its title. 
(b)  Advertisement of ordinances. Except as otherwise authorized by law or as a declared emergency ordinance, no ordinance shall be passed until after descriptive notice of an intention to propose the same for passage shall prior to its passage have been published once a week for two successive weeks in a newspaper published and having a general circulation within Fauquier County, Virginia. The second publication shall not be sooner than one calendar week after the first publication. Such notice shall specify the time and place at which persons affected may appear and present their views, not less than six days nor more than twenty-one (21) days after the second advertisement shall appear in such newspaper. The publication shall include a statement that a copy of the full text of the ordinance is on file in the office of the town manager for the Town of Warrenton. During all such time subsequent to the first publication until passage, a written copy of the ordinance shall be placed on file for public inspection during regular business hours at the office of the town manager. 
(c)  Enactment of ordinance; recording of vote. Any ordinance read at one (1) such meeting may be amended and passed as amended at such meeting without the necessity of further public hearing provided the amendment does not materially change the ordinance. In the event such amendment does materially change an ordinance, a further public hearing after publication notice provided herein must be held prior to adoption. The ayes and nayes shall be taken and recorded upon passage of all ordinances and entered upon the journal of the proceedings of council. 
(Code 1981, § 2-13; Ord. No. 1990-6, 10-9-9; Ord. No. 1994-12, 10-11-94) 
State constitution reference- Recording of how each member votes on ordinances and resolutions, Article VII, § 7. 
Sec. 2-72. - Effective dates; emergency measures. 
(a)  Effective date of ordinance. After enactment of ordinances by the town council, such ordinance shall become effective upon adoption or upon a date affixed by the council. 
(b)  Emergency measures. The council, may by the affirmative vote of five (5) of its members pass emergency measures without publication of notice of intention. An emergency measure is an ordinance for the immediate preservation of the public peace, property, health or safety or providing for the daily operation of a municipal department. The emergency shall be stated in every such measure. 
(Code 1981, § 2-14; Ord. No. 1994-12, 10-11-94) 
Sec. 2-73. - Form in which introduced. 
(a)  All proposed ordinances introduced in the town council shall be in printed or typewritten form. 
(b)  All proposed resolutions having the effect of an ordinance shall be in writing. 
(Code 1981, § 2-15) 
Sec. 2-74. - Enacting clause. 
(a)  The enacting clause of all ordinances passed by the town council shall read substantially as follows: "Be it ordained by the Council of the Town of Warrenton, Virginia." 
(b)  The enacting clause of all resolutions passed by the town council shall read as follows: "Be it resolved by The Council of The Town of Warrenton, Virginia." 
(Code 1981, § 2-16) 
Sec. 2-75. - Numbering. 
    All ordinances of the town shall be consecutively numbered in annual series, the number of a particular ordinance to consist of the year in which passed and the consecutive number of the ordinance. 
(Code 1981, § 2-17) 
Sec. 2-76. - Ordinance book-Generally. 
    The town recorder shall enter in a permanent well-bound book copies of all ordinances passed by the town council. The book in which ordinances are thus entered shall be known as the "Ordinances at Large of the Town of Warrenton, Virginia" and shall be indexed. 
(Code 1981, § 2-18) 
Sec. 2-77. - Same-Notation as to amendment. 
    The town recorder shall write on the first page of every ordinance entered in the ordinance book if such ordinance has been amended or repealed, with a reference to the page of the ordinance book where the amending or repealing ordinance can be found. 
(Code 1981, § 2-19) 
Sec. 2-78. - Effect of repeal. 
    No new ordinance shall be construed to repeal a former ordinance as to any offense committed against the former ordinance or as to any act done or penalty, forfeiture or punishment incurred or as to any right accrued or claim arising under the former ordinance or in any way whatsoever to affect any such offense or act committed or done, penalty, forfeiture or punishment incurred, right accrued, or claim arising before the new ordinance takes effect, save only that the precedings thereafter had shall conform, so far as practicable, to the ordinance in force at the time of such proceedings. 
(Code 1981, § 2-20) 
Sec. 2-79. - Revival of former ordinance upon repeal of repealer. 
    When an ordinance which has repealed another shall itself be repealed, the previous ordinance shall not be revived without express words to that effect. 
(Code 1981, § 2-21) 
State Law reference- Repeal not to revive former law, Code of Virginia, § 1-17. 
Secs. 2-80-2-95. - Reserved.

Footnotes:

Editor's note- From time to time, the town adopts position classification and pay plans. The current provisions are on file in the office of the town recorder. 
Charter reference- Appointment and removal of officers and employees, § 6-2.

Sec. 2-96. - Town recorder. 
    The town council shall appoint a recorder. The recorder shall attend all meetings of the town council and keep a record of the proceedings. He shall have such other functions, powers and duties as may be provided by the town council. 
(Code 1981, § 2-31) 
Charter reference- Appointment, duties, compensation and term of town recorder, § 3-8. 
Secs. 2-97-2-110. - Reserved.

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Charter reference- Appointment, duties, compensation and term of town attorney, § 3-7. 

Sec. 2-111. - Appointment; qualifications. 
    The town council shall appoint an attorney for the town who shall have been admitted to practice in the courts of the state and who shall be a licensed practicing attorney. 
(Code 1981, § 2-22) 
State Law reference- Attorneys at law, Code of Virginia, § 54-42 et seq. 
Sec. 2-112. - Powers and duties generally. 
    The town attorney shall have the management, charge and control of all legal affairs of the town and shall be the legal adviser of the town council or any committee thereof, town officers and the several departments of the town government. When required by the mayor or town manager, he shall furnish written or verbal opinions upon any legal affairs of the town. 
(Code 1981, § 2-23) 
Secs. 2-113-2-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TOWN MANAGER[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Charter reference- Town manager, Art. VI. 
Cross reference- Responsibility for cemetery, § 5-2. 

Sec. 2-126. - Appointment and term. 
    The town manager shall be appointed by the town council and shall hold office at the pleasure of the council. 
(Code 1981, § 2-24) 
Sec. 2-127. - Duties generally. 
    The town manager shall be the general administrative and executive head of the town and he shall exercise all functions and powers vested in him by the town council or conferred upon him by this Code or other ordinances of the town. He shall have supervision and control over all employees, agents or representatives of the town, except the town recorder and the town attorney, and of all agents, departments and branches of the municipal government. He shall exercise general supervision over the care, maintenance and operation of all town property. He shall be responsible to the town council and shall make such reports to it and at such times as the council shall deem proper. 
(Code 1981, § 2-25) 
Secs. 2-128-2-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - FINANCE DIRECTOR[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Charter reference- Financial administration generally, Art. VII; annual audit, Art. VIII. 

Sec. 2-141. - Appointment and term. 
    The finance director shall be appointed by the town manager and shall serve at his pleasure. In the event of a vacancy in the office, the town manager shall serve as finance director. 
(Code 1981, § 2-26) 
Sec. 2-142. - Powers and duties, deputy director. 
(a)  The finance director shall have charge, subject to the direction and control of the town manager, of the administration of the financial affairs of the town and shall perform all the duties of a town treasurer and such other duties as may be directed by the town manager or ordinances of the town. 
(b)  The finance director may appoint a deputy finance director, subject to approval of the town manager. 
(Code 1981, § 2-27) 
Sec. 2-143. - Bond. 
    Before entering upon the duties of his office, the finance director shall execute a bond, the premium on which shall be paid by the town, with surety approved by the town attorney and in an amount approved by the town council, conditioned upon the faithful discharge of the duties of his office. Such bond shall be for the proper collection of and accounting for all moneys received or which it shall be his duty to collect and for the payment of all moneys by him to those entitled to receive same. 
(Code 1981, § 2-28) 
Sec. 2-144. - Receipt and disbursement of funds. 
    The finance director shall receive all funds due and payable to the town and shall make all authorized disbursements for and on behalf of the town as provided in this Code or authorized by the town council. 
(Code 1981, § 2-29) 
Sec. 2-145. - Right of distress, levy, etc. 
    For the purposes of collecting taxes, license taxes, assessments and other money, revenues and funds due the town, the finance director shall have the right of distress, levy, attachment and all other remedies provided by general law. 
(Code 1981, § 2-30) 
State Law reference- Collection of local taxes by distress, suit, lien, etc., Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3940. 
Secs. 2-146-2-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PLANNING COMMISSION[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
State Law reference- Planning, subdivision of land and zoning, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-427 et seq.; planning commissions generally, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-427.1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-161. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a planning commission for the town. 
(Code 1981, § 2-33) 
State Law reference- Duty of council to create planning commission, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-427.1. 
Sec. 2-162. - Composition; appointment and terms of members. 
    The planning commission shall be composed of not less than five (5) nor more than fifteen (15) members, who shall be appointed by the town council, all of whom shall be residents of the town qualified by knowledge and experience to make decisions on questions of community growth and development; at least half of such members shall be freeholders. One (1) member of the commission may be a member of the town council and one (1) member may be a member of the administrative branch of government of the town. The term of each of these two (2) members shall be coextensive with the term of the office to which they have been elected or appointed unless the town council, at the first regular meeting of each year, appoints others to serve as their representatives. Neither of these two (2) members is eligible to vote on any issue before the planning commission, however, they may engage in discussions regarding any item brought before the planning commission and they do not have a conflict with said item. The remaining members of the commission shall serve for four (4) years each. 
(Code 1981, § 2-34; Ord. No. 2006-09, 12-12-2006) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-437. 
Sec. 2-163. - Compensation. 
    All members of the planning commission shall serve as such with compensation, as established from time to time by the town council. 
(Code 1981, § 2-35; Ord. No. 1997-02, 3-11-97) 
State Law reference- Compensation of members of the planning commission, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-437. 
Sec. 2-164. - Removal of members. 
    Any member of the planning commission may be removed from office for malfeasance in office. 
(Code 1981, § 2-36) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-437. 
Sec. 2-165. - Filling of vacancies. 
    Vacancies upon the planning commission, however caused, shall be filled by the council for the unexpired term only. 
(Code 1981, § 2-37) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-437. 
Sec. 2-166. - Powers and duties. 
    The planning commission shall have the functions, powers and duties and shall be subject to the limitations which are prescribed by law. 
(Code 1981, § 2-38) 
State Law reference- General powers and duties of planning commissions, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.1-428, 15.1-439 et seq. 
Secs. 2-167-2-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PUBLIC PROCUREMENT; SURPLUS PROPERTY[11] 
Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
State Law reference- Virginia Public Procurement Act, Code of Virginia, § 11-35 et seq.; acquiring property adjoining parks, monuments, streets, etc., Code of Virginia, § 15.1-275; acquiring public utilities, land, rights-of-way, fixtures, etc., Code of Virginia, § 15.1-292; acceptance or refusal of gifts, donations, bequests, grants, etc., Code of Virginia, § 15.1-848. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-181. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Brand name or equal specification: A specification limited to one (1) or more items by manufacturers' name or catalog numbers to describe the standard of quality performance, and other salient characteristics needed to meet town requirements and which provides for the submission of equivalent products. 
    Brand name specification: A specification limited to one (1) or more items by manufacturers' names or catalog numbers. 
    Business: Any corporation, partnership, individual, sole proprietorship, joint stock company, joint venture or any other private legal entity. 
    Change order (unilateral): A written order signed and unilaterally issued by the town manager directing the contractor to make changes which the "changes" clauses of the contract authorizes the town manager to order without the consent of the contractor. 
    Confidential information: Any information which is available to an employee only because of the employee's status as an employee of this town and is not a matter of public knowledge or available to the public on request. 
    Construction: Building, altering, repairing, improving or demolishing any structure, building or highway and any draining, dredging, excavation, grading or similar work upon real property. 
    Construction management contract: A contract in which a party is retained by the owner to coordinate and administer contracts for construction services for the benefit of the owner, and may also include, if provided in the contract, the furnishing of construction services to the owner. 
    Contract: All types of town agreements, regardless of what they may be called, for the procurement of goods, services, insurance or construction. 
    Contract modification: Any written alteration in specifications, delivery point, rate of delivery, period of performance, price, quantity, or other provision of any contract accomplished by mutual action of the parties to the contract. 
    Contractor: Any person having a contract with the town or a using agency thereof. 
    Cost reimbursement contract: A contract under which a contractor is reimbursed for costs which are allowable and allocable in accordance with the contract terms and the provisions of this article, and a fee or profit, if any. 
    Direct or indirect participation: Involvement through decision, approval, disapproval, recommendation, preparation of any part of a purchase request, influencing the content of any specification or procurement standard, rendering of advice, investigation, auditing, or in any other advisory capacity. 
    Employee: An individual drawing a salary or wages from the town whether elected or not; also any noncompensated individual performing personal services for the town or any department, agency, commission, council, board or any other entity established by the executive or legislative branch of this town and any noncompensated individual serving as an elected official of the town. 
    Goods: All materials, equipment, supplies, printing and automated data processing hardware and software. 
    Informality: A minor defect or variation of a bid or proposal from the exact requirements of the invitation to bid or the request for proposal, which does not affect the price, quality, quantity or delivery schedule for the goods, services or construction being procured. 
    Insurance: A contract whereby, for a stipulated consideration, one party undertakes to compensate the other for loss on a specified subject by specified perils.
