Sec. 10-3. - Powers of town manager to designate stop or yield right-of-way intersections and to promulgate parking regulations. 
(a)  The town manager may designate intersections at which vehicles shall come to a full stop or yield the right-of-way and may cause to be erected appropriate signs or markers at such intersections so that an ordinarily observant person will be aware of the existence of such designation. 
(b)  The town manager may classify vehicles with reference to parking and may designate the time, place and manner such vehicles may be allowed to park on town streets, and may make and enforce such additional rules and regulations as parking conditions may require. When any parking regulation is established, pursuant to this paragraph, the town manager shall cause to be erected appropriate signs or markers so that an ordinarily observant person, who may be affected by such regulation, will be aware of such regulation. 
(c)  When any regulation is made pursuant to this section and when appropriate signs or markers have been erected as required by this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to violate any such regulation. 
(Code 1981, § 9-1.1) 
State Law reference- Designation of stop and yield right-of-way intersections, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1301; local parking regulations, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1220. 
Sec. 10-4. - Direction of traffic by police officers. 
    Every police officer of the town is authorized to act as a traffic officer in the direction of traffic on any highway where traffic is heavy or continuous. 
(Code 1981, § 9-2) 
Sec. 10-5. - Speed limits on certain streets, etc. 
(a)  Thirty-five (35) miles per hour. Upon the streets and parts of streets set out in this subsection, the maximum speed limit is hereby established as thirty-five (35) miles per hour. No person shall drive a vehicle upon the following such streets or parts of streets in excess of thirty-five (35) [miles] per hour: 
(1)  Walker Drive from its intersection with Lee Street to the point of intersection with Breezewood Drive. 
(2)  Lee Street from its intersection with the eastern town limits to the point of intersection with Falmouth Street. 
(3)  Broadview Avenue from the town incorporated limits to intersection with Lee Highway. 
(4)  Blackwell Road from Lee Highway to a point two hundred (200) feet north of the intersection of Old Alexandria Pike. 
(b)  Forty (40) miles per hour. Upon the streets and parts of streets set out in this subsection, the maximum speed limit is hereby established as forty (40) miles per hour. No person shall drive a vehicle upon the following such streets or parts of streets in excess of forty (40) miles per hour: 
(1)  Broadview Avenue between intersection with Winchester Street and intersection with Waterloo Street. 
(2)  East Shirley Avenue - From the Southern Corporation Limit (SCL) to eight hundred fifty (850) feet west and from two thousand three hundred forty (2,340) feet west of the SCL to the intersection of East Shirley Avenue and Broadview Avenue. 
(3)  Frost Avenue. 
(4)  Lee Highway. 
(5)  West Shirley Avenue. 
(c)  Fifty-five (55) miles per hour. Upon the streets and parts of streets set out in this subsection, the maximum speed limit is hereby established as fifty-five (55) miles per hour. No person shall drive a vehicle upon the following such streets or parts of street in excess of such fifty-five (55) miles per hour: Route 17 spur from the east corporate limits of town to the north corporate limits. 
(Code 1981, § 9-4; Ord. No. 1989-4, 5-2-89; Ord. No. 1990-7, 12-11-90; Ord. No. 1994-17, 12-13-94; Ord. No. 1997-14, 1-13-98; Ord. No. 1998-1, 4-14-98; Ord. No. 2002-03, 1-8-2002; Ord. No. 2005-01, 3-8-2005; Ord. No. 2005-06, 6-14-2005; Ord. No. 2006-01, 3-14-2006; Ord. No. 2019-01 , 1-8-19) 
State Law reference- Maximum speed limit in city and town business and residence districts-Section 46.2-874 of the Code of Virginia of 1950 as amended; Maximum speed limit on other highways in cities and towns-Section 46.2-875; Authority to change speed limits-Section 46.2-878 of the Code of Virginia of 1950, as amended. 
Sec. 10-6. - One-way streets. 
(a)  The following streets are hereby established and designated as one-way streets and, except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, it shall be unlawful for any vehicle to be driven or moved on such streets in a direction other than as herein set forth: 
(1)  Academy Hill Road, from High Street to Boundary Lane, for traffic moving north. 
(2)  Calhoun Street, from Maine Street to Horner Street, for traffic moving north. 
(3)  Court Street, from Main Street to Hotel Street, for traffic moving south. 
(4)  Culpeper Street, from Lee Street to Main Street, for traffic moving north. 
(5)  Haiti Street, from Liberty Street to North Street, for traffic moving north. 
(6)  Fourth Street, from Main Street to East Lee Street, for traffic moving south. 
(7)  Second Street, from Main Street to East Lee Street, for traffic moving south. 
(8)  Smith Street, for Winchester Street to Waterloo Street for traffic moving south. 
(9)  Third Street, from Main Street to East Lee Street, for traffic moving south from Lee Street to Main Street for traffic moving north. 
(b)  This section shall become effective as to any such one-way street when signs have been provided therefor as set out in subsection (c) of this section. 
(c)  The town manager is authorized and directed to provide signs on the one-way streets designated in this section as will apprise an ordinarily observant person of such one-way streets. 
(d)  When it can be demonstrated to the satisfaction of the town manager or his duly authorized representative that the strict enforcement of this section will cause an unreasonable hardship on some particular person or persons relative to the loading and unloading of trucks or other vehicles on such one-way streets, then in such event the town manager or his duly authorized representative is authorized to issue a special permit to such person or persons permitting a variance from the provisions of this section. Any such special permit shall be in writing and shall specify the nature of such variance and the place and period of time when such variance shall be permitted. Such permit shall only be issued when it can be demonstrated to the satisfaction of the town manager or his duly authorized representative that the granting of such permit will alleviate a clearly demonstrable hardship as distinguished from a special privilege or convenience to the person or persons who seek such permit. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5; Ord. No. 1986-6, 8-5-86; Ord. No. 1989-1, 5-2-89; Ord. No. 1993-2, 3-9-93; Ord. No. 2001-18, 11-13-2001; Ord. No. 2016-07 , 10-11-16) 
Sec. 10-7. - Motor truck routes and tractor trailer truck routes. 
(a)  Vehicles prohibited. The use of any street, or portion of street, hereinafter designated, by truck, trailer, and semi-trailer other than pickup trucks not exceeding an actual gross weight of seven thousand five hundred (7,500) pounds, except for the purpose of receiving passengers or goods or making residential deliveries, is prohibited, and the town manager is authorized and directed to erect suitable signs at such places as may be necessary to notify drivers of such vehicles of this prohibition. 
(b)  Definitions. For purposes of this chapter the definitions of truck, trailer and semi-trailer defined in Section 46.2-100 of the Code of Virginia, as may be amended from time to time, are incorporated herein by reference. 
(c)  Operators of trucks, trailers and semi-trailers shall be restricted to the use of the following named streets in passing through the town: 
(1)  Broadview Avenue. 
(2)  East Shirley Avenue. 
(3)  Frost Avenue. 
(4)  Lee Highway. 
(5)  West Shirley Avenue. 
(d)  [ Specific prohibitions. ] Specifically all trucks, trailers and semi-trailers are prohibited from driving on Falmouth Street beginning at the intersection of Falmouth Street and Old Meetze Road through to the intersection of Falmouth Street and E. Lee Street. 
(e)  Exceptions: 
(1)  Fire trucks or other emergency vehicles on emergency business. 
(2)  Road repair, construction or maintenance vehicles while involved in repair, construction or maintenance of roads. 
(3)  Garbage service vehicles while providing services to town residents. 
(4)  Vehicles owned by the Town of Warrenton. 
(f)  Penalty for violation. The driver of any such vehicle operated in violation of this section shall be guilty of a Class 4 misdemeanor for each occurrence. 
(Code 1981, § 9-6; Ord. No. 1989-3, 5-2-89; Ord. No. 2007-04, 12-11-07) 
Sec. 10-8. - Permits for parades and processions. 
    No funeral procession or parade, excepting the military forces of the United States, the military forces of the state and the forces of the police and fire departments of the town, shall occupy, march or proceed along any street, except in accordance with a permit issued by the town manager and such other regulations as are set forth in this chapter which may apply. 
(Code 1981, § 9-10.2) 
State Law reference- Power of town to permit the temporary use of streets from other than public purposes, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-14(9). 
Sec. 10-9. - Powers of town manager to designate reduced speed limits through construction zones. 
    The town manager may designate for a temporary period not to exceed sixty (60) days, a reduced speed limit upon any portion of street or highway of the town on which work is being done or where the street or highway is under construction or repair. The street or highway work zone shall be indicated by appropriately placed signs displaying the reduced maximum speed limit. Such designation shall constitute a "highway work zone" under section 46.2-878.1 of the Code of Virginia and a violation thereof shall be unlawful and constitute a traffic infraction punishable by fine of not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) as provided therein. 
(Ord. No. 1995-10, 8-8-95) 
State Law reference- Decreased maximum speed limits in highway work zone, Code of Virginia § 46.2-878.1; powers of local authorities generally; maximum penalties, Code of Virginia § 46.2-1300. 
Secs. 10-10. - Additional assessment for electronic summons system. 
(a)  The sum of five dollars ($5.00) is hereby assessed as part of the costs in each criminal or traffic case in the Juvenile and Domestic Relations Court, General District Court, and Circuit Court of the county, in which the defendant is charged with a violation of any statute or ordinance within the town limits. The assessment shall be collected by the clerk of the court in which the action is filed, remitted to the town treasurer, and held by the town treasurer subject to disbursements by the town council to the Warrenton Police Department solely to fund software, hardware, and associated equipment costs for the implementation and maintenance of an electronic summons system. 
(b)  The assessment provided for herein shall be in addition to any other fees prescribed by law. 
( Ord. No. 2015-04, 8-11-15 ) 
State Law reference- Statutory authority, Code of Virginia § 17.1-279.1. 
Secs. 10-11-10-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSING OF VEHICLES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-07 , adopted Aug. 14, 2018, amended Art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. II, §§ 10-26-10-35, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1981, §§ 9-11-9-19, 9-20; Ord. No. 1991-9, adopted Jan. 14, 1992; Ord. No. 1991-17, adopted Jan. 14, 1992; Ord. Sec. 10-26. - License registration fee required; exceptions. 
    The town hereby levies and assesses a license registration fee on every motor vehicle, including, but not limited to, automobiles and trucks having a situs pursuant to Code of Virginia § 58.1-3511, except: 
(1)  Vehicles used by an active member of the Warrenton Volunteer Fire and Rescue Company (WVFC), provided, however, that active members of WVFC shall provide to the finance director at the time of declaration of personal property a written certification by the WVFC chief that said applicant is an active member, and is a member whose name appears in the book of "volunteer fire fighters" kept by the clerk of the circuit court. The exception shall apply to no more than one (1) vehicle. 
(2)  Vehicles owned or leased by a person who is sixty-five (65) years of age or older shall be entitled to a fifty (50) percent reduction in the license registration fee assessed on that vehicle, provided that no such discount shall be available for more than one (1) vehicle owned or leased by the same person. 
(3)  Vehicles owned by town residents who are disabled veterans and have been issued special "DV" plates. The exception shall apply to no more than one (1) vehicle. 
(4)  Military personnel are entitled to an exception for one (1) vehicle. No exception applies to their spouses. 
(5)  Antique motor vehicles as defined in Code of Virginia, § 46.2-100, as amended, are eligible for an exception. 
    The exceptions noted above do not apply if any taxes are due. 
(Ord. No. 2018-07 , 8-14-18) 
Sec. 10-27. - Amount of fee-motor vehicles; motorcycles. 
    The cost of the license registration fee required by this article shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00); except fifteen dollars ($15.00) for motorcycles and similar two-wheel vehicles. Purchasers of new or used automobiles shall be billed for such fee on the supplemental bill for such vehicle as may be required. 
(Ord. No. 2018-07 , 8-14-18) 
Sec. 10-28. - Limitations. 
    This article is subject to the limitations on the imposition of such license registration fees by the town as are set forth in Code of Virginia, §§ 46.2-663, 46.2-683, 46.2-750, 46.2-752 and 46.2-755, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 2018-07 , 8-14-18) 
Sec. 10-29. - Vehicle registration fee year. 
    The vehicle registration year shall commence on January 1 of each year. The annual fee shall be payable December 5 of every year or the billing date for subsequent assessments made for that calendar year. The fee shall be collected as taxes are collected. 
(Ord. No. 2018-07 , 8-14-18) 
Sec. 10-30. - Transfer of license registration fees; refunds. 
    The license registration fee shall not be transferable between persons or vehicles. There shall be no refund of the license registration fee imposed herein for vehicles sold or otherwise disposed of during the tax year. 
(Ord. No. 2018-07 , 8-14-18) 
Sec. 10-31. - Collection. 
    The finance director shall, after the due date for any license registration fee required under this section, collect such license registration fee in accordance with the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3919 and any other applicable state law. Additionally the finance director shall have the authority to take any action authorized by Code of Virginia, § 46.2-752. 
(Ord. No. 2018-07 , 8-14-18) 
State Law reference- Ordinance providing amount of local license fee or tax on vehicles, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-752. 
Secs. 10-32-10-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - REGULATIONS APPLICABLE IN EVENT OF SNOW, SLEET, ETC.[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Regulation of operation of vehicles in snow, sleet, etc., Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1302. 

Sec. 10-61. - Penalties for violation of article. 
    In addition to the charges for storage and removal referred to in section 10-64, any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined not to exceed twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each such offense. 
(Code 1981, § 9-25) 
Sec. 10-62. - Purpose of article. 
    The purpose of this article is hereby declared to be the regulation of the operation of vehicles on the streets in the town, in the event of snow, sleet, hail, freezing rain, ice, water, flood, high wind or storm or the threat thereof. 
(Code 1981, § 9-21) 
Sec. 10-63. - Snow routes-Enumerated; posting. 
(a)  The streets set out in this section are hereby declared to be snow routes and shall be so designated and posted. 
(b)  The streets referred to in the first paragraph of this section are hereby enumerated as follows: 
(1)  Alexandria Pike. 
(2)  Blackwell Road. 
(3)  Broadview Avenue. 
(4)  Culpeper Street. 
(5)  East Shirley Avenue. 
(6)  Falmouth Street. 
(7)  Frost Avenue. 
(8)  Lee Highway. 
(9)  Main Street. 
(10)  Waterloo Street. 
(11)  West Shirley Avenue. 
(12)  Winchester Street. 
(Code 1981, § 9-22) 
Sec. 10-64. - Same-Regulations generally. 
    In the event of snow, sleet, hail, freezing rain, ice, water, flood, high wind or storm or the threat thereof: 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle on any of the streets enumerated in section 10-63. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct or impede traffic on any of the streets enumerated in section 10-63 by reason of his failure to have the vehicle operated by him equipped with snow tires or chains. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon a vehicle on any of the streets enumerated in section 10-63. 
(4)  Vehicles that are stalled, stuck, parked or abandoned on any of the streets enumerated in section 10-63 may be removed by the police. 
(5)  Vehicles removed pursuant to subsection (d) of this section shall be stored and a reasonable charge, to be determined by the town manager, is hereby imposed for such removal and storage. 
(Code 1981, § 9-23) 
Sec. 10-65. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1997-02, adopted March 11, 1997, repealed § 10-65 in its entirety. Formerly, § 10-65 pertained to play areas for sledding, etc., and derived from § 9-24 of the 1981 Code. 
Secs. 10-66-10-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PARKING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-81. - Notice of violation; payment of penalty, contest. 
    It shall be the duty of police officers of the town, in the event a vehicle is found parked in violation of the parking regulations promulgated by the town manager pursuant to section 10-3 of this Code, to attach to the vehicle in question a notice to the owner or operator thereof that such vehicle has been parked in violation of a parking regulation, and instructing such owner or operator as follows: 
(1)  Uncontested payment of a parking violation may be made in person or by mail to the town in the amount provided by the parking regulations and indicated on the face of the notice of violation. The payment shall be made within seventy-two (72) hours from the issuance of the notice of violation. 
(2)  The vehicle owner or operator may contest the violation by notifying the police department within seventy-two (72) hours from the issuance of the notice of violation. A court date and time shall be provided to those persons wishing to contest a violation. Notice of all contested cases shall be given in writing by the police department to the clerk of the general district court. 
(3)  Failure to contest a violation or pay without contest shall result in an additional penalty of five dollars ($5.00) and the issuance of a summons by the police department to the registered owner of the vehicle requiring him or her to appear in court and answer to the violation after notice as prescribed by law. 
(Ord. No. 1981-4, 3-3-81) 
State Law reference- Conditions precedent to issuance of summons for violation of parking ordinance, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-941. 
Sec. 10-82. - Parking for certain purposes restricted, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle of any kind for the purpose of selling or offering for sale from such vehicle, or of accepting orders therefor from such vehicle, any fruit, vegetables or merchandise of any character or for the purpose of advertising or displaying merchandise or samples thereof in or on such vehicle, except in an area designated by the town manager; provided, that a person may properly park a vehicle for the purpose of making deliveries therefrom of merchandise previously sold. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or place any automobile, truck, trailer or other vehicle upon or in any street, alley or parkway for the purpose of selling or offering the same for sale or rent. No sign or lettering shall be attached or placed upon any automobile, truck, trailer or other vehicle parked in or upon any public street, alley or parkway of the city indicating that such vehicle is offered for sale or rent. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for the operator of any truck or trailer loaded with livestock to park such truck or trailer upon any street within the town. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for the operator of any truck or trailer used for the transportation of livestock of any kind to park such truck or trailer when unloaded, upon any street, alley, parking lot or elsewhere within the town for a period longer than one (1) hour in any twenty-four-hour period, if such vehicle is in the condition that it gives off such nauseous, noxious or offensive odors as to constitute a public nuisance. 
(Code 1981, § 9-3) 
Sec. 10-83. - Manner of using loading zones. 
    Where a loading and unloading zone has been set apart by the town manager in accordance with applicable provisions of this chapter, the following regulations shall apply with respect to the use of such areas: 
No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in any place marked as a curb loading zone except for the purpose of the expeditious unloading and delivery or pickup and loading of materials. Such allowed usage shall not exceed one (1) hour. All delivery vehicles, other than regular delivery trucks, using such loading zones shall be identified by the owner's or company's name in letters three (3) inches high on both sides of the vehicle. 
(Code 1981, § 9-7; Ord. No. 1995-16, 2-13-96; Ord. No. 2013-04, 8-13-13 ) 
Sec. 10-84. - Storage of inoperative vehicles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep on any property zoned for residential, commercial or agricultural purposes, any motor vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer, as such are defined in Section 46.2-100 of the Code of Virginia, which is inoperate, unless such motor vehicle, trailer or semi-trailer is kept within a fully enclosed building or structure, or is otherwise shielded or screened from view. 
(b)  As used in this section, "inoperative motor vehicle" shall mean any motor vehicle: 
(1)  Not in operating condition; or 
(2)  Partially or totally disassembled by the removal of tires and wheels, the engine, or other essential parts required for operation of the vehicle, for a period of sixty (60) days or longer; or 
(3)  Not displaying valid license plates; or 
(4)  Not displaying a valid inspection decal. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to licensed business regularly engaged in business as an automobile dealer, salvage dealer or scrap processor. 
(d)  Violation of this section shall constitute a Class Three (3) misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 9-8; Ord. No. 1985-5, 9-3-85; Ord. No. 1991-12, 9-10-91) 
Cross reference- Garbage, trash and weeds, Ch. 8. 
State Law reference- Authority to restrict keeping of inoperative motor vehicles, etc., on residential or commercial property, removal of such vehicles, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-11.1. 
Sec. 10-85. - Disposition of inoperative, abandoned vehicles. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, or the provisions of section 46.2-617 of the Code of Virginia, as amended, any motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer or part thereof found within the corporate limits of the town which is inoperable and by virtue of this condition is an "inoperable motor vehicle" as defined in section 10-84 of this Code, may be disposed of in the following manner: 
(1)  The town manager shall direct the town police to notify the owners of property zoned for residential or commercial or agricultural purposes, on which there is located an inoperable motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer, and the owner of the motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer, to remove the same therefrom within fifteen (15) days after being given notice in writing to remove the same. 
(2)  If the vehicle has not been moved after fifteen (15) days, the town through its own agents or employees may remove any such inoperative vehicle when the owner of the premises or motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer has failed to do so. 
(3)  In the event that the town through its own agents or employees removes any such motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer after having been given such notice, the town may dispose of such motor vehicle after having given additional notice to the owner of the vehicle. 
(4)  The town police shall inform the owner of the motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer and the owner of the premises, that the cost of any such removal or disposal shall be chargeable to the owner of the vehicle or premises and may be collected by the town as taxes and levies are collected. 
(5)  Every cost authorized by this section with which the owner of the premises shall have been assessed shall constitute a lien against the property from which the vehicle was removed, the lien to continue until actual payment of such costs have been made to the town. 
(Code 1981, § 9-8.1; Ord. No. 1983-1, 6-7-83) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-11.1(b). 
Sec. 10-86. - Removal and disposition of certain unattended vehicles. 
(a)  Whenever any motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer is found on the public streets or public grounds unattended by the owner or operator and constitutes a hazard to traffic, or is parked in such manner as to be in violation of the law, or whenever any motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer is left unattended for more than ten (10) days upon any public property or privately owned property other than the property of the owner of such motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer with the town, or is abandoned upon such public property or privately owned property, without the permission of the owner, lessee or occupant thereof, or whenever any motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer is stalled or rendered immobile as the result of adverse weather conditions or other emergency situations on any public roadway, any such motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer may be removed for safekeeping by or under the direction of a police officer to a storage garage or area; however, no such vehicle shall be so removed from privately owned premises without the written request of the owner, lessee or occupant thereof. The person at whose request such motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer is removed from privately owned property shall indemnify the town against any loss or expense incurred by reason of removal, storage or sale thereof. It shall be presumed that such motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer or part thereof is abandoned if: 
(1)  It lacks: 
a.  A current license plate; or 
b.  A current town plate, sticker or decal; or 
c.  A valid state inspection certificate or sticker; and 
(2)  It has been in a specific location for four (4) days without being moved. 
Each removal shall be reported immediately to the chief of police, who shall give notice thereof to the owner of the motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer as promptly as possible. 
(b)  The owner of such vehicle, or trailer or semitrailer, before obtaining possession thereof, shall pay to the persons entitled thereto all reasonable costs incidental to the removal, storage and locating of the owner of the motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer. Should such owner fail or refuse to pay the cost or should the identity or whereabouts of such owner be unknown and unascertainable after a diligent search has been made, and after notice to him at his last known address and to the holder of any lien of record in the office of the state department of motor vehicles against the motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer, the chief of police may, after holding the motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer thirty (30) days and after due notice of sale, dispose of the same at public sale, and the proceeds from the sale shall be forwarded by the chief of police to the town finance director; provided, that if the value of such motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer is determined by three (3) disinterested dealers or garagemen to be less than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00), it may be disposed of by private sale or junked. The finance director shall pay from the proceeds of sale the cost of removal, storage, investigation as to ownership and liens and notice of sale, and the balance of such funds shall be held by him for the owner and paid to the owner upon satisfactory proof of ownership. 
(c)  If no claim has been made by the owner for the proceeds of such sale, the remaining funds may be deposited to the general fund or any special fund of the town. Any such owner shall be entitled to apply to the town within three (3) years from the date of such sale, and if timely application is made therefor, the town shall pay the same to the owner without interest or other charges. No claim shall be made nor shall any suit, action or proceeding be instituted for the recovery of such funds after three (3) years from the date of such sale. 
(d)  Subsections (a)-(c) shall not operate to deprive any person of other remedies available under law to obtain payment from the owner of unattended, abandoned or immobile vehicles for towing, storage or other services rendered. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to leave any motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer or part thereof on the private property of any other person without his consent. Upon complaint of the owner of the property on which such motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer, or part thereof, has been left for more than seventy-two (72) hours, such motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer or part thereof may be removed by or under the direction of a police officer to a storage garage or area. The owners of private property which is normally open to the public for parking shall post or cause to be posted signs warning that vehicles left on the property for more than seventy-two (72) hours will be towed or removed at the expense of the vehicle owner. The person at whose request the vehicle, trailer, semitrailer, or part thereof, is so removed shall indemnify the town against any loss or expense incurred by reason of removal, storage or sale thereof. 
(f)  In the case of the removal of a motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer or part thereof from private property, when the same cannot be readily sold, such motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer or part thereof may be disposed of in such manner as the town council may provide. 
(g)  In all other respects, the provisions of subsections (a)-(d) of this section shall apply to such removals; provided, that disposal of a motor vehicles, trailer or semitrailer may, at the option of the town council, be carried out under either the provisions of subsection (a) of this section or under the provisions of this subsection after a diligent search for the owner, after notice to him at his last known address and to the holder of any lien of record in the office of the state or motor vehicles against such motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer, and after the motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer has been held at least sixty (60) days. 
(h)  The state department of motor vehicles shall be notified of the disposition of any motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer under this section. 
(Code 1981, § 9-9; Ord. No. 1983-1, 6-7-83) 
Sec. 10-87. - Removal or immobilization of motor vehicles having outstanding parking violations. 
(a)  Whenever there is found any motor vehicle parked upon the public streets or public grounds against which there are three (3) or more outstanding unpaid or otherwise unsettled parking violation notices, such vehicle may, by towing or otherwise, be removed or conveyed to a place in the town designated by the chief of police for the temporary storage of such vehicle, or such vehicle may be immobilized in such manner as to prevent its removal or operation except by authorized officers or members of the police department. The removal, conveyance or immobilization of the vehicle shall be by, or under the direction of, an officer or member of the police department. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the officer or member of the police department removing or immobilizing such motor vehicle or under whose direction such vehicle is removed or immobilized, to inform as soon as practicable the owner of the removed or immobilized vehicle of the nature and circumstances of the prior unsettled parking violation notices, for which or on account of which such vehicle was removed or immobilized. In any case involving immobilization of a vehicle pursuant to this section, there shall be placed on such vehicle, in a conspicuous manner, a notice warning that such vehicle has been immobilized and that any attempt to move such vehicle might result in damage thereto. 
(c)  The owner of an immobilized vehicle, or other duly authorized person, shall be allowed twenty-four (24) hours from the time of immobilization to repossess or secure the release of the vehicle. Failure to repossess or secure the release of the vehicle within this time period may result in the removal of such vehicle to a storage area for safekeeping under the direction of a police officer or member of the police department. 
(d)  The owner of such removed or immobilized motor vehicle, or other duly authorized person, shall be permitted to repossess or to secure the release of the vehicle by payment of outstanding parking violation notices for which the vehicle was removed or immobilized and by payment of all reasonable costs incidental to the immobilization, removal and storage of the vehicle, and the efforts to locate the owner of the vehicle. Should such owner fail or refuse to pay such fines and costs; or should the identity or whereabouts of such owner be unknown and unascertainable, such motor vehicle shall be sold in accordance with the procedures set forth in section 10-86(a)-(d). 
(Code 1981, § 9-10) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, §§ 46.2-1216, 46.2-1217. 
Sec. 10-88. - Washing or greasing vehicle on street or sidewalk prohibited. 
    No person shall, for compensation, wash, polish or grease a vehicle upon a street or sidewalk, nor shall the owner of a vehicle permit it to be washed, polished or greased, for compensation, upon a street or sidewalk. 
(Code 1981, §§ 9-10.1, 14-21) 
Sec. 10-89. - Parking in handicapped designated parking spaces. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle not displaying a license plate, decal or special parking permit, issued under Code of Virginia, section 46.2-731, 46.2-739 or 46.2-1238, in a parking space reserved for the handicapped on public property or at privately owned parking areas open to the public. A motor vehicle shall be unlawfully parked if it does not display an appropriate state identification for a handicapped person. Notice of violation for such offense shall be issued by the town police officers pursuant to section 10-81 of this Code. 
(b)  The town manager shall designate handicapped parking spaces and shall cause to be erected appropriate above-grade signs so that an ordinarily observant person will be aware of this section. The signs shall conform to the Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices adopted by the Virginia Department of Highways and Transportation and ordinances of the town. Signs on privately owned parking areas shall be erected at the expense of the owner or lessee of such areas. 
(c)  Any violation of this section shall be a Class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 1984-6.1, 10-9-84) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1237. 
Sec. 10-90. - General parking prohibitions. 
    No person shall park a vehicle except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a law enforcement officer or traffic control devices in the following manner or places: 
(1)  On a sidewalk, or in any manner which blocks travel on, access to, or access from any sidewalk; 
(2)  In front of a public or private driveway; 
(3)  Within an intersection; 
(4)  Within fifteen (15) feet of a fire hydrant located on private or public property or within a fire lane as defined in section 7-33 of the Code of the Town of Warrenton; 
(5)  On a crosswalk; 
(6)  Within thirty (30) feet upon the approach to any flashing beacon, stop sign or traffic control signal located at the side of a roadway; 
(7)  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty (30) feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless a different length is indicated by official signs or markings; 
(8)  Within fifty (50) feet of the nearest rail of a railroad grade crossing; 
(9)  Within twenty (20) feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station within seventy-five (75) feet of the entrance when properly signposted; 
(10)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when such parking would obstruct traffic; 
(11)  On the roadway side of any vehicle parked at the edge or curb of a street; 
(12)  Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a street or highway or within a tunnel; 
(13)  At any place where official signs prohibit parking; 
(14)  When the vehicle fails to display a current valid decal of the Town of Warrenton or other political jurisdiction. 
(15)  When the vehicle fails to display a valid state inspection sticker and valid state license plate. 
(Ord. No. 1994-18, 12-13-94; Ord. No. 1998-14, 11-10-98) 
Sec. 10-91. - Parking of certain commercial vehicles in residential areas prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  No person shall park any truck, trailer or semitrailer, bus or other commercial vehicle on or along roads, highways and streets in any area of the town zoned for residential uses; provided that, during regularly scheduled school hours, school buses may be parked in such residential areas by their drivers for a continuous period not to exceed six (6) hours. 
(b)  This section shall not be applicable to commercial vehicles picking up or discharging passengers or merchandise or temporarily parked for necessary repairs or pursuant to the performance of work or service in residential areas. 
(c)  Areas zoned for residential use includes all areas of the town which have been zoned to a zoning classification which permits one (1) or more residential dwelling units. The zoning boundaries shall be used in the enforcement of the requirements of this subsection. However, in any case in which a highway serves as the boundary between an area zoned for residential use and an area zoned for another use, then the centerline of that highway shall be considered as the boundary between the area zoned for residential use and the area zoned for another use. In such cases, the prohibitions of this subsection shall apply only to the side of the highway that abuts the area zoned for residential use. 
(d)  In any prosecution under this section 10-91, proof that the vehicle described in the complaint, summons or warrant was parked in violation of such rule or regulation, together with proof that the defendant was at the time of such parking the registered owner of the vehicle, as required by Code of Virginia, § 46.2-600, shall constitute in evidence a rebuttable presumption that such registered owner of the vehicle was the person who parked the vehicle at the place where and for the time during which such violation occurred. 
(e)  For any purpose of this section, the term "commercial vehicle" shall mean every motor vehicle in excess of twenty (20) feet in length or seven (7) feet in height; other than a passenger car or passenger van, which is clearly designated by visible writing on the vehicle to be a van pool vehicle. The term shall also include any construction equipment, cranes, well digging apparatus and other heavy equipment, except when such equipment is being used for construction activities at sites where building permits are in force. 
(f)  Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this section shall be fined not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) 
(Ord. No. 2000-05, 6-13-2000) 
State Law reference- Code of Virginia § 15.2-2001 
Secs. 10-92-10-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PARKING LOTS 

Sec. 10-106. - Municipal parking lots. 
(a)  The municipal parking lots now or hereafter acquired or established by the town shall be under the supervision of the town manager and he is hereby authorized to make and enforce rules and regulations as parking conditions require. 
(b)  When any parking regulation is established pursuant to this section, the town manager shall cause to be erected, appropriate signs or markers so that an ordinarily observant person who may be affected by such regulation will be aware of such regulation. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle in any municipal parking lot in violation of any ordinance or regulation established pursuant to this section. 
(Ord. No. 1981-3, § 9-35, 3-3-81) 
Sec. 10-107. - Other public parking lots. 
(a)  Any parking lot open to the public and designed to accommodate fifty (50) or more vehicles pursuant to Code of Virginia, section 46.2-1219 shall be subject to the applicable regulations as set forth in title 46.2 and Article 2, Chapter 7 of Title 18.2 of the Code of Virginia. 
(b)  The owner or lessee of such public parking lot shall install at his expense the necessary signs and other marking to regulate the flow of vehicular and pedestrian traffic, parking and speed limits within such parking lots. 
(c)  Any parking regulations, times of operations, signs and markings shall be subject to the designation and approval of the town manager and such signs shall conform to the Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices adopted by the state department of highways and transportation and the town. 
(Ord. No. 1981-3, § 9-36, 3-3-81) 
Secs. 10-108-10-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BICYCLES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-121. - Carrying extra passengers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person riding or operating a bicycle designed to carry only one (1) person, to carry any extra passengers in any business district. 
(Code 1981, § 9-26) 
Sec. 10-122. - Skating, skateboarding and riding of bicycles prohibited on certain sidewalks and crosswalks. 
    The use of roller skates or skateboards and/or the riding of bicycles on any designated sidewalks or crosswalks, located in a commercial or industrial zoning district, including those of any church, school, recreational facility or any business property open to the public where such activity is prohibited by the owner, is hereby prohibited. 
    The town manager shall designate the sidewalks and/or crosswalks where skating, skateboarding and/or bicycle riding shall be prohibited. Signs indicating such prohibition shall be conspicuously posted in the general area where skating, skateboarding and/or bicycle riding is prohibited. 
    A violation of this section shall be punishable by a civil penalty of not more than fifty dollars ($50.00) per occurrence. 
(Ord. No. 1988-6, 10-11-88; Ord. No. 1999-6, 7-13-99) 
State Law reference- Power to regulate, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-904. 
Secs. 10-123-10-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REGISTRATION[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Power of town to require the licensing of bicycles or mopeds, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-133; registration of bicycle serial numbers, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-908. 

Sec. 10-136. - Generally. 
    No person who resides within the limits of the town shall ride or propel a bicycle on any street in the town unless and until the bicycle has been registered and a decal attached thereto as provided in this division. 
(Code 1981, § 9-28) 
Sec. 10-137. - Application and issuance. 
(a)  Applications for registration to operate a bicycle shall be made to the police department upon a form to be approved by the town manager and such application forms shall be secured at police headquarters or other locations designated by the chief of police. 
(b)  Upon presentation of such application in proper form, along with payment of the registration fee, the police department shall provide at the expense of the town a certificate of registration and a decal. 
(Code 1981, § 9-29) 
Sec. 10-138. - Term; display of decal generally. 
    The registration shall be for the life of the bicycle and the decal shall remain displayed on the bicycle for which it was issued during the period such bicycle is operated within the town. 
(Code 1981, § 9-30) 
Sec. 10-139. - Records. 
    A record shall be kept in the police department, which record shall show the name, address and age of the owner of each registered bicycle, the date of registration and sufficient information to identify such bicycle. 
(Code 1981, § 9-31) 
Sec. 10-140. - Reports of sale, etc.; transfers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or transfer ownership of any bicycle without reporting the sale or transfer to the police department within forty-eight (48) hours. The purchaser or transferee of any such bicycle shall apply for a transfer of registration thereof within five (5) days from the time the bicycle is acquired. 
(Code 1981, § 9-32) 
Sec. 10-141. - Fees. 
    The registration fee to be paid for each bicycle registered shall be fixed from time to time by the town council. Once a bicycle has been registered in a given name, the registration thereof may be transferred from one (1) owner to another without payment of an additional fee. 
(Code 1981, § 9-33) 
Sec. 10-142. - Stamping number on frame; destroying, etc., stamped number. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person willfully or maliciously to remove, destroy, mutilate or alter the number upon the frame of any bicycle registered pursuant to this division. Nothing in this division shall be construed to prohibit the police department from stamping a number on the frame of a bicycle on which no serial number can be found or on which such number is illegible or insufficient for identification purposes. 
(Code 1981, § 9-34) 
Chapter 11 - OFFENSES-MISCELLANEOUS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Crimes and offenses generally, Code of Virginia, Title 18.2. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 11-1. - Advertising; posting notices, etc., on poles, trees, buildings or fences. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to put in any manner any notices or advertising matter on any telegraph, electric light or telephone pole or upon any tree or upon any building or fence in the town, without the consent of the owner of the pole, building, fence or tree in question. If any person shall employ a minor to post notices and advertising matter, he shall be responsible for the acts of such minor and shall be liable to the penalty provided for the violation of the foregoing provisions of this section. 
(Code 1981, § 10-1) 
State Law reference- Employment of persons under fourteen years of age in streets or public places, Code of Virginia, § 40.1-83. 
Sec. 11-2. - Assault and battery. 
    Any person who shall commit a simple assault or assault and battery shall be guilty of a Class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 10-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-57. 
Sec. 11-3. - Attempts. 
    Every person who attempts to commit an offense which is a misdemeanor shall be punishable by the same punishment prescribed for the offense the commission of which was the object of the attempt. 
(Code 1981, § 10-3) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-27. 
Sec. 11-4. - Bad checks; fee for passing. 
    If any person shall publish or pass any check or draft for the payment of taxes or other sums due the town, which check or draft is subsequently returned for insufficient funds, or because there is no account, or the account has been closed, a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) will be charged to such person for passing such check or draft. 
(Code 1981, § 10-4; Ord. No. 1991-5, 5-14-91) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-29.4. 
Sec. 11-5. - Begging. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to beg upon the streets of the town or to remain on the streets of the town for the purpose of begging; provided, that this shall not be construed to apply to the holder of a permit issued as provided in section 13-5 of this Code. 
(Code 1981, § 10-5) 
State Law reference- Solicitation of contributions, Code of Virginia, § 57-48 et seq. 
Sec. 11-6. - Burial; where permitted. 
    No person shall bury or cause to be buried the remains of any person in any place within the corporate limits of the town, except in a duly authorized and legally established cemetery. 
(Code 1981, § 10-6) 
State Law reference- Authority of municipal corporations to regulate burials, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-860. 
Sec. 11-7. - Coin operated devices; unlawful operation. 
    Any person who shall operate, cause to be operated, or attempt to operate or cause to be operated any coin box telephone, parking meter, vending machine or other machine that operates on the coin-in-the-slot principle, whether of like kind or not, designed only to receive lawful coin of the United States of America, in connection with the use or enjoyment of telephone or telegraph service, parking privileges or any other service, or the sale of merchandise or other property, by means of a slug, or any false, counterfeit, mutilated, sweated or foreign coin, or by any means, method, trick or device whatsoever, not authorized by the owner, lessee or licensee of such coin box telephone, parking meter, vending machine or other machine; or who shall obtain or receive telephone or telegraph service, parking privileges, merchandise, or any other service or property for any such coin box telephone, parking meter, vending machine or other machines, designed only to receive lawful coin of the United States of America, without depositing in or surrendering to such coin box telephone, parking meter, vending machine, or other machine lawful coin of the United States of America to the amount required therefor by the owner, lessee or licensee of such coin box telephone, parking meter, vending machine or other machine, shall be guilty of a Class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 10-7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-179. 
Sec. 11-8. - Defacing or removing street signs, fire hydrants or monuments. 
    No person without proper authorization shall deface, remove or displace any street signs, fire hydrants or monuments marking the street lines or town boundaries. 
(Code 1981, § 10-8) 
Charter reference- Town boundaries, § 1-2. 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 7; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 14. 
State Law reference- Injuring, etc., any property, monument, etc., Code of Virginia, § 18.2-137; injuring road markers, etc., Code of Virginia, § 33.1-345. 
Sec. 11-9. - Disorderly conduct in public places. 
(a)  A person is guilty of disorderly conduct if, with the intent to cause public inconvenience, annoyance or alarm, or recklessly creating a risk thereof, he: 
(1)  In any street, highway, public building, or while in or on a public conveyance, or public place engages in conduct having a direct tendency to cause acts of violence by the person or persons at whom, individually, such conduct is directed; provided however, such conduct shall not be deemed to include the utterance or display of any words or to include conduct otherwise made punishable under this Code or state laws; or 
(2)  Willfully, or being intoxicated, whether willfully or not, disrupts any meeting of the council or a division or agency of the town, or of any school, literary society or place of religious worship, if such disruption prevents or interferes with the orderly conduct of such meeting or has a direct tendency to cause acts of violence by the person or persons at whom, individually, such disruption is directed; provided, however, such conduct shall not be deemed to include the utterance or display of any words or to include conduct otherwise punishable under this Code or state laws. 
(b)  The person in charge of any such building, place, conveyance or meeting may eject therefrom any person who violates any provision of this section, with the aid, if necessary, of any persons who may be called upon for such purpose. A person violating any provision of this section shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 10-9) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-415. 
Sec. 11-10. - Possession of open alcoholic beverages container, drinking, or tendering, etc., of alcohol beverages in public place. 
(a)  Possession of open container of alcoholic beverage. It shall be unlawful for any person to possess an open or opened receptacle containing alcoholic beverage in any park, playground or any public street within the town. 
(b)  Drinking or tendering drink of alcoholic beverages. It shall be unlawful for any person to take a drink of alcoholic beverages, or tender a drink to another of alcoholic beverages, whether accepted or not, in any public place within the town. 
(c)  Exceptions. This section shall not prevent any person from possessing an open or opened receptacle containing alcoholic beverages, drinking alcoholic beverages or offering a drink thereof to another: 
(1)  Where such alcoholic beverages were purchased and possessed, drunk, or offered, in the dining room or other designated room, as defined in Code of Virginia, Section 4-25, of a hotel, restaurant, club, boat, dining car, club car, or buffet car of any train, provided such establishment or the person who operates the same, including a concessionaire, is licensed to sell at retail for consumption in such establishment; or 
(2)  Wine, wine coolers, or similar products that qualify as beverages as defined in Section 4-99 [Code of Virginia] and beer only during the performance of a professional sporting exhibition or event in all seating areas, concourses, walkways, concession areas, as well as other additional locations designated by the Virginia Alcoholic Beverage Control Board in coliseums, stadia, or similar facilities, provided such alcoholic beverages and beer is served in a paper, plastic or similar disposal container and where such establishment or the person who operates the same, including a concessionaire, is licensed to sell at retail for consumption such alcoholic beverages in such establishment. 
(3)  In any area approved by the Virginia Alcoholic Beverage Control Board in any local public park at an event for which a banquet license or mixed beverage special events license has been issued. 
(d)  Penalties. Any person violating this section shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 10-10; Ord. No. 1992-1, 3-10-92) 
State Law reference- Drinking alcoholic beverages or tendering to another, in public place, penalty, Code of Virginia, 1950, § 4-78, as amended; local ordinances or resolutions regulating alcoholic beverages, Code of Virginia, 1950, § 4-96, as amended. 
Sec. 11-11. - Drunkenness; profane swearing. 
    If any person profanely curses or swears or is drunk in public he shall be deemed guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. In any area in which there is located a court-approved detoxification center a law-enforcement officer may authorize the transportation, by police or otherwise, of public inebriates to such detoxification center in lieu of arrest; however, no person shall be involuntarily detained in such center. 
(Code 1981, § 10-11) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-388. 
Sec. 11-12. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1995-1, adopted January 10, 1995, repealed § 11-12, which pertained to false alarms and derived from Code 1981, § 10-12. Similar provisions may be found in Article III of this Chapter 11. 
Sec. 11-13. - Gambling. 
    Except as provided in section 18.2-334.2 of the Code of Virginia, any person making, placing or receiving any bet or wager in the form of money or other thing of value, made in exchange for a chance to win a prize, stake or other consideration or thing of value, dependent upon the result of any game, contest or any other event the outcome of which is uncertain or a matter of chance, whether such game, contest or event occurs or is to occur inside or outside the town limits, shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 10-13; Ord. No. 1981-9, 12-1-81) 
State Law reference- Gambling, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-325 et seq.; penalty for illegal gambling, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-326; exceptions to gambling offenses, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-333 et seq. 
Secs. 11-14, 11-15. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1997-02, adopted March 11, 1997, repealed §§ 11-14, 11-15 in their entirety. Formerly, said sections pertained to annual permits and reports for bingo and raffles and derived from Ord. No. 1981-9, adopted December 1, 1981. 
Sec. 11-16. - Indecent exposure. 
    Every person who intentionally makes an obscene display or exposure of his person, or the private parts thereof, in any public place, or in any place where others are present, or procures another to so expose himself, shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 10-14) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-387. 
Sec. 11-17. - Loitering-Definitions. 
(a)  "Loitering" shall mean remaining idle in essentially one (1) location and shall include the concept of spending time idly; to be dilatory; to linger; to stay; to saunter; to delay; to stand around and shall also include the colloquial expression "hanging around". 
(b)  "Public place" shall mean any place to which the general public has access and a right to resort to business, entertainment or other lawful purpose, but does not necessarily mean a place devoted solely to the uses of the public. It shall also include the front or immediate area of any store, shop, restaurant, tavern or other place of business and public grounds, areas or parks. 
(Code 1981, § 10-15) 
Sec. 11-18. - Same-Police order to disperse; penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter, loaf, wander, stand or remain idle either alone and/or in consort with others in a public place in such manner so as to: 
(1)  Obstruct any public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building by hindering or impeding or tending to hinder or impede the free and uninterrupted passage of vehicles, traffic or pedestrians; 
(2)  Commit in or upon any public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building any act or thing which is an obstruction or interference to the free and uninterrupted use of property or with any business lawfully conducted by anyone in or upon or facing or fronting on any such public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building, all of which prevents the free and uninterrupted ingress, egress and regress, therein, thereon and thereto. 
(b)  When any such person causes or commits any of the conditions enumerated in subsection (a) of this section, a police officer or any law enforcement officer shall order that person to stop causing or committing such conditions and to move on or disperse. Any person who fails or refuses to obey such orders shall be guilty of a violation of this section. 
(c)  Any person who violates any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 10-15.1) 
Sec. 11-19. - Noise. 
(a)  The creation and continuation of any loud, disturbing and unnecessary noises in the town is hereby prohibited. No person shall cause, make or contribute to create any loud or disturbing noise of such character, intensity or duration as to be detrimental to the life or health of any individual, or such noises as disturb the quiet and peace of any citizen of the town. 
(b)  Any person who violates any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a Class 4 misdemeanor. 
(c)  The following acts, among others, are declared to be loud, disturbing, annoying and unnecessary noises in violation of this section, but such enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive: 
(1)  Blasting horns. The creation by means of any signal device of any loud or harsh noise, and the sounding of such device for any unnecessary or unreasonable period of time; 
(2)  Radios, phonographs, etc. The playing of any television set, radio, phonograph, musical instrument or any music box, juke box or similar device in such manner or with such volume as to annoy or disturb any person, or the playing of such instrument in such manner as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of any person in any dwelling, hotel or other residence; 
(3)  Pets. The keeping of any animal or bird which, by causing frequent or long continued noise, shall disturb the comfort or repose of any persons in the vicinity; 
(4)  Vehicles. The use of any automobile, motorcycle or vehicle so out of repair, so loaded or used or repaired in such manner as to create loud or unnecessary noises, particularly grating, grinding, rattling, riveting or other disturbing noises; 
(5)  Whistles. The blowing of any whistle attached to any stationary boiler, except to give notice of the time to begin or stop work or as a warning of danger; 
(6)  Exhaust discharge. The discharge into the open air of the exhaust from any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine or motorboat engine except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises therefrom; 
(7)  Devices using compressed air. The use of any mechanical device operated by compressed air, unless the noise created thereby is effectively muffled and reduced; 
(8)  Building operations. The erection, including excavation, demolition, alteration or repair, of any building in a residential or business district other than between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. on weekdays, except in cases of urgent necessity in the interest of public safety, and then only with a permit from the proper town officials; 
(9)  Noises near schools, hospitals, churches, etc. The creation of any excessive noise on any street adjacent to any school, institution of learning, library, sanitarium, hospital or court, while the same is in session, or adjacent to any church during the church services, which interferes with the work or worship in any such place or institution; provided, that signs must be displayed in such streets indicating that the same is a school, hospital, church, library, sanitarium or court; 
(10)  Loading and unloading operations. The creation of loud and excessive noises in connection with loading or unloading any vehicle or repairing any vehicle or opening and destroying bales, boxes, crates and containers; 
(11)  Bells or gongs. The sounding of any bell or gong attached to any building or premises which disturbs the quiet or repose of any person in the vicinity thereof; 
(12)  Hawking, peddling or soliciting. Shouting, loud talking, crying or soliciting by peddlers, hawkers, taxicab drivers, solicitors and vendors, which disturbs the quiet and peace of the neighborhood or any person therein; 
(13)  Noise to attract attention. The use of any drum, loudspeaker or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention to any performance or event, show, sale or the display or advertisement of merchandise by the creation of noise; 
(14)  Loudspeakers or amplifiers. The use of any mechanical loudspeaker or amplifier, except by special permission of the town manager when the public will not be unreasonably disturbed thereby; 
(15)  Business noises at night near residences. The operation of any garage, filling station, auto repair business, taxi business, plant, store, factory or other place of business, between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., in such manner as to create loud and disturbing noises of such frequency or such volume as to annoy or disturb the quiet and comfort of any citizen, and particularly the creating of disturbing noises of such frequency and volume as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of any person in any dwelling, hotel, boardinghouse or other type of residence. 
(Code 1981, § 10-16; Ord. No. 1992-25, 10-13-92) 
Cross reference- Animals and fowl, Ch. 3; buildings, Ch. 4; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 10; solicitors, Ch. 13; taxicabs, Ch. 16. 
State Law reference- Power of town to regulate noise from motorcycle mufflers, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-29.12; power of town to regulate or prohibit the use of explosive devices to repel birds, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-29-13; loudspeakers prohibited near polling places, Code of Virginia, § 24.1-96.1. 
Sec. 11-20. - Nuisances, etc.; abatement, etc. 
(a)  Whenever it shall come to the attention of the town manager that a nuisance is being created or maintained within the town or that an unsanitary, unsafe or unhealthful condition exists in the town or that the nuisance or condition in question has been existing for some period of time, the town manager shall cause an immediate inspection of the premises in question to be made and, if a nuisance or unsanitary, unsafe or unhealthful condition is found, he shall cause to be served upon the occupant of the premises or if the premises be not occupied, then upon the owner thereof or his agent, a notice to abate such nuisance or to correct such unsanitary, unsafe or unhealthful condition within a specified time. If such notice is not complied with in the specified time, the recipient thereof shall be summoned to appear before the general district court and show cause why such notice should not be complied with. In the case of a known nonresident, having no agent in the town, such notice shall be mailed to the last known address of the owner or his agent, and fifteen (15) days allowed for a reply. 
(b)  If the nuisance or condition complained of as provided in the first paragraph of this section is such that immediate action is necessary for the protection of the public health and welfare, the town manager shall cause the same to be abated or corrected at once, without notice, and all costs incident thereto shall be assessed against the owner of the premises and collected in the same manner in which taxes or other assessments are collectible by law. 
(Code 1981, § 10-17) 
State Law reference- Power of town to prevent injury or annoyance from anything dangerous, offensive or unhealthy and to cause any nuisance to be abated, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-14(5); nuisances generally, Code of Virginia, Title 48. 
Sec. 11-21. - Odors and fumes; collection and discharge into street, etc., by mechanical means. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make use of mechanical apparatus for the purpose of collecting kitchen and cooking odors, fumes or other offensive odors and to discharge such fumes or odors from the building in question into the streets of the town or upon the property of such person in such manner as to be offensive to the citizens of the town. 
(Code 1981, § 10-18) 
State Law reference- Power of town to prevent injury or annoyance from anything dangerous, offensive or unhealthy and to cause any nuisance to be abated, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-14(5). 
Sec. 11-22. - Poolrooms and bowling alleys; when closing required. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner, operator or manager of any poolroom, billiard, bowling alley or tenpin alley to keep open, or to allow, cause or permit to be kept open, the establishment for which he is responsible, between 2:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m., except on Sundays, when such establishment shall remain closed until 12:00 noon. 
(Code 1981, § 10-19) 
Sec. 11-23. - Public property-Damaging, destroying, etc. 
    Any person who shall willfully damage or destroy any real or personal property owned, leased or used by the town shall be guilty of a Class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 10-21) 
State Law reference- Injuries to public buildings, etc., Code of Virginia, § 18.2-138. 
Sec. 11-24. - Same-Unlawful use. 
    The town manager shall have the power to promulgate such reasonable rules and regulations, not in conflict with the provisions of this Code, or other ordinances of the town, or the Commonwealth of Virginia for the use of any of the parks, or any other public places or public property or any public easement of any description owned or occupied by the town as shall be necessary for the safe and proper use of the public property, including but not limited to, establishing the hours during which any park or property operated by the town shall be open to the public. Such rules and regulations shall be subject to the approval of the town council. The rules and regulations, including such hours during which the park or property is open to the public, shall be posted prominently at the entrance to the park or public property. 
(a)  Other than employees or agents of the town engaged in the conduct of official business, participants or spectators in any town-sponsored activity or event, or person with a valid permit to conduct an event or activity beyond the posted hours, it shall be unlawful for any person to be present within the park or property at such times not within the posted hours during which the park or public property is open to the public, the violation of which shall constitute trespass, a Class 1 misdemeanor. 
(b)  Other than what is set out herein, it shall be unlawful for any person to fail, neglect or refuse to comply with any other of such rules and regulations so established, promulgated, approved and posted, the violation of which shall constitute a Class 4 misdemeanor. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to undertake to occupy or use any of the streets, avenues, parks, bridges or any other public places or public property or any public easement of any description of the town, in a manner not permitted to the general public, without having first legally obtained the consent thereto of the council, the violation of which shall constitute a Class 4 misdemeanor. Such occupancy shall be deemed a nuisance and the court trying the case shall have the power to cause the nuisance to be abated and to commit the offenders engaged in such offenses to jail until such order of the court shall be obeyed. 
(Code 1981, § 10-22; Ord. No. 1990-9, 11-13-90) 
State Law reference- Persons occupying or using streets, etc., contrary to law, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-316. 
Sec. 11-25. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1997-02, adopted March 11, 1997, repealed § 11-25 in its entirety. Formerly, § 11-25 pertained to railroad cars obstructing streets or roads and vehicles standing on railroad tracks, and derived from § 10-23 of the 1981 Code. 
Sec. 11-26. - Resisting or obstructing officers, employees, etc. 
    No person shall resist, abuse, obstruct or hinder any officer or employee of the town in the discharge of his duty, or any contractor or other person in the execution of any work for the town. 
(Code 1981, § 10-24) 
State Law reference- Obstructing justice by threats or force, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-460. 
Sec. 11-27. - Telephones, etc.-Use of profane, threatening or indecent language. 
    If any person shall use obscene, vulgar, profane, lewd, lascivious, or indecent language, or make any suggestion or proposal of an obscene nature, or threaten any illegal or immoral act with the intent to coerce, intimidate, or harass any person, over any telephone or citizens band radio in the town, he shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 10-25) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-427 
Sec. 11-28. - Same-Giving certain false information to another. 
    If any person maliciously advises or informs another over any telephone in the town of the death of, accident to, injury to, illness of, or disappearance of some third party, knowing the same to be false, he shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 10-26) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-428. 
Sec. 11-29. - Same-Causing to ring with intent to annoy. 
    Any person who, without intent to converse but with intent to annoy any other person, causes any telephone not his own to ring, and any person who permits or condones the use of any telephone under this control for such purpose shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 10-27) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-429. 
Sec. 11-30. - Same-Venue. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of sections 11-27-11-29 may be prosecuted in this county when he called from this county or when the call was received in this county. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-430. 
Sec. 11-31. - Trespass-After having been forbidden to do so; penalties. 
(a)  If any person shall, without authority of law, go upon or remain upon the lands, buildings or premises of another, or any part, portion or area thereof, after having been forbidden to do so, either orally or in writing, by the owner, lessee, custodian or other person lawfully in charge thereof, or after having been forbidden to do so by a sign or signs posted on such lands, buildings, premises or part, portion or area thereof, at a place of places where it or they may be reasonably seen, or if any person, whether he is the owner, tenant or otherwise entitled to the use of such land, building or premises, goes upon, or remains upon such land, building or premises after having been prohibited from doing so by a court of competent jurisdiction by an order issued pursuant to Code of Virginia sections 16.1-253, 16.1-253.1, 16.1-278.2 through 16.1-278.6, 16.1-278.8, 16.1-278.14, 16.1-278.15, 16.1-279.1, 19.2-152.8, 19.2-152.9, 19.2-152.10 or an ex parts order issued pursuant to Code of Virginia section 20-103, and after having been served with such order, he shall be guilty of a class I misdemeanor. This section shall not be construed to affect in any way the provisions of Code of Virginia sections 18.2-132 through 18.2-136. 
(b)  Any owner of real property may, in writing on a form prescribed by the chief of police, designate the police department as a "person lawfully in charge thereof," as those terms are used in subsection (a) of this section, for the purpose of forbidding another to go or remain upon the lands, buildings or premises of such owner. Such designation shall include a description of the land(s), building(s) or premises to which it applies; shall reference the period of time during which it is in effect; and shall be kept on file in the office of the chief of police or in such other location within the police department as the chief of police deems appropriate. 
(Code 1981, § 10-28; Ord. No. 2002-01, 1-8-2002) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-119. 
Sec. 11-32. - Same-Instigating, etc., by others; preventing service to persons not forbidden to trespass. 
    If any person shall solicit, urge, encourage, exhort, instigate or procure another or others to go upon or remain upon the lands, buildings, or premises of another, or any part, portion or area thereof, knowing such other person or persons to have been forbidden, either orally or in writing, to do so by the owner, lessee, custodian or other person lawfully in charge thereof, or knowing such other person or persons to have been forbidden to do so by a sign or signs posted on such lands, buildings, premises or part, portion or area thereof at a place or places where it or they may reasonably be seen; or if any person shall, on such lands, buildings, premises or part, portion or area thereof prevent or seek to prevent the owner, lessee, custodian, person in charge or any of his employees from rendering service to any person or persons not so forbidden, he shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 10-29) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-120. 
Sec. 11-33. - Same-At night upon church or school property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, without the consent of some person authorized to give such consent, to go or enter upon, in the nighttime, the premises or property of any church or upon any school property for any purpose other than to attend a meeting or service held or conducted in such church or school property. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 10-33) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-128. 
Sec. 11-34. - Same-Entering property of another for purpose of damaging it, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to enter the land, dwelling, outhouse or any other building of another for the purpose of damaging such property or any of the contents thereof or in any manner to interfere with the rights of the owner, user or the occupant thereof to use such property free from interference. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 10-31) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-121. 
Sec. 11-35. - Same-Peeping or spying into structure occupied as dwelling. 
    If any person shall enter upon the property of another, in the nighttime, and secretly or furtively peep through or attempt to so peep into or through, or spy through, a window, door or other aperture of any building, structure, or other enclosure of any nature occupied or intended for occupancy as a dwelling, whether or not such building, structure or enclosure be permanently situated or transportable and whether or not such occupancy be permanent or temporary, such person shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 10-32) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-130. 
Secs. 11-36-11-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WEAPONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of municipal corporations to regulate or prohibit the discharge of firearms, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-865; crimes relating to weapons, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-279 et seq.; control of firearms generally, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-29.15. 

Sec. 11-51. - Discharging air rifles, gravel shooters, bows, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge shots, bullets or similar pellets from any air gun, air rifle or pellet gun or to discharge shot, gravel or similar substance from a gravel shooter, slingshot or similar implement or to discharge arrows, bolts, nails or bullets from a bow or crossbow within one hundred (100) yards of any residence or public street. Each act done in violation of this section shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1981, § 10-34) 
Sec. 11-52. - Discharging firearms.
