    If any person willfully discharges or causes to be discharged any firearm in any street in the town, or in any place of public business or place of public gathering, he shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor; provided that this section shall not apply to any law enforcement officer in the performance of his official duties nor to any other person whose willful act is otherwise justifiable or excusable at law in the protection of his life or property, or is otherwise specifically authorized by law. 
(Code 1981, § 10-35) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-280. 
Secs. 11-53, 11-54. - Reserved. 
Sec. 11-55. - Sale, possession of blackjacks, etc. 
    If any person sells or barters, or exhibits for sale or for barter, or gives or furnishes, or causes to be sold, bartered, given or furnished, or has in his possession, or under his control, with the intent of selling, bartering, giving or furnishing, any blackjack, brass or metal knucks, any disc of whatever configuration having at least two (2) points or pointed blades which is designed to be thrown or propelled and which may be known as a throwing star or oriental dart, switchblade knife or like weapons, such person shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. The having in one's possession of any such weapon shall be prima facie evidence, except in the case of a conservator of the peace, of his intent to sell, barter, give or furnish the same. 
(Code 1981, § 10-38) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-311. 
Sec. 11-56. - Furnishing certain weapons to minors. 
    If any person sell, barter, give or furnish, or cause to be sold, bartered, given or furnished to any minor a pistol, dirk, switchblade knife or bowie knife, having good cause to believe him to be a minor, such person shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 1039) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-309. 
Sec. 11-57. - Selling or giving toy firearms. 
(a)  No person shall sell, barter, exchange, furnish, or dispose of by purchase, gift or in any other manner any toy gun, pistol, rifle or other toy firearm, if the same shall, by means of powder or other explosive, discharge blank or ball charges. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. Each sale of any of the articles hereinbefore specified to any person shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Nothing contained in this section shall be construed as preventing the sale of what are commonly known as cap pistols. 
(Code 1981, § 10-40) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-284. 
ARTICLE III. - ALARM SYSTEMS 
DIVISION 1. - DEFINITIONS 

Sec. 11-58. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings given: 
    Alarm company means any corporation, partnership, business or individual engaged in the for-profit business of the installing, maintenance, alteration, or servicing of alarm systems or which responds to such alarm systems. Such term, however, shall not include alarm systems maintained by governmental agencies or departments, nor shall it include a business which merely sells from a fixed location or manufactures alarm systems unless such business services, installs, monitors or responds to alarm systems at the protected premises. 
    Alarm response means any response to a premise by any law enforcement agency, including but not limited to the Town of Warrenton Police Department, or any fire or rescue company as a result of an alarm signal. Should the law enforcement agency or fire or rescue company discover evidence that the alarm signal was the result of a criminal offense or occurrence for which the alarm system was designed to detect, that event shall not be considered an alarm response for the purposes of this chapter. 
    Alarm signal means the activation of an alarm system resulting in a request for an alarm response regardless of cause. 
    Alarm system means any assembly of equipment and devices arranged to signal the presence of a hazard requiring urgent attention and to which law enforcement or fire or rescue personnel are expected to respond. 
    Alarm user means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind who or which purchases, leases, contracts for, or otherwise obtains an alarm system, or the servicing, maintenance or monitoring of an alarm system from an alarm company. 
    Automatic dialing device means a device which is interconnected to a telephone line and is programmed to a predetermined telephone number and which automatically transmits by recorded voice message or signal the existence of a hazard requiring urgent attention and to which law enforcement personnel or fire or rescue personnel are expected to respond. 
    Communications coordinator shall mean the communications coordinator for the Warrenton-Fauquier Joint Dispatch Center. 
    Town manager shall mean the town manager of the Town of Warrenton or his designee. 
    Person shall mean any individual, group of persons, firm, partnership, association of any kind, company or corporation. 
    Police department means the Town of Warrenton Police Department. 
    Protected premise shall mean the premises upon which an alarm has been placed for the purpose of detecting a hazard. 
    Fire or rescue company means any fire or rescue company duly recognized in accordance with the terms of the Code for the Town of Warrenton. 
(Ord. No. 1995-1, 1-10-95) 
DIVISION 2. - FIRE AND SECURITY ALARM SYSTEMS 

Sec. 11-59. - Intentional false alarms prohibited. 
    Any person who knowingly and willfully activates either a security alarm to summon law enforcement, fire or rescue personnel, or an automatic dialing device which transmits a prerecorded message or code signal directly to a "911" telephone number, where there is no actual or threatened emergency or criminal activity, shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this section, which violation shall be punishable by confinement in jail for not more than twelve (12) months and a fine of not more than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00), either or both. 
(Ord. No. 1995-4, 4-11-95) 
Sec. 11-60. - Automatic dialing device restrictions. 
    Any alarm company or person who installs, operates or maintains an automatic dialing device which is programmed to transmit a prerecorded message or code signal directly to a "911" telephone number shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this section, which violation shall be punishable by a fine of not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(Ord. No. 1995-4, 4-11-95) 
Sec. 11-61. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1995-4, adopted April 11, 1995, repealed § 11-61, which pertained to automatic dialing service restrictions and derived from Ord. No. 1995-1, adopted January 10, 1995. 
Sec. 11-62. - Required equipment. 
(a)  An alarm system operated within the town shall be equipped in such a manner so as to prevent false alarms due to interruptions in electrical power. 
(b)  An alarm system within the town which is equipped with a horn, bell, siren, or other noise device audible beyond the confines of the premise shall be equipped and adjusted in such a manner that it will not sound for longer than fifteen (15) minutes before resetting and silencing itself. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to an alarm system installed prior to January 1, 1995; provided, however, that upon a violation of section 3-6, the alarm system must be brought into compliance with this section. 
(Ord. No. 1995-4, 4-11-95) 
Sec. 11-63. - Notification of alarm system installation; emergency information. 
(a)  Within thirty (30) days of installing an alarm system, the alarm user shall, on a form provided by the communications coordinator, furnish the communications coordinator with emergency information concerning the protected premise, the alarm user, and the alarm company. 
(b)  If, at any time, there is a change in the status of the protected premise which renders any part of the emergency information form inaccurate, the alarm user shall file an amended emergency information form within thirty (30) days of the change. 
(c)  Alarm users with alarm systems installed prior to January 1, 1995 shall comply with this section prior to April 2, 1995. 
(d)  Any alarm response which results from an alarm signal initiated by an alarm system which is not in compliance with this section shall be deemed to be an excessive alarm response and a violation of section 11-64 of this chapter. 
(e)  Prior to January 1, 1995 the communications coordinator shall make necessary forms for the reporting of emergency information available to alarm companies and the general public. 
(Ord. No. 1995-4, 4-11-95) 
Sec. 11-64. - Excessive alarm responses prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any alarm user in the town to allow an excessive number of false or without just cause alarm responses to occur at a protected premise for which they are responsible. 
(b)  False or without just cause alarm responses to a protected premise in excess of five (5) in any consecutive twelve-month period or three (3) in any consecutive four-month period are deemed to be an excessive number and shall be a violation of this chapter. 
(c)  Town of Warrenton Police Officers assigned to incidents which are determined to be false or without just cause alarm responses shall, whenever possible, leave written notice for the alarm user which provides the following information: 
Date and time of false or without just cause alarm response. 
Officer's name and business telephone number. 
Brief synopsis of the alarm ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 1995-4, 4-11-95) 
Sec. 11-65. - Inspection of alarm systems. 
    An alarm user in violation of section 11-64 shall cause their alarm system to be inspected by an alarm company licensed to conduct business in the Town of Warrenton. The inspection shall entail a complete examination of the alarm system including, but not limited to, satisfactory design and installation of the equipment, proper functioning of the equipment and user education in the operation of the equipment. The alarm company shall record the details of the inspection on a form provided by the communications coordinator for this purpose. Notification of the requirements of this section shall be made in writing, within thirty (30) days of the initial notification by the communications coordinator. The completed inspection report shall be returned to the town police by the alarm company within thirty (30) days of the initial notification by the town police. A copy of the completed inspection report shall be provided to the alarm user and communications coordinator by the alarm company upon completion of the inspection. 
(Ord. No. 1995-4, 4-11-95) 
Sec. 11-66. - Penalties for noncompliance with inspection. 
    If the communications coordinator does not receive the completed inspection report within thirty (30) days of notification as provided in section 11-68, an administrative service fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be assessed against the alarm user. 
(Ord. No. 1995-4, 4-11-95) 
Sec. 11-67. - Penalties for subsequent violations. 
(a)  If within any one calendar year of the notification, as provided in section 11-65, there is cause for more than two (2) alarm responses to a protected premise, administrative service fees, in accordance with the following fee schedule (section 11-67[b]), shall be assessed against the user for all subsequent alarm responses. 
(b)  Administrative Service Fee Schedule: 
(1)  Third response ..... $ 20.00 
(2)  Fourth response ..... 50.00 
(3)  Fifth response ..... 75.00 
(4)  Sixth response ..... 100.00 
(5)  Seventh response ..... 125.00 
(6)  Responses in excess of seven, each ..... 150.00 
(c)  If no responses to a protected premise are recorded within any twelve (12) month period following notification, action will be initiated to remove the alarm user from the violator file, provided all outstanding administrative fees have been paid. 
(d)  To ensure that the assessed amounts are representative of the costs incurred by the town to provide alarm responses and to administer this chapter, the amounts contained in the administrative service fee schedule shall be evaluated and amended, as necessary, on an annual basis. 
(Ord. No. 1995-4, 4-11-95) 
DIVISION 3. - ADMINISTRATIVE APPEAL HEARING 

Sec. 11-68. - Administrative appeal hearing. 
(a)  In the event an inspection order is issued to an alarm user or service fees are assessed, the alarm user may request an appeal hearing to determine whether there is just cause for such action. 
(b)  The hearing shall be held before a hearing officer who shall have been appointed by the town manager. The hearing shall be held within seventy-two (72) hours after the request is filed with the town police office unless an extension has been agreed upon by both the alarm user and the town police office. 
(c)  The alarm user shall have the right to appear and present witnesses and other evidence, but there shall be no formal rules of procedure required for the conduct of the hearing and the hearing officer shall not have the power to compel the attendance of witnesses or the production of other evidence. 
(d)  The hearing officer shall proceed forthwith to hear the matter and to determine by a preponderance of the evidence whether there is probable cause to believe that the provisions of this division have been applied legally, fairly and impartially. The hearing officer shall have authority, if he/she determines that there is insufficient evidence to fully support imposition of an inspection requirement or administrative service fees, to order that any inspection requirements or fees imposed under this division be waived or rescinded in whole or in part. 
(Ord. No. 1995-4, 4-11-95) 
Sec. 11-69. - Grounds for rescinding, waiving or reducing service fees. 
(a)  Administrative hearing officers shall consider the following factors in reaching a determination as to the modification of a service fee or waiving an inspection order. 
(1)  Evidence of attempts by the alarm user to eliminate the cause of false alarms, such as: 
Installation of new equipment. 
Replacement of defective equipment. 
Inspection and repair of the system by an alarm technician. 
Specific formal training of alarm users. 
(b)  Evidence that the false alarm was caused by electrical storm, hurricane, tornado, blizzard, or other acts of God. 
(c)  Evidence that the false alarm was caused by the disruption of telephone circuits beyond the control of the user or the user's alarm company and the cause of such disruption has been corrected. 
(d)  Written evidence that the alarm system which caused the alarm responses has been disconnected and/or removed from the protected premises. 
    Nothing in this section shall be interpreted to require that all appeals which meet any or all of these circumstances will be granted. These are intended as guidelines for the hearing officer and shall not prevent the hearing officer from granting appeals for additional reasons. 
(Ord. No. 1995-4, 4-11-95) 
DIVISION 4. - FIRE AND SECURITY ALARM SYSTEMS COMMISSION 

Sec. 11-70. - Fire and security alarm systems commission. 
(a)  A fire and security alarm systems commission shall be appointed by the town council, as an advisory commission, under authority of Section 15.1-33.2 of the Code of Virginia and shall consist of the following membership of the Joint Communications Center Board of Directors: 
-The chief of police of the Town of Warrenton. 
-The sheriff of Fauquier County. 
-Fire and Rescue Association President. 
-One (1) member of the technical advisory committee. 
(b)  The fire and security alarm systems commission shall periodically review the implementation and effectiveness of the alarm ordinance and make recommendations, as appropriate, to the town council. 
(c)  The fire and security alarm systems commission shall periodically review the decisions of administrative hearing officers for the purpose of monitoring effectiveness of the administrative hearing process. 
(d)  The fire and security alarm systems commission shall develop recommendations for the town council concerning the need for additional local regulation of alarm company operators, as permitted by the Code of Virginia, Section 15.1-28.2, and/or the adoption of statewide standards by the department of housing and community development or other regulatory authority. 
(Ord. No. 1995-4, 4-11-95) 
ARTICLE IV. - OUTDOOR STORAGE IN RESIDENTIAL ZONES 

Sec. 11-71. - Outdoor storage in residential zones. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of residential outdoor storage regulations is to ensure that adequate opportunity is allowed for the outdoor storage of vehicles and materials in residential zones (R-6, R-10, R-15 and RT Districts) while promoting safe and attractive residential areas and not impacting the character and uses intended for residential zones in Warrenton. The regulation of outdoor storage in residential areas is intended to insure a safe and healthy area free from hazards and the accumulation of materials that could harbor vermin or their breeding. 
(b)  Prohibited. No outdoor storage, as defined in subsection A of this section, shall be allowed on any parcel within a residential zone, except as otherwise authorized by this section. 
A.  Outdoor storage defined. For the purposes of this section, "outdoor storage" means the physical presence of any personal property not fully enclosed within a structure for more than one (1) week. "Outdoor storage" means and includes, but shall not be limited to, the following: 
1.  Inoperable and/or unlicensed motor vehicles as more fully defined in section 1-84 of the Warrenton Town Code, and farm, commercial and industrial equipment of all types; 
2.  Inoperable or unlicensed recreation vehicles; 
3.  Junk, imported waste and discarded or salvaged materials; 
4.  Dismantled vehicles and vehicle parts, including but not limited to commercial and industrial farm machinery or parts thereof, such as tires and batteries; 
5.  Scrap metal, including but not limited to salvaged structural steel; 
6.  Salvaged lumber and building materials; 
7.  Salvaged commercial or industrial trade fixtures; 
8.  Construction materials and supplies or any project for which no building permit has been issued or is currently in effect; 
9.  Household furniture or appliances sold and distributed for indoor use; 
10.  Accumulations of bottles, cans and paper and other refuse; 
11.  Boxes, cable spools, pallets and packing crates; and 
12.  All other miscellaneous personal property not excluded by subsection C of this section. 
B.  Exclusions. Outdoor storage as defined in subsection (b)A of this section shall not include the following: 
1.  The parking of operable and licensed motor vehicles, including passenger vehicles, commercial vehicles and recreational vehicles; 
2.  The storage of residential building materials and supplies which are needed to construct a project on the parcel for which a building permit has been issued and is in effect; and/or 
3.  The storage of materials or objects that are clearly incidental and customary to the residential functions or a residential property, including but not limited to the storage of firewood, barbeque grills, and outdoor furniture that is manufactured and sold for outdoor use. 
C.  Regulations regarding outdoor storage. 
1.  The maximum area on any parcel in residential zones shall not exceed two hundred (200) square feet in area or five (5) percent of the lot area, whichever is less. 
2.  Such storage areas shall not be located in the front of the house (between the structure and the street) or in the required side or rear yard setback. 
3.  Outdoor storage areas shall not prevent emergency access to the residence or any outbuilding. 
D.  Violations, notice and penalty. Written notice shall first be sent to the person owning the property upon which a violation of this section has occurred. The owner of the property shall then either comply with the written notice within ten (10) days or respond denying the violation. Once notice has been sent via United States Mail First Class to the address for the property upon which there is a violation, and the violation has not been rectified or a response denying the violation has been returned the matter may then be taken to the Fauquier County District Court as a Class 4 misdemeanor as the penalty for said violation. Each day said violation occurs shall constitute a new violation. 
(Ord. No. 2006-07, 7-11-2006) 
ARTICLE V. - DEFACEMENT OF PROPERTY; GRAFFITI 

Sec. 11-72. - Defacement of property prohibited; criminal penalty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to apply graffiti upon or to willfully and maliciously deface or damage in any other manner any public buildings, facilities or other property, or any private buildings, facilities or other property. In any case where the defacement is (i) more than twenty (20) feet off the ground, (ii) on a highway overpass, or (iii) committed for the benefit of, at the direction of, or in association with any criminal street gang, as that term is defined by Code of Virginia, § 18.2-46.1, there shall be a mandatory minimum fine of $500.00. Any fine imposed pursuant to conviction of a minor for violations of this section shall be assessed against the minor and such minor's parents or legal guardian. 
(b)  Upon a finding of guilt in a case tried before the court without a jury where the violation constitutes a first offense that results in property damage or loss, the court, without entering a judgment of guilt, upon motion of defendant, may defer further proceedings and place defendant on probation pending completion of a plan of community service work. If the defendant fails or refuses to complete the community service as ordered by the court, the court may make final disposition of the case and proceed as otherwise provided. If the community service work is completed as the court prescribes, the court may discharge the defendant and dismiss the proceedings. Such discharge and dismissal procedure under this section shall be without adjudication of guilt and operates as a conviction only for the purposes of applying this article in subsequent proceedings. 
(c)  Community service work prescribed by the court under subsection (b) shall include, to the extent feasible, the repair, restoration, or replacement of any damage or defacement to property within the town, and may include clean-up, beautification, landscaping or other appropriate community service within the town. 
(d)  Community service work prescribed by the court under subsection (b) shall be performed under the supervision of the town manager or his/her designee, who shall report on such work to the court imposing the community service work requirement at such times and in such manner as the court may direct. 
(e)  At or before the time of sentencing under this section, the court shall receive and consider any plan for making restitution or performing community service submitted by the defendant, as well as the recommendations of the town manager or the manager's designee concerning the plan. 
(f)  As provided in Code of Virginia, § 15.2-908, the court may order any person convicted of unlawfully defacing property to pay full or partial restitution to the town for costs incurred by the town in removing or repairing the defacement. No person convicted of a violation of this article shall be placed on probation or have his/her sentence suspended unless such person shall make at least partial restitution for such property damage or is compelled to perform community services, or both, as is more particularly set forth in Code of Virginia, § 19.2-305.1. The court's order of restitution shall be docketed as provided in Code of Virginia, § 8.01-446 when so ordered by the court upon written request of the town and may be enforced by the town in the same manner as a judgment in a civil action. 
(g)  Upon a final conviction of any charge under this article V herein the penalty shall be a Class 3 misdemeanor for the first conviction, and a Class 1 misdemeanor for any second or subsequent final conviction. 
(Ord. No. 2017-06 , 5-9-17) 
Sec. 11-73. - Parental liability for cost of repair of damage to public or private property. 
(a)  In accordance with Code of Virginia, § 8.01-44, the town may institute an action and recover from the parents or either of them of any minor living with such parents or either of them for damages suffered by reason of the willful or malicious destruction of, or damage to, public property by such minor. No more than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) may be recovered from such parents or either of them as a result of any incident or occurrence on which such action is based. 
(b)  The owner of any property in the town may institute an action and recover from the parents, or either of them, of any minor living with such parents, or either of them, for damages suffered by reason of the willful or malicious destruction of, or damage to, such property by such minor. No more than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) may be recovered from such parents, or either of them, as a result of any incident or occurrence on which such action is based. Any recovery from the parent or parents of such minor shall not preclude full recovery from such minor except to the amount of the recovery from such parent or parents. The provisions of this section shall be in addition to, and not in lieu of, any other law imposing upon a parent liability for the acts of his minor child. 
(Ord. No. 2017-06 , 5-9-17) 
Sec. 11-74. - Definition of "graffiti." 
    Graffiti shall mean the unauthorized application by any means of any writing, painting, drawing, etching, scratching or marking of an inscription, word, mark, figure or design of any type on any public or private building or other real or personal property owned, operated or maintained by a governmental entity or agency or instrumentality thereof or by any private person. 
(Ord. No. 2017-06 , 5-9-17) 
Sec. 11-75. - Graffiti declared a public nuisance. 
    The existence of graffiti within the town limits in violation of this article is expressly declared a public nuisance, and is subject to the removal and abatement procedures specified in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2017-06 , 5-9-17) 
Sec. 11-76. - Removal of graffiti. 
(a)  The town manager or his/her designated representative is authorized to undertake or contract for the removal or repair of the defacement of any public building, wall, fence or other structure, by the application of graffiti. Further the town manager or his/her designated representative may also undertake or contract for the removal or repair of the defacement by graffiti of any private building, wall, fence or other structure where such defacement is visible from any public right-of-way, but only in accordance with the following procedures: 
(1)  Prior to such removal of graffiti from private property, the town manager or his/her designated representative shall send to the property owner, by regular mail sent to the last address listed for the owner in town property assessment records, a notice stating: the street address and legal description of the property; that the property has been determined by the town to constitute a graffiti public nuisance; that the owner must take corrective action to abate the public nuisance created by such graffiti within fifteen (15) days of the date of the notice; and that if the graffiti is not removed within the fifteen-day period, the town will begin removal procedures. In the case of unimproved property, the notice shall also state that the cost of such corrective action shall be charged to the property owner. The notice shall further advise the owner of the right to challenge the town's determination and proposed action by requesting a meeting with a town official identified in the notice within fifteen (15) days of the date of the notice. The town shall initiate no corrective actions while a request for such a meeting or the outcome of such a meeting is pending. The determination of the designated town official following the requested meeting shall be final. 
(2)  If no corrective action is taken by the property owner within the fifteen-day period provided above and there is no request to challenge the town's determination within that period, the town manager or his/her designee shall send to the property owner by regular mail an additional notice that shall conform to the requirements of the first notice as set forth in subsection (a)(1) above and shall also state the date on which the town will commence corrective action to remove the graffiti on the property, which date shall be no earlier than fifteen (15) days from the date of mailing the second notice. Such additional notice shall also reasonably describe the corrective action contemplated to be taken by the town. Where the property owner fails to abate the public nuisance within fifteen (15) days after issuance of the second notice, the town manager or his/her designated representative is authorized to proceed with removal efforts forthwith. 
(3)  Before entering upon private property for the purpose of graffiti removal, the town shall attempt to obtain the consent of the property owner, occupant or other responsible party. 
(b)  Where a structure defaced by graffiti is owned by a public entity other than the town, the removal of the graffiti by the town is conditioned upon securing the consent of an authorized representative of the public entity having jurisdiction over the structure. 
(c)  If the town manager or his/her designee determines that any graffiti is an immediate danger to public health, safety or welfare and is unable to provide notice by personal service after at least two (2) attempts to do so, then forty-eight (48) hours after the later of (1) mailing notice to the property owner or other responsible party and (2) posting notice in a conspicuous place on the property, the town may remove or cause the graffiti to be removed. 
(Ord. No. 2017-06 , 5-9-17) 
Sec. 11-77. - Assessment of costs against property for removal of graffiti. 
(a)  If the town undertakes corrective action to remove graffiti from private property after complying with the notice provisions of subsection 11-76(a)(1), the actual cost or expenses for such removal and related repairs shall be chargeable to and paid by the property owner, and may be collected as a special assessment against the respective lot or parcel of land to which it relates in the manner in which town taxes and levies are collected. 
(b)  Every charge authorized by this section with which the owner of any such property has been assessed and which remains unpaid shall constitute a lien against such property with the same priority as liens for unpaid local taxes and enforceable in the same manner as such liens. The town manager may waive and release such liens in order to facilitate the sale of the property. Such liens may be waived only as to a purchaser who is unrelated by blood or marriage to the owner and who has no business association with the owner. All such liens shall remain a personal obligation of the owner of the property at the time the liens were imposed. 
(Ord. No. 2017-06 , 5-9-17) 
Chapter 12 - POLICE DEPARTMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 10; duty of police to keep sidewalks clear, § 14-2; taxicabs containing radios receiving police calls, § 16-17. 
State Law reference- Police and public order, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-131 et seq.; Line of Duty Act, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-136.1 et seq.; general municipal law enforcement powers, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-137 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Composition. 
    The police department of the town shall consist of a chief of police and such other officers and patrolmen as the council, upon recommendation of the town manager, may deem necessary for the protection of the lives and property of the citizens and the enforcement of state laws, town ordinances and resolutions. 
(Code 1981, § 12-1) 
State Law reference- Organization of police forces, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-131.7. 
Sec. 12-2. - Supervision. 
    The police department shall be under the control of the town manager for the purpose of preserving and enforcing peace and order, for the execution of the laws of the state and this Code and other ordinances of the town and the performance of such other duties as the town manager may prescribe. 
(Code 1981, § 12-2) 
Charter reference- Town manager, Art. VI. 
Sec. 12-3. - Oaths of office. 
    Every member of the police department, before entering upon the discharge of his duties as such, shall take the oath of office prescribed by the state. A certificate of such oath shall be filed with the town manager. 
(Code 1981, § 12-3) 
State Law reference- When and how city and town officers qualify, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-38; form of general oath required of officers, Code of Virginia, § 49-1. 
Sec. 12-4. - Filling vacancies. 
    The town manager may appoint policemen to fill such vacancies as may occur. He shall report such appointments to the town council at its next regular meeting. All appointments under this section shall be made subject to physical examinations and examination as to knowledge of the laws, ordinances and regulations. The examination as to laws, ordinances and regulations shall be approved by the town manager and may be either oral or written. The physical examination shall be made by such local physician as the town manager may designate. 
(Code 1981, § 12-4) 
State Law reference- Law enforcement officer training standards, Code of Virginia, § 9-179 et seq.; minimum qualifications of police officers, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-131.8. 
Sec. 12-5. - Auxiliary police force. 
(a)  An auxiliary police force pursuant to section 15.1-159.2 (B) of the Code of Virginia of 1950, as amended, the size of which shall not exceed twelve (12) persons, is hereby established. The members of the auxiliary police force shall have all of the power, authority, and all of the immunities provided full-time law enforcement officers of the town. The town council shall approve, by resolution, such rules and regulations for the uniform, organization, and operation of the auxiliary police force, as it deems necessary. 
(b)  The town manager is authorized to appoint four (4) persons, or such greater number as he deems necessary, not to exceed the limitation stated herein, to the auxiliary police force. The persons appointed to the auxiliary police force shall be of good character and their final appointment be subject to their satisfactory completion of all applicable criteria required of full-time police officers of the town, including a physical examination, other general requirements of the town provided in section 15-4 of this Code, and in the police employment policy of the town. The town manager shall promptly report all appointments to the next regular meeting of the town council. 
(c)  The chief of police is hereby authorized to call into service such appointed members of the auxiliary police as have completed all training requirements established by the department of criminal justice services, to aid and assist the regular police officers in the performance of their duties. 
(Code 1981, § 12-5; Ord. No. 1992-13, 8-11-92) 
State Law reference- Establishment of auxiliary police forces in counties, cities and towns, authorized powers, authority and immunities generally, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-159.2, et seq. 
Sec. 12-6. - General powers and duties. 
(a)  Each member of the police force shall devote his whole time and attention to the business of the police department. Although certain hours are allotted to the respective members for the ordinary performance of duty, each member shall at all times respond to the call of the town manager for services in the prosecution of his duties and be prepared to act immediately, on notice that his services are required by the town manager, chief of police or any citizen. 
(b)  A police officer shall have all powers: 
(1)  Of any conservator of the peace; 
(2)  Of a sheriff, in criminal cases; 
(3)  Which, under the laws of the town, may enable him to discharge the duties of his office. 
(c)  Punctual attendance and conformity to the provisions of this article shall be rigidly enforced. The members of the police department shall strictly comply with all rules and regulations which may be prescribed by the chief of police in addition to the rules and regulations set out in this article. 
(Code 1981, §§ 12-6, 12-7) 
State Law reference- Sheriffs and sergeants, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-74 et seq.; general powers police officers, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.1-131 et seq., 15.1-138; sergeants of towns, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-796; conservators of the peace and special policemen, Code of Virginia, § 19.2-12 et seq. 
Sec. 12-7. - Records of arrests, etc. 
    The chief of the police department and all members of the police department shall, within a reasonable time after making an arrest, enter upon the police blotter in the chief's office the name of the person arrested or summoned, the place of arrest, the offense charged and whether the offender was confined in jail, admitted to bail or recognized for his appearance at court. Any police officer of the town failing to make such entry in the police blotter of any arrest within a reasonable time after such arrest shall be guilty of a violation of this section. 
(Code 1981, § 12-8) 
State Law reference- Arrest, Code of Virginia, § 19.2-71 et seq. 
Sec. 12-8. - Off-duty performance. 
    If a patrolman is appealed to when it is not his time for regular duty, he shall, regardless of the time of day, do all the emergency requires. 
(Code 1981, § 12-9) 
State Law reference- Giving false reports to police officers, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-461. 
Sec. 12-9. - Conduct generally. 
    No member of the police department shall drink any kind of intoxicating liquor or beer while on duty or while in uniform off duty or smoke on the streets or enter any house of ill fame, except in the strict performance of his duty. 
(Code 1981, § 12-10) 
Sec. 12-10. - Conduct toward offenders and prisoners. 
    When it becomes necessary to take a person into custody, the policeman shall do so in an easy and quiet manner as possible, using only sufficient force to secure the prisoner; in no instance shall he strike a prisoner, except in self-defense. He shall see that the prisoner is properly dealt with and cared for until he is taken from his custody according to law and any unnecessary deprivations and abuses of prisoners will be met with reproof and punishment. 
(Code 1981, § 12-11) 
State Law reference- Malicious bodily injury to law enforcement officers, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-51.1; obstructing justice by threats or force, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-460. 
Sec. 12-11. - Political activities. 
    No member of the police department shall solicit or be obligated to make contributions, in money or otherwise, on any pretext, to any person, committee or association for any political purpose whatsoever. Every member of the department shall have the right to entertain political or partisan opinions and his right of elective franchise will be deemed sacred and inviolate, but no member of the police department shall take any part in any convention held for the nomination of candidates for political office or take an active part in elections or in the political advancement of any party, clique or individual. 
(Code 1981, § 12-12) 
Sec. 12-12. - Uniforms. 
    All regular policemen, including the chief, shall wear an official uniform furnished by the town, except as authorized by the chief of police. 
(Code 1981, § 12-13; Ord. No. 1997-02, 3-11-97) 
State Law reference- Unlawful wearing of officer's uniform, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-175. 
Sec. 12-13. - Disposal of unclaimed evidence and other property. 
(a)  The chief of police may dispose of unclaimed evidence and other personal property, hereinafter referred to as "property", acquired as part of the enforcement of the laws of the Commonwealth of Virginia and the town in the manner provided herein. Any such property may be sold at public auction or retained for use by the police department if it remains unclaimed after notice to its original owner as required herein. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall be applicable to property which has been acquired by the police department pursuant to its duties, which is not needed in any criminal prosecution, which has not been claimed by its rightful owner and which the state treasurer has indicated will be declined if remitted under the Uniform Disposition of Unclaimed Property Act of the Virginia Code. Whenever property coming under this section has no inherent value, is inherently dangerous or may not lawfully be sold or used, the chief of police shall provide for it to be destroyed or discarded in the county landfill or some other safe and appropriate location. 
(c)  The chief of police, or his duly authorized agent, shall make reasonable attempts to notify the rightful owner that their property is no longer necessary for the purposes which it was originally held. Written notice shall be sent to the owner, certified mail, return receipt requested, at their last [known] address, which shall reasonably identify their property and that such property is to be the subject of an auction and the date, place and time of such auction. The notice must inform the owner where the property is to be sold or displayed, if retained for use, must inform them of their right to the property if they claim the same prior to an auction and must notify them that no further notice will be given prior to the disposition of the proceeds or the property. The notice must be mailed, postage prepaid, no later than thirty (30) days prior to the scheduled auction. In addition, the chief of police shall also obtain from the attorney for the commonwealth in writing a statement advising that such property is not needed in any criminal prosecution. 
(d)  Upon compliance with the provisions of subsection (c), the chief of police shall cause to be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the town, once a week for two (2) successive weeks, notice that there will be a public auction and sale of unclaimed property. The notice shall generally describe the property for sale and for retention, the date, time and place of the auction and that the property will be available for public viewing at such time. 
(e)  The auction shall be conducted in any reasonable manner determined by the chief of police as appropriate for the type of unclaimed property to be sold. The proceeds of the auction shall be applied first to the cost of advertisement and notice of sale, then to removal and storage, and then to the cost of investigation of ownership and liens against the property and then to any liens determined to be valid against such property. 
(f)  Any unclaimed property for which no bid is received or which has been designated to be retained for use by the police department shall become property of the town sixty (60) days after the auction. Such property shall become property of the town only if, in the opinion of the chief of police that there is a legitimate use of the property by the police department and that retention of the property is a more economical alternative than purchase of similar or equivalent property. Property which is not retained and for which no bid was made at the auction, may be disposed of by the chief of police in the most economical manner for the town sixty (60) days after the auction. 
(g)  The balance of the funds remaining after expenses and liens for property sold shall be held by the chief of police in an account established by the finance director of the town for the owner and paid to the owner upon satisfactory proof of ownership. 
(h)  If no claim has been made for the property or proceeds of such sale within sixty (60) days of the sale, the remaining funds shall be deposited in the general fund of the town and the retained property may be placed into use by the police department. 
(i)  Any owner notified of the sale or retention of property under this section shall be entitled to apply to the town council within three (3) years from the date of this sale, and, if timely application is made therefor and satisfactory proof of ownership of the funds or property is made, the town shall pay the remaining proceeds of sale or return the retained property to the owner without interest or other charges or compensation. No claim shall be made or any suit, action or proceeding be instituted for the recovery of such funds or property after three (3) years from the date of the sale. 
(Ord. No. 2001-11, 7-10-2001) 
State Law reference- Virginia Code reference: § 15.2-1719 
Secs. 12-14-12-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CHIEF OF POLICE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 

Sec. 12-31. - Appointment; term. 
    The town manager shall appoint a chief of police in the same manner as other police officers are appointed. The chief of police shall hold office at the will of the town manager. 
(Code 1981, § 12-14) 
Charter reference- Town manager, Art. VI. 
Sec. 12-32. - Powers and duties generally. 
(a)  The chief of police shall be the chief executive of the police department but he shall always be subject to the orders and regulations of the town manager. He shall be under the control of the town manager for the purpose of preserving and enforcing peace and order and executing the laws of the state and ordinances of the town. It shall be the duty of the police force to respect and obey orders of the chief not in conflict with the rules and regulations. It shall be his duty at all times, day or night: 
(1)  To preserve the public peace. 
(2)  To prevent the commission of crimes, and arrest offenders. 
(3)  To protect the rights of persons and of property. 
(4)  To guard the public health. 
(5)  To report nuisances and obstructions in the streets, alleys and other public places. 
(6)  To provide proper police force at fires. 
(7)  To protect the firemen and property at fires and to discharge such other duties as may be required of him by the town manager. 
(b)  When charges are filed in his office against any member of the police force or when he shall be informed of any gross neglect of duty, he shall immediately transmit such charges to the town manager, together with the names of witnesses to be summoned, so that the charges may be fully investigated by the town manager. 
(c)  He shall be responsible for the good order of the town and for the general good conduct of the members of the police force. 
(d)  He shall pay frequent visits at uncertain times to various portions of the town in order to supervise the conduct of all subordinates. 
(Code 1981, § 12-15) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 7. 
Sec. 12-33. - Records and reports. 
    The chief of police shall: 
(1)  Make periodic reports in writing from time to time to the town manager as he may require, showing the condition of the police force, the number of times each policeman has been absent and the cause of such absence, the condition of the jail, the number of arrests and the causes of such arrests and the number of ordinance violations reported. 
(2)  Keep a record compiled by himself of the work of each policeman, showing marks of credit in the performance of duty, and showing demerits and the cause therefor and any and all complaints with reference to any given member of the force. 
(3)  On the first day of each month or as soon thereafter as practicable, furnish the town manager with a consolidated written report of the activities of his department for the previous month. Forms of such reports shall be prepared and furnished by the town manager. 
(4)  Keep duplicate records in his office of the reports made to the town manager in pursuance of the requirements of this section. 
(5)  Keep records showing the name of each member of the police force and the area in which each member is stationed from day to day, the date of appointment and time of removal or suspension and the happening of any vacancies in the department. 
(6)  Communicate to the town manager any information from the daily reports of members of the department or other persons in regard to streets, lights and other matters which will be of use to the town manager in the administration of his office. 
(7)  Comply with the additional requirements of Code of Virginia, section 15.1-135.1. 
(Code 1981, § 12-16) 
State Law reference- Records kept by chiefs of police, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-135.1. 
Sec. 12-34. - Absence from duty. 
    The chief of police shall not leave the town unless he shall first receive permission to do so from the town manager. When such permission is granted, or in case of sickness, he shall designate a member of the force as acting chief of police during his absence. This rule shall not apply when it may become necessary for him to leave the town hurriedly on business directly connected with the police department. 
(Code 1981, § 12-17) 
State Law reference- Police may be sent beyond territorial limits, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-131; powers of police, etc., as to property owned by town beyond its territorial limits, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-131.1. 
Chapter 13 - SOLICITORS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Dealers in precious metals and gems, Ch. 6; licenses, Ch. 9; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 10; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 14; taxation, Ch. 15; noise, § 11-19. 
State Law reference- Municipal regulation of certain door-to-door vendors, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.1-37.3:1, 15.1-37.3:2; solicitation of contributions, Code of Virginia, § 57-48 et seq.; local ordinances relating to charitable solicitations, Code of Virginia, § 57-63; licensing of peddlers and itinerant merchants, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3717 et seq. 

Sec. 13-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Charitable organization: Any person which is or holds itself out to be organized or operated for any charitable purpose, or any person which solicits or obtains contributions solicited from the public. This definition shall not be deemed to include: 
(1)  Any church or convention or association of churches, primarily operated for nonsecular purposes and no part of the net income of which inures to the direct benefit of any individual; 
(2)  Any political party as defined in Code of Virginia, § 24.1-1, or any political campaign committee required by state or federal law to file a report or statement of contributions and expenditures; 
(3)  Any labor union registered under Code of Virginia, § 40.1-76, nor any trade association; 
(4)  Any authorized individual who solicits, by authority of such organization, solely on behalf of a registered or exempt charitable organization or on behalf of an organization excluded from the definition of charitable organization. 
    Charitable purpose: Any charitable, benevolent, humane, philanthropic, patriotic, or eleemosynary purpose and the purposes of influencing legislation or influencing the actions of any public official or instigating, prosecuting, or intervening in litigation. 
    Sale, sell and sold: The transfer of any property or the rendition of any service to any person in exchange for consideration, including any purported contribution without which such property would not have been transferred or such services would not have been rendered. 
    Solicit and solicitation: The request or appeal, directly or indirectly, for any contribution on the plea or representation that such contribution will be used for a charitable purpose, including, without limitation, the following methods of requesting such contribution: 
(1)  Any oral or written request; 
(2)  Any announcement to the press, over the radio or television, or by telephone or telegraph concerning an appeal or campaign to which the public is requested to make a contribution for any charitable purpose connected therewith; 
(3)  The distribution, circulation, posting or publishing of any handbill written advertisement or other publication which directly or by implication seeks to obtain public support; 
(4)  The sale of, offer or attempt to sell, any advertisement, advertising space, subscription, ticket, or any service or tangible item in connection with which any appeal is made for any charitable purpose or where the name of any charitable organization is used or referred to in any such appeal as an inducement or reason for making any such sale, or when or where in connection with any such sale, any statement is made that the whole or any part of the proceeds from any such sale will be donated to any charitable purpose. 
    Solicitation , as defined herein, shall be deemed to occur when the request is made, at the place the request is received, whether or not the person making the same actually receives any contribution. 
    Solicitor: A person who goes from door to door visiting multi-family or single-family dwellings for the following purposes: 
(1)  To sell any goods, wares, merchandise or services or accept subscriptions or orders therefor. 
(2)  To accept or request donations for any charitable purpose. 
(Code 1981, §§ 13-1, 13-2; Ord. No. 2017-07 , 5-9-17) 
Sec. 13-2. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to: 
(1)  Any person who visits any residence or apartment at the request or invitation of the owner or occupant thereof. 
(2)  To unpaid members of any civic or charitable organization who have an approved means of identification provided by the organization represented. 
(3)  Persons selling, or soliciting subscriptions to any newspaper for home delivery. 
(4)  Route deliverymen who make deliveries at least once a week to regular customers and whose solicitation is only incidental to their regular deliveries. 
(5)  Persons selling fresh farm products. 
(6)  Persons licensed under the provisions of Code of Virginia, Title 38.2. 
(7)  Charitable organizations that have registered with the state commissioner of agriculture and consumer services or his designee as provided by law, but the names of such organizations' solicitors shall be registered pursuant to this chapter. 
(Code 1981, § 13-7; Ord. No. 2017-07 , 5-9-17) 
State Law reference- Persons exempted from ordinances regulating vendors, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-37.3:1; exemption of charitable organizations from ordinance provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-63(d). 
Sec. 13-3. - Registration required. 
    All persons, before entering into or upon residential premises within the town for the purpose of soliciting, shall register with the chief of police and furnish him with the following information: 
(1)  The name, local and permanent addresses, age, race, weight, height, color of hair and eyes and any other distinguishing physical characteristics of the applicant. 
(2)  The nature or purpose for which solicitations will be made and the nature of the goods, wares, merchandise or services offered for sale. 
(3)  The name and permanent address of the employer or organization represented. 
(4)  A statement as to whether the applicant has been convicted of any felony or misdemeanor and, if so, the nature of the offense, when and where convicted and the penalty or punishment assessed therefor. 
(Code 1981, § 13-3; Ord. No. 2017-07 , 5-9-17) 
Sec. 13-4. - Permit-Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in soliciting funds for any charitable, philanthropic, educational or other like purpose, in and upon the streets of the town or in any public place within the town, unless he shall first have obtained a permit therefor from the chief of police. 
(Code 1981, § 13-3.1; Ord. No. 2017-07 , 5-9-17) 
Sec. 13-5. - Same-Issuance; display required. 
    Upon furnishing the information required under section 13-4, the applicant shall be issued a permit, unless the information furnished in compliance with this chapter shows that the applicant has been convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude. A permit issued under this chapter shall be good for one (1) year from the date of issuance, unless earlier revoked as provided in this article. Every solicitor required by this chapter to obtain a permit shall carry his permit with him at all times while engaged in soliciting, and shall display the same to any person who shall demand to see the same while he is so engaged. 
(Code 1981, § 13-4; Ord. No. 2017-07 , 5-9-17) 
Sec. 13-6. - Same-Fees. 
    A fee fixed from time to time by the town council to cover the costs of investigation of the applicant and processing of the application shall be paid to the chief of police when the application is filed, and shall not be returnable under any circumstances. 
(Code 1981, § 13-5; Ord. No. 2017-07 , 5-9-17) 
State Law reference- Fee may be collected from certain vendors, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-37.3:2. 
Sec. 13-7. - Prohibited acts. 
    No person shall: 
(1)  Enter into or upon any residential premises in the town under false pretenses to solicit for any purpose or for the purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares, merchandise or services. 
(2)  Remain in or on any residential premises after the owner or occupant has requested any such person to leave. 
(3)  Enter upon any residential premises for soliciting, when the owner or occupant has displayed a "no soliciting" sign on such premises. 
(4)  Engage in the practice of soliciting in the town without a permit as provided for in this chapter. 
(5)  Knowingly give false information or fail to provide correct information in obtaining a permit. 
(Code 1981, § 13-6; Ord. No. 2017-07 , 5-9-17) 
State Law reference- Fee may be collected from certain vendors, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-37.3:2. 
Sec. 13-8. - Penalties. 
    Any person guilty of violating this chapter shall be guilty of a Class 4 Misdemeanor for a first offense. Any second or subsequent offense shall be guilty of a Class 1 Misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 2017-07 , 5-9-17) 
Chapter 14 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Special assessments, § 2-3. 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; animals and fowl, Ch. 3; buildings, Ch. 4; cemetery, Ch. 5; garbage, trash, and weeds, Ch. 8; depositing refuse in public places, § 8-2; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 10; permits for parades and processions, § 10-8; defacing street signs, monuments, etc., § 11-8; water and sewers, Ch. 17. 
State Law reference- Municipal streets, walks, alleys and public places, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.1-14, 15.1-363 et seq., 15.1-888 et seq.; assessment for local improvements, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-239 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Obstructions generally; sidewalk cafes. 
(a)  Permit to obstruct. No person shall obstruct any of the streets or alleys of the town by any article, material or device or by the exhibition or storage of any property or materials thereon unless such person has first obtained a permit therefor from the town manager. Such a permit may be issued where the safety of the public is adequately protected. 
(b)  Displays. It shall be unlawful for any person to use any portion of the public sidewalks in the town for the purpose of displaying, exhibiting or offering for sale any goods, wares, merchandise or other articles; except that merchants dealing in seasonal flower plants, vegetable plants and ornamental shrubbery may display the same on shelves or stands extending not more than eighteen (18) inches in front of the building line of the place of business. Such displays shall be permitted only where the sidewalk is of adequate width, and provided that such displays shall be removed from in front of the place of business each day by or immediately after the close of the business day. 
(c)  Sidewalk cafes. Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter and subject to the regulations and specifications contained in this section, sidewalk cafes shall be allowed within the central business district upon issuance of a permit from the town manager. The term "sidewalk cafe" or "cafe" shall mean an outdoor or semi-enclosed dining area directly adjoining and part of a restaurant within the central business district and located on a public sidewalk, alley, or right-of-way, where customers of the restaurant sit and dine. 
(1)  Regulations. 
a.  Every cafe shall be temporary in nature and designed so that the entire cafe structure and its improvements, including chairs, planters, fences, railings, etc., can be removed during periods of non-use. 
b.  No portion of a sidewalk cafe may be used for any purpose other than dining or circulation. 
c.  Cafes shall comply with all applicable federal, state, and local laws and regulations, and shall be inspected and approved by the zoning administrator prior to beginning actual operation. 
d.  Each cafe shall be adjacent to its adjoining restaurant facility. 
e.  The operation of sidewalk cafes shall be exempt from any additional off-street parking requirements as set forth in the zoning ordinance. 
f.  No cafe shall begin operations until the town manager has reviewed and approved a certificate of insurance indicating that the business operator has general liability insurance coverage for personal injury and property damage in the amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) aggregate, with the town named as an additional insured. Such certificate shall further indicate that such coverage shall not be modified or canceled for any reason without the insurer providing the town with at least thirty (30) days' prior notice of such change(s). 
(2)  Specifications. 
a.  Sidewalk cafe operations shall be confined to a physical area approved by the town manager. No equipment or facilities of a cafe shall project beyond the designated perimeter of the cafe as approved. A cafe may not cover or extend beyond the frontage face of its adjoining restaurant facility. The size, scale, proportion, and overall design of the cafe shall be reviewed and approved by the town manager to ensure that the cafe is compatible with the public right-of-travel, adjoining buildings, streetscape, and character of the zoning district. The approved size of the cafe will be based partly on the width of the sidewalk upon which it is located and the space available for pedestrian passage. 
b.  The cafe operator shall be responsible at all times for the maintenance of an attractive, clean, and safe cafe area and for any necessary maintenance of the cafe area. All movable objects or equipment (e.g., tables, chairs, furnishings and fixtures) required to operate the cafe shall be removed from the cafe area and stored out of public view during the winter months and during nonbusiness hours. 
c.  Only the existing sidewalk surface is to be used for placement of removable cafe furnishings. 
d.  Not more than one (1) well-marked entrance shall be permitted for each sidewalk cafe. 
e.  The exterior furnishings of the cafe shall consist of temporary fixtures and decorative accessories. No permanent fixtures or improvements to town sidewalks shall be permitted. 
f.  The furnishings of the cafe shall be placed under an awning attached to the building facade and with a minimum clearance of at least four (4) feet between the furnishings and the edge of the sidewalk or appropriate cover. 
(3)  Applications. 
a.  Any person or entity seeking to operate a sidewalk cafe shall file an application with the town manager. The application shall be on a form supplied by the town. 
b.  The application shall include three (3) copies of the applicant's sidewalk cafe plan/drawing, depicting the proposed cafe area boundary, placement of tables, chairs, signs, awnings and other equipment or furnishings, and any other information deemed necessary by the town manager. 
c.  The town manager shall review and recommend approval, modification or denial of a sidewalk cafe permit ("permit"). If the application requires ARB approval for structural alterations, the town manager shall make such recommendation pending ARB action. 
(4)  Permits. 
a.  Prior to final approval of a permit by the town manager, the applicant shall certify that approval has been received from all relevant governmental authorities to begin operating, including the health department and the alcoholic beverage control board of the commonwealth. 
b.  The town manager shall have sole discretion to issue a permit to the owner of a restaurant/cafe business. The permit shall contain such terms and conditions as the town manager determines are necessary to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
c.  The permit, as issued and signed by the town manager, shall contain a statement, executed by the permittee, that they agree to indemnify and hold harmless the town, its agents, and employees from any and all losses, damages, expenses, and claims arising out of the permittee's design, construction, operation, and maintenance of the sidewalk cafe. 
d.  The initial permit issued by the town manager shall be valid for one (1) year from the date of issuance. 
e.  The town manager may reissue permits for periods up to three (3) years, with such modifications as the manager deems appropriate. If any application for renewal involves exterior alterations to the restaurant building, the applicant shall submit an application to the architectural review board. 
(5)  Enforcement. 
a.  The town manager, or his designee, shall have the authority to inspect sidewalk cafes at any time and to take all necessary steps to enforce the provisions of this section. In the event that the town manager suspects that a sidewalk cafe operator has failed to comply with any provision of this section, any provision of its permit, or any other provision of law, the town manager shall provide the operator with a written notice of violation, detailing the violations and giving the permittee a minimum of forty-eight (48) hours to remedy such violations(s). 
b.  If a cafe operator fails to correct any violation specified in a notice of violation within the time period set forth herein, the town manager shall have the right to revoke the operator's permit for cause upon an administrative hearing held with at least two (2) weeks prior written notice. The town manager's decision following such hearing shall be final. 
c.  The town manager shall have the right to terminate any permit for the convenience of the town upon ninety (90) days' prior written notice to the operator. 
d.  The town manager shall have the authority to require the permittee to suspend or limit cafe operations or to relocate or alter all or part of the cafe structure or improvements, either temporarily or permanently, in order to facilitate or allow town operations upon public property. 
e.  In the event of an emergency, the town manager shall have the authority to require the immediate suspension of operations of a sidewalk cafe and/or the removal of all physical improvements constituting the cafe structure. 
(Code 1981, § 14-8; Ord. No. 1998-15, 10-13-98) 
Sec. 14-2. - Use of sidewalks when receiving deliveries. 
    Merchants and other persons, while receiving goods or articles, may place the same on the outer margin of the sidewalk, using only as much thereof as may be necessary; provided, that the public shall not be deprived thereby of the free, easy and comfortable use of the sidewalk. Such occupation of the sidewalk shall be for only such time as may be necessary for such reception or delivery. It shall be the duty of the police to see that the sidewalks are not obstructed so as to deprive the public of the use of them as described in this section. They are empowered to require that goods and other articles obstructing the sidewalk be moved at once. 
(Code 1981, § 14-9) 
Cross reference- Police department, Ch.12. 
Sec. 14-3. - Building operations abutting streets or sidewalks. 
(a)  When any work is being done on structures abutting on any street or sidewalk, which work may endanger persons passing along such street or sidewalk, barriers shall be placed across the way so as to prevent and warn persons against the danger and shall have sufficient lanterns or lights hung thereon at night. No bricks, slate or any other thing or substance shall be thrown off, from or out of such structure or any part thereof into the street or sidewalk, except within the space enclosed by such barriers. Any person failing to comply with the provisions of this section shall, in addition to the penalty for such noncompliance, be responsible for all damages resulting therefrom. 
(b)  The town manager may grant a permit for the use of half of the street between curb lines opposite a lot upon which any building or wall is being erected, for use laying timber and other building materials during such reasonable time as may be necessary for such erection, but no longer. Should there be buildings in course of construction on the opposite side of the street at the same time, then each may occupy one-fourth (1/4) of such street. When such building or wall is being erected, the sidewalk in front thereof shall not be obstructed, but, for the protection of persons passing, a shed or platform shall be erected over the sidewalk which shall be at least seven and one-half (71/2) feet high, five (5) feet wide or as wide as the existing sidewalk and as long as the building or wall which is being constructed, under which persons may safely walk. Any damage done to the street or sidewalk by such building or contractor shall be repaired by him. 
(Code 1981, § 14-10) 
Cross reference- Buildings, Ch. 4. 
Sec. 14-4. - Barriers required for ditches, etc., abutting streets or sidewalks. 
    When any ditch is dug or excavation is made in or abutting a street or sidewalk, sufficient barriers shall be placed around and over such ditch or excavation to prevent persons or animals from falling therein. During every night while such excavation or opening is uncovered or unenclosed, sufficient lanterns or other noticeable lights shall be conspicuously placed so as to cast their light upon such excavation or opening. The person failing to comply with the provisions of this section shall, in addition to the penalty for violation of this section, be responsible for all damages resulting therefrom. 
(Code 1981, § 14-11) 
Sec. 14-5. - Disposition of snow, ice, etc. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the occupant of any house and lot which abuts upon a paved sidewalk or a footway of stone, brick or wood to have all snow removed from such sidewalk or footway within six (6) hours after the same shall have ceased falling, unless such snow shall have fallen during the night or on a Sunday, in which case it shall be removed by 12:00 noon of the day following. The same requirements shall exist with respect to ice or sleet on sidewalks or footways; except, that ice or sleet, when it cannot be removed without injury to the sidewalk or footway, shall be covered, within the period of time as above specified, with sand, ashes or some other substance which will render it safe for travel on foot. Whenever any house or lot is unoccupied, it shall be the duty of the owner, or of the agent of the owner, to have the snow or ice removed from his sidewalk or footway in the same manner as set forth above for occupants of properties. Each violation of this subsection shall be a class 4 misdemeanor, and every six (6) hours that such snow or ice is allowed to remain in violation of this subsection shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person removing ice or snow from his premises to place or deposit such ice or snow upon any street or sidewalk. 
(Code 1981, § 14-12) 
Sec. 14-6. - Retaining walls for earth embankments. 
    Whenever earth embankments abut on any paved street or sidewalk, it shall be the duty of the owner of such property to erect suitable barriers or retaining walls to prevent loose earth or mud from falling upon such street or sidewalk. 
(Code 1981, § 14-13) 
Sec. 14-7. - Snowbreaks on buildings on street lines. 
    Buildings which are located on the line of any street shall be provided with suitable snowbreaks or guards on the side next to such street. 
(Code 1981, § 14-15) 
Sec. 14-8. - Planting shade trees. 
    No person shall plant any shade trees in the streets or sidewalks of the town without the prior consent of the town manager, who shall designate the proper line for such trees. 
(Code 1981, § 14-16) 
State Law reference- Landscape studies for urban highway construction projects, Code of Virginia, § 33.1-47.1. 
Sec. 14-9. - Barbed wire fencing along streets, etc. 
    No person shall erect along or on any street, alley or sidewalk of the town what is known as barbed wire fencing. 
(Code 1981, § 14-17) 
Sec. 14-10. - Holes, depressions, etc., below grade of street. 
    Upon private lots, all holes, depressions, excavations or other dangerous places below the grade of the adjoining street, shall be properly enclosed with fences or walls or filled up by the owners or occupants of such lots so as to prevent persons or animals from falling therein. It shall be the duty of the chief of police and town manager to notify the owners or occupants of premises on which such dangerous places exist and require that fences or walls be built around them or that they be filled up within such period as they shall deem that the exigencies of the case may require. In case of failure to comply with such notification, the owners or occupants shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this section, and the town manager may cause such fencing or filling to be done at the expense of the town and the sum so expended, plus twenty (20) percent thereof added as a penalty, shall be collected from the owner or occupant in addition to the penalty provided under section 1-7. 
(Code 1981, § 14-18) 
Sec. 14-11. - Use of streets as bus terminal. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person operating any motor vehicle as a carrier of passengers in intrastate or interstate commerce to use, or cause to be used, the streets in the town as a terminal or station for the purpose of receiving or discharging passengers. 
(Code 1981, § 14-19) 
Sec. 14-12. - Sales by book agents to pedestrians. 
    Book agents selling directly to customers, licensed as provided in chapter 9, shall not sell or offer to sell to persons walking along the sidewalks and streets of the town. 
(Code 1981, § 14-20) 
Sec. 14-13. - Keeping sidewalks clear of dirt, filth, etc. 
    Every person owning or occupying property abutting on a paved sidewalk shall cause such sidewalk to be kept clear of dirt or filth or dangerous or obnoxious matter and substance. Failure to keep such sidewalk clear shall constitute a violation of this section unless such dirt or filth has been deposited on the sidewalk by the city or a public service corporation over which the person owning or occupying the abutting property can have no control. 
(Code 1981, § 14-22) 
Sec. 14-14. - Placing, etc., glass, etc., on street. 
(a)  No person shall throw or deposit or cause to be deposited upon any street or highway any glass bottle, glass, nail, tack, wire, can or any other substance likely to injure any person or animal, or damage any vehicle upon such street or highway, nor shall any person throw or deposit or cause to be deposited upon any street or highway any soil, sand, mud, gravel or other substances so as to create a hazard to the traveling public. 
(b)  Any person who drops, or permits to be dropped or thrown, upon any street or highway any destructive, hazardous or injurious material shall immediately remove the same or cause it to be removed. 
(c)  Any person removing a wrecked or damaged vehicle from a street or highway shall remove any glass or other injurious substance dropped upon the street or highway from such vehicle. 
(Code 1981, § 14-23) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-324. 
Sec. 14-15. - Paving, relaying, etc.-Sidewalk construction by citizen or property owner. 
    Whenever any citizen or property owner desires to lay a sidewalk for himself in a town street, he shall make application to the town manager in writing. The town manager shall grant such permission upon the condition that the applicant shall make such improvement at his own expense and shall do the work under the supervision of the town manager. 
(Code 1981, § 14-25) 
Sec. 14-16. - Same-Procedure when changing grade. 
(a)  Whenever the paving, grading or making of sidewalks or streets anywhere in the town is ordered by the town council, it shall be the duty of the town manager, when in his opinion such street or sidewalk should be so graded as to raise or lower the same materially with reference to the property of abutting lot owners, to make his plans of such improvement, showing accurately in feet and tenths the elevation or lowering of the street with reference to such adjacent property. 
(b)  Before proceeding with the work under this section the town manager shall obtain from the owners of the property to be affected by such change of grade, a written waiver of all damages. If such property owners refuse to sign such waiver the town manager shall report the situation to the town council and receive authority from that body before proceeding with work. 
(Code 1981, § 14-26) 
Sec. 14-17. - Same-Exposure of water pipes. 
    When, in repairing or grading or otherwise disturbing a street, any water pipe is left uncovered or exposed, it shall be the duty of the person in charge of such work to forthwith notify the town manager of such exposure. 
(Code 1981, § 14-27) 
Sec. 14-18. - Removal of warning signs, barriers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to remove, injure, disturb or interfere with any barriers, barricades or lights placed under this chapter as a warning of danger or for the protection of persons or property. 
(Code 1981, § 14-37) 
Sec. 14-19. - Repaving, relaying, repairing, reconstructing, or altering sidewalks; assessments of cost upon owners. 
    The owners of property abutting on any sidewalk in the town which shall be hereafter repaved, relaid, repaired, reconstructed or altered shall not be required to pay for said improvement. Should the owners of property abutting on any sidewalk in the town desire that the same be repaved, relaid, repaired, reconstructed or altered in any other substance other than what is existing, said abutting property owner shall be charged or taxed for the additional cost for any other substance other than what is existing. 
(Ord. No. 1987-4, 1-5-88) 
Secs. 14-20-14-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ENCROACHMENTS; PROJECTIONS
