(b)  No person shall solicit patronage for any taxicab by word, signal or otherwise on any public street or public property in the town other than at such stands as may be designated and assigned under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1981, § 17-11) 
Sec. 16-13. - Vehicles-Type. 
    Every taxicab shall be of the enclosed or sedan type with four (4) doors, at least two (2) seats and of not less than five (5) passenger capacity. 
(Code 1981, § 17-12) 
Sec. 16-14. - Same-Condition. 
    Every taxicab shall be at all times in good order and repair when in operation. 
(Code 1981, § 17-13) 
Sec. 16-15. - Same-Inspection; correction of defects. 
    Each taxicab within the town shall be inspected by the chief of police, or some member of the police department designated by him, on the first Monday in January and June of each year. If any such vehicle shall be found to be unsafe, unfit or in an unclean condition, the owner thereof shall be notified at once that such vehicle shall not be operated thereafter until such defective or unclean condition has been remedied. 
(Code 1981, § 17-14) 
Sec. 16-16. - Same-Display of information. 
    Every taxicab shall bear on the outside and on at least two (2) sides, the name of the owner in letters not less than two (2) inches high and plainly visible at a distance of one hundred (100) feet. On two (2) sides and the back, the owner's telephone number shall be in letters three (3) inches high and shall be plainly visible at a distance of one hundred (100) feet. However, operators shall be permitted, if they so desire, to maintain one (1) unmarked cab for each four (4) marked cabs, which unmarked cab shall be used for private charter trips. 
(Code 1981, § 17-15) 
Sec. 16-17. - Same-Containing radios receiving police calls. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate any taxicab along the streets of the town in which a radio is installed which is capable of receiving police calls. It shall be unlawful for such taxicabs to be equipped with a radio capable of receiving only a standard broadcast. 
(Code 1981, § 17-16) 
Cross reference- Police department, Ch. 12. 
Sec. 16-18. - Transporting soiled objects. 
    Owners of taxicabs are prohibited from transporting or permitting to be transported objects or materials within their vehicles which might leave dirt, stains, dust or otherwise soil or leave unclean the taxicabs or taxicab drivers in such a way that the presence of these conditions might be damaging or objectionable to other persons using the taxicabs or lead to an unclean condition therein. 
(Code 1981, § 17-17) 
Sec. 16-19. - License prerequisite to operation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, or cause to be operated, within the town any taxicab unless a license therefor has been issued to the owner thereof in accordance with chapter 9. 
(Code 1981, § 17-18) 
Sec. 16-20. - Application of and compliance with chapter. 
    The operation of taxicabs in the town shall be subject to the conditions, regulations and restrictions set forth in this chapter and it shall be unlawful to operate or cause to be operated within the city any taxicab unless the conditions, regulations and restrictions herein set forth and prescribed have been complied with by such owner. 
(Code 1981, § 17-19) 
Secs. 16-21-16-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CERTIFICATE OF PUBLIC CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY 

Sec. 16-36. - Prerequisite to license or operation on streets. 
    No license for the operation of a taxicab shall be issued by the finance director, nor shall any taxicab be operated on the streets of the town unless and until the council has issued a certificate to the owner thereof. 
(Code 1981, § 17-20) 
Sec. 16-37. - Application-Contents; filing. 
(a)  Application for a certificate, as required in this article, shall be made by the owner or proposed owner to the council and filed with the town manager upon forms provided therefor by the town and shall furnish the following information under oath of the applicant: 
(1)  The full name and the home and business address of the applicant. 
(2)  The trade name under which the applicant does or proposes to do business. 
(3)  The financial status and responsibility of the applicant. 
(4)  The name and address of any person lending money or furnishing capital to applicant where the operation or proposed operation is to be financed wholly or in part by means of borrowed money or capital in any form furnished by any person other than the owner. 
(5)  The number and kind of vehicle, showing seating capacity, design and color scheme of each. 
(6)  The character and location of the depots and terminals to be used, if any. 
(7)  Each conviction or plea of guilty for the violation of any criminal law, whether such violation was of a town ordinance, state law or federal laws. 
(8)  The specific experience of applicant in the transportation of passengers for hire. 
(9)  All facts or circumstances upon which applicant bases his belief that public convenience and necessity require the granting of his application. 
(b)  Such application shall be filed with the town manager at least seven (7) days prior to the regular council meeting at which the application is to be acted upon. 
(Code 1981, § 17-21) 
Sec. 16-38. - Same-Copy furnished to police chief. 
    Upon the filing of an application, as provided in section 16-37, with the town manager, the chief of police shall be furnished with a copy immediately. 
(Code 1981, § 17-22) 
Sec. 16-39. - Same-Publication of notice. 
    Notice of an application filed as provided in section 16-37 shall be published by the applicant in a newspaper published in the town, once a week for two (2) successive weeks prior to the date on which the application is heard. 
(Code 1981, § 17-23) 
Sec. 16-40. - Investigation of applicants. 
    Upon the receipt of an application furnished to the chief of police pursuant to section 16-38, it shall be the duty of the chief of police promptly to make an investigation as to the suitable character and qualification of the applicant to conduct such business and, in the case of corporations, to investigate the fitness of the officers, directors and stockholders. He shall report his findings in writing, which report shall be filed with the town manager prior to the regular council meeting at which the application is to be acted upon. Such written report, when so filed, shall be available to the applicant and to his attorney at law or to either. 
(Code 1981, § 17-24) 
Sec. 16-41. - Determination of necessity-Burden of proof upon applicant. 
    When the town council considers an application for a certificate required by the provisions of this article, the burden shall be upon the applicant to establish the existence of public convenience and necessity for the operation of the taxicabs designated in his application and all other facts required for the granting of such application. 
(Code 1981, § 17-25) 
Sec. 16-42. - Same-Standards considered by council. 
    The town council shall determine whether the public convenience and necessity require the operation of the taxicabs for which application has been filed under the provisions of this article. In making this determination, the following shall be considered: 
(1)  The adequacy and efficiency and safety of existing taxicab service and other forms of transportation for passengers already in existence. 
(2)  The probable permanence and quality of the service offered by the applicant. 
(3)  The financial status, character and qualification and responsibility of the applicant. 
(4)  The number and character of vehicles. 
(5)  Whether or not depots and terminals will be used; if so, their character and location. 
(6)  The experience of the applicant in the transportation of passengers for hire in taxicabs. 
(Code 1981, § 17-26) 
Sec. 16-43. - Authority of town council to issue, refuse, etc. 
    The town council shall have the authority to grant a certificate as applied for under this article or to grant a certificate for a lesser number of vehicles than that specified in the application or to deny the application in the exercise of a sound discretion, after a consideration of the factors prescribed by section 16-42. 
(Code 1981, § 17-27) 
Sec. 16-44. - Issuance generally; fees; contents. 
    Upon determination by the town council that any application, filed as provided in section 16-37 shall be granted and upon payment to the finance director of a certificate fee, fixed from time to time by the town council, a certificate shall be issued to the applicant by the town manager and shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the owner. 
(2)  The number, kind and description of vehicles, the operation of which is authorized by the certificate. 
(3)  The date of issuance and the date of expiration. 
(4)  The fact that the certificate is being issued subject to the provisions of this chapter and all other laws and ordinances governing the operation of taxicabs in the town. 
(Code 1981, § 17-28) 
Sec. 16-45. - Term. 
    Every certificate issued under this article shall be good and valid, unless revoked or suspended as provided in this article, from the date of issuance until the following thirty-first day of May and shall be valid annually thereafter until the thirty-first day of May of each year, unless revoked by the town council. 
(Code 1981, § 17-29) 
Sec. 16-46. - Transferability. 
    A certificate issued under this article shall be transferable only by and with the consent of the town council. Application for any such transfer shall be filed with the town manager and, upon the filing of such application for transfer, the person to whom the transfer is to be made shall file an application as if an original application were being made. The proceedings upon such transfer shall be the same as upon an original application. 
(Code 1981, § 17-30) 
Sec. 16-47. - Revocation, suspension, etc. 
    Any certificate issued pursuant to this article may be revoked, cancelled or suspended by the town council, after due notice to the certificate holder, for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Failure to operate the taxicabs specified in the certificate. 
(2)  Failure to maintain taxicabs in good order or repair. 
(3)  Failure to pay the personal property tax or other taxes due the town or state on taxicabs specified in the certificate. 
(4)  Failure to maintain insurance as required under this chapter. 
(5)  Failure to report any accident as required by law or this chapter. 
(6)  Failure of the drivers employed by the holder of the certificate to stay neat in appearance. 
(7)  Failure of the drivers employed by the holder of the certificate to be courteous at all times. 
(8)  Failure of the drivers employed by the holder of the certificate to have and exhibit taxicab drivers' permits in the taxicab. 
(9)  Repeated and persistent violations of traffic and safety ordinances by drivers employed by the holder of the certificate. 
(10)  Employment of a driver who has been convicted a third time of a state, municipal or federal offense. 
(11)  Purchase by drivers employed by the holder of the certificate of alcoholic beverages of any description for their passengers or toleration of any disorderly conduct in the taxicab. 
(12)  Wilful or continued failure to comply with the provisions of this chapter or any other law or ordinance regulating the operation of public vehicles or taxicabs in the town. 
(13)  Wilful neglect to render promised service. 
(Code 1981, § 17-31) 
State Law reference- Unlawful transportation of alcoholic beverages, Code of Virginia, § 4-74 et seq. 
Sec. 16-48. - Change in authorized numbers of vehicles. 
    The town council is authorized from time to time to increase or decrease, as public convenience and necessity may require, the number of vehicles operated under certificates issued pursuant to this article; provided, that in the event the public convenience and necessity require a decrease in the number of vehicles so operated, the certificates last granted shall be the first to be subject to decrease. 
(Code 1981, § 17-32) 
Sec. 16-49. - Substitution of authorized equipment. 
    No equipment shall be substituted for that described in a certificate unless and until it has been inspected and approved by the chief of police and the substitution has been endorsed on the certificate by the chief of police and approved by the town manager. 
(Code 1981, § 17-33) 
Sec. 16-50. - Persons operating taxicabs on effective date of chapter. 
    All persons engaged in the business of operating taxicabs on the effective date of this chapter who can qualify with the requirements of this chapter shall be entitled to a certificate for each vehicle. No certificate for any additional vehicle shall be issued unless the council determines that the public convenience and necessity require such additional service. 
(Code 1981, § 17-34) 
Secs. 16-51-16-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TAXICAB DRIVER'S PERMIT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal licensing of drivers of taxicabs, Code of Virginia, §§ 46.2-310; 58.1-3703(B)(13). 

Sec. 16-66. - Required. 
    No person shall drive a taxicab within the town unless he shall have obtained a special permit to be known as a "taxicab driver's permit," which shall be in addition to any other license required of such person. 
(Code 1981, § 17-35) 
Sec. 16-67. - Application-Making in person, fingerprints. 
    Each applicant for a taxicab driver's permit shall apply for his permit in person and have his fingerprints taken, which fingerprints shall constitute a part of his application. 
(Code 1981, § 17-36) 
Sec. 16-68. - Same-Contents. 
    Application for a taxicab driver's permit shall be made in writing under oath to the chief of police of the town and shall show the following: 
(1)  Full name of applicant. 
(2)  Present address. 
(3)  Age. 
(4)  Place of birth. 
(5)  Places of previous address and employment for the past five (5) years. 
(6)  Height. 
(7)  Weight. 
(8)  Color of eyes. 
(9)  Color of hair. 
(10)  Sex. 
(11)  Whether or not applicant is in good physical condition. 
(12)  Whether or not applicant has good hearing and good eyesight. 
(13)  Whether or not applicant uses or has used within the past five (5) years, intoxicating liquors, drugs or any other form of narcotic and, if so, to what extent. 
(14)  Whether or not applicant has ever been convicted of, plead guilty to or entered the plea of nolo contendere to the violation of any municipal, state, federal or other criminal law and, if so, the number of times and the kind of offenses and such other information as may be required by the chief of police. 
(15)  What experience, if any, applicant has had in the operation of cars. 
(16)  Whether or not applicant has previously been employed or licensed as a driver or chauffeur and, if so, whether or not his license has ever been revoked or suspended for any reason. 
(Code 1981, § 17-37) 
Sec. 16-69. - Same-Photographs. 
    Each applicant for a taxicab driver's permit shall file with his application two (2) recent photographs of himself of a size designated by the chief of police, one (1) of which shall be attached to and become a part of the application. 
(Code 1981, § 17-38) 
Sec. 16-70. - Same-Investigation. 
    The chief of police shall promptly make an investigation of the facts stated in an application, filed as provided in section 16-68, and shall make a written memorandum of his findings, which shall be kept on file in his office for the benefit of any interested party. 
(Code 1981, § 17-39) 
Sec. 16-71. - Medical examination of applicant. 
    The chief of police shall require of the applicant for a taxicab driver's permit such medical examination as he may deem proper. 
(Code 1981, § 17-40) 
Sec. 16-72. - Issuance or denial generally. 
    If the chief of police, upon the investigation made as provided in section 16-70, finds that the applicant is duly qualified and of good moral character, he shall issue him a taxicab driver's permit. If the chief of police is not satisfied of the qualifications and fitness of the applicant to operate taxicabs upon the streets of the town, he shall refuse to issue such permit. 
(Code 1981, § 17-41) 
Sec. 16-73. - Appeals from denial. 
    The applicant for a permit required by the provisions of this article shall have the right, within five (5) days from the day a taxicab driver's permit is denied, to appeal to the town manager from the decision of the chief of police denying the permit. The decision of the town manager shall be made after hearing relevant evidence and shall be subject to an appeal to the town council. 
(Code 1981, § 17-42) 
Sec. 16-74. - Form and contents. 
    Each taxicab driver's permit issued under this article shall contain a statement of the name, home address, business address and the employer of the holder thereof. One (1) of the photographs filed by an applicant for a taxicab driver's permit shall be attached to his permit in such manner that no other photograph may be substituted therefor without probability of detection. Taxicab drivers' permits shall be serially numbered. 
(Code 1981, § 17-43) 
Sec. 16-75. - Display. 
    Each taxicab driver's permit issued under this article shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the taxicab while such taxicab is being operated by or in the charge of the holder of such permit. 
(Code 1981, § 17-44) 
Sec. 16-76. - Fees. 
(a)  The fees with reference to taxicab driver's permits shall be as fixed from time to time by the town council. 
(b)  All fees, as provided for in this section shall be collected by the chief of police or some member of his department designated by him and shall promptly be paid over to the finance director to be placed in the general fund. 
(Code 1981, § 17-45) 
Sec. 16-77. - Term. 
    All taxicab drivers' permits issued under this article shall be valid, unless sooner revoked or suspended as provided in this article, from the date of issuance until the following thirty-first day of May of each year. 
(Code 1981, § 17-46) 
Sec. 16-78. - Transferability. 
    No taxicab driver's permit issued under this article shall be transferable. 
(Code 1981, § 17-47) 
Sec. 16-79. - Revocation or suspension generally. 
(a)  The town manager, upon application of the chief of police or any other interested party and upon ten (10) days' notice by personal service, shall have the power to revoke or suspend the taxicab driver's permit of any driver holding a taxicab driver's permit hereunder for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Repeated and persistent violation of traffic and safety laws and ordinances. 
(2)  Failure to report any accident in which such driver is involved, however slight. 
(3)  Operation of any taxicab known to the driver not to be in good order and repair. 
(4)  Conviction of reckless driving more than twice in any calendar year. 
(5)  Violation of any provision of this chapter. 
(6)  Violation of the laws of any state or the ordinances of any municipality. 
(7)  Purchase of alcoholic beverages of any description for a passenger or toleration of any disorderly conduct in a taxicab. 
(b)  The decision of a town manager relative to the revocation or suspension of a taxicab driver's permit shall be subject to an appeal to the town council. 
(Code 1981, § 17-48) 
Sec. 16-80. - Effect of conviction, etc., of crimes of moral turpitude. 
    A taxicab driver's permit issued under this article shall immediately become void and shall be immediately surrendered by the holder thereof upon his conviction of or plea of guilty or nolo contendere to the violation of any municipal, state, federal or other criminal law involving moral turpitude. 
(Code 1981, § 17-49) 
Sec. 16-81. - Driving without permit; employment of driver without permit. 
    Any person operating a taxicab on the streets of the town without a taxicab driver's permit and any owner of a taxicab who shall permit the same to be operated by any person who does not have a valid and effective taxicab driver's permit shall be punished as provided in section 16-2. 
(Code 1981, § 17-50) 
Chapter 17 - WATER AND SEWERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; buildings, Ch. 4; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 7; garbage, trash and weeds, Ch. 8; licenses, Ch. 9; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 14. 
State Law reference- Municipal water supply, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.1-37 et seq., 15.1-332.1 et seq.; public utilities, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-292 et seq.; sewage disposal generally, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.1-317 et seq., 32.1-163 et seq.; municipal regulation and inspection of water supplies, sewers, septic tanks, etc., Code of Virginia, § 15.1-854 et seq.; operation of water and sewage facilities within or without the town, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.1-875, 15.1-876; State Water Control Law, Code of Virginia, § 62.1-44.2 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 17-1. - Adoption of construction standards. 
(a)  The manual entitled "The Public Facilities Manual for the Town of Warrenton, Virginia" is hereby adopted and is in full force and effect as if fully set forth herein. 
(b)  All water lines, sanitary sewer lines, storm drains and streets which are constructed within any public right-of-way or easement or which are the extension of any public water line, sewer line, storm drain or street shall be constructed in accordance with the above manual. 
(c)  Such manual shall be on file in the office of the town recorder and shall be available for inspection during regular office hours. 
(Code 1981, § 19-1; Ord. No. 1992-12, 8-11-92) 
Sec. 17-2. - Applicability of fees. 
    Except where otherwise provided in this chapter, sewer and water connection fees as provided for in this chapter shall apply only where water and sewer mains exist abutting the property to be served. 
(Code 1981, § 19-3) 
Sec. 17-3. - Pro-rata payment for sewer and water conveyance facilities. 
(a)  When the town council, from time to time, upon application of town property owners, establishes need for the construction of sewer and/or water mains and other conveyance facilities, it may by ordinance authorize the construction of such sewer and/or water mains and other conveyance facilities, hereinafter referred to as "the project," and allocate the costs incurred by the town for the project among the benefitted property owners. 
(b)  Such ordinance shall be adopted after public hearing. Notice of the public hearing shall be published once a week for three (3) consecutive weeks and the public hearing shall be held no sooner than ten (10) days after the date the second notice appears in the newspaper. Such notice shall also be mailed to all benefitted property owners. 
(c)  The cost of the project shall include all costs for design, easement and right-of-way acquisitions, actual construction costs and any other costs incurred incident to the project, and shall be allocated among the benefitted property owners by the ordinance adopted by the town council. All costs shall be allocated on a pro-rata basis based upon established engineering estimates of the sewer and/or water flows, as the case may be, necessary for servicing each benefitted property. 
(d)  Benefitted property owners shall pay their pro-rata share of such costs prior to the time of connection of any portion of their property to the facilities installed as part of the project. In addition, payment of the pro-rata share shall include interest, at the rate established in the authorizing ordinance, from the date of completion of the project until payment. 
(e)  The town manager shall maintain for public inspection a record, in map or other form, of the sewer and/or water conveyance facilities subject to pro-rata fees provided herein. The finance director shall maintain a complete record of the costs of the project and the allocation of fees and shall notify the commissioner of revenue of the county of the costs payable by each benefitted property owner. 
(Ord. No. 1998-3, 4-14-98) 
Secs. 17-4-17-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - METERS AND SERVICE RATES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 17-21. - Use of meters generally. 
    All water furnished by the town will be furnished by meter measurements at the rates adopted by the town council and all water passing through any meter will be paid for according to the meter reading at such rate, whether used or wasted. 
(Code 1981, § 19-4) 
Sec. 17-22. - Selection of types, etc., of meters. 
    The town manager is authorized to select for the use of the town such types and makes of water meters as, in his knowledge, will best serve the town. 
(Code 1981, § 19-4) 
Sec. 17-23. - Meters property of town; right of entry to repair, etc. 
    Water meters shall be the property of the town and shall at all times be subject to control and inspection on the part of the town. Where the meter is located on or within any private property, building or premises, the town may enter such private property, building or premises at all reasonable hours for the purpose of examining, repairing or removing the meter in question or to take meter readings. 
(Code 1981, § 19-6) 
Sec. 17-24. - Replacement, etc., of injured meters. 
    Any water meter injured by hot water breaking from the heater or by any cause directly or indirectly attributable to the owner or occupant of the premises in question shall be replaced or repaired by the town at the expense of such owner or occupant. 
(Code 1981, § 19-7) 
Sec. 17-25. - Obstructed or covered meters. 
    If any customer of town water has his water meter so covered or obstructed that it cannot be easily read, then the water service to such customer shall be discontinued, after due notice by the town manager, until the customer in question corrects the situation at his own expense. 
(Code 1981, § 19-8) 
Sec. 17-26. - Removing, bypassing, etc., meters by unauthorized persons. 
(a)  No unauthorized person shall turn or cause to be turned off or on the town water at the curb stopcock box or meter box or remove or replace a water meter or make any connection connecting the town water with the house service after a meter has been removed or make any connection around a meter. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to turn any water cock for the purpose of allowing water to flow from the water main of the town into any premises when the water supply of such premises has been turned off for failure to pay the charges under this division. 
(Code 1981, § 19-9) 
Secs. 17-27-17-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CHARGES FOR WATER AND SEWER SERVICE 

Sec. 17-41. - Premises in town. 
    The water and sewer service rates to be charged for water consumed on any premises within the town shall be as provided for by the town council. 
(Code 1981, § 19-10; Ord. No. 1984-5, § 19-10, 6-5-84) 
Sec. 17-42. - Premises out of town. 
    The water and sewer service rates to be charged for water consumed on any premises outside the town shall be as provided for by the town council. 
(Code 1981, § 19-11; Ord. No. 1984-5, § 19-11, 6-5-84) 
Sec. 17-43. - Liability of owner of premises. 
    Where property is occupied by more than one (1) family or occupied other than by the owner, the owner of such property shall be directly liable to the town for the charges under this division for all water consumed on such property. The town manager shall bill the owner of such property for the water consumed thereon at the rates and times specified for the billing of water rents. 
(Code 1981, § 19-12) 
Sec. 17-44. - Discounts, etc., on vacated property. 
    No discount or rebate shall be allowed upon any bill for charges under this division by reason of property becoming vacant, unless the occupant of the property in question shall give written notice thereof to the town manager previous to the time the property becomes vacant. 
(Code 1981, § 19-13) 
Sec. 17-45. - Due dates. 
    The bills for charges under this division shall be due and payable on or before the twentieth day following the date of billing. 
(Code 1981, § 19-14; Ord. No. 1984-5, § 19-14, 6-5-84) 
Sec. 17-46. - Discontinuance of service for nonpayment. 
    If a bill for charges under this division is not paid by the thirtieth day following the billing period for which the bill was submitted, the town manager may discontinue the service to the premises in question. 
(Code 1981, § 19-15; Ord. No. 1984-5, § 19-15, 6-5-84) 
Sec. 17-47. - Estimate of consumption through defective, etc., meter. 
(a)  If any water meter at any time shall be found to have been tampered with or for any reason shall fail to register or shall be found defective in registering since the last previous reading, the water consumption for such period may be estimated by an average of previous readings through the same or from future readings. 
(b)  The town manager may adjust the bill for charges under this chapter where a leak has developed underground on the premises of such user and an excessive use of water has shown on the meter as a result of such leak which leak has been due to elements beyond the control of the water user, but only after due compliance with section 17-78. 
(c)  In the event of a loss of water due to an inside leak, resulting in a usage increase of at least one hundred fifty (150) percent over their average usage, the customer can request a courtesy adjustment of fifty (50) percent off the excess charges for usage over their average usage. Only one courtesy adjustment per customer, per three (3) years, will be granted for inside leaks. Any known leaks must have been repaired promptly and there must not be any ongoing leaks; it is to be verified by the meter report if available and/or a meter check by the meter department. 
(1)  Requests must be received in writing within sixty (60) days of the billing for the requested adjustment. Repairs must have been made within thirty (30) days of the billing for the high usage. 
(2)  Requests must include an explanation for the high usage, and include details of what was done to remedy the leak. 
(3)  A maximum of two (2) months will be considered for adjustment. 
(4)  Only one (1) adjustment per customer per three (3) years 
(5)  Failure to repair leaks in a timely manner may result in termination of service until repairs are made. 
(Code 1981, § 19-16; Ord. No. 2018-08 , 12-11-18) 
Sec. 17-48. - Charges for septic tank pumpers, etc. 
    Any person who discharges any animal or human excrement or garbage or other objectionable waste, from septic tanks or otherwise, directly into the sanitary sewer system by means other than through sewer connections shall be charged such rates as shall be provided by the town council. 
(Code 1981, § 19-17) 
Sec. 17-49. - Sewer service charge for property with private water supply. 
(a)  The owner of any residential property connected to the town sewer system, which property has a private water supply, shall pay in advance a charge in an amount as provided by the town council for such sewer service. 
(b)  The owner of any commercial property connected to the town sewer system, which property has a private water supply, shall pay for the sewer service such charges as may be established by contract with the town. 
(c)  So far as applicable, the other provisions of this division shall apply to the charges under this section. 
(Code 1981, §§ 19-18-19-20; Ord. No. 1984-5, § 19-18, 6-5-84) 
Secs. 17-50-17-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WATER 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 17-66. - Duties of town manager. 
(a)  Subject to the control of the council, the town manager shall be charged with the general supervision, control and government of the town waterworks and water supply system. The town manager shall have general charge of the reservoir, fire plugs, fixtures and pipes connected to or laid down for the waterworks and of the lands on which the reservoirs and springs of the town and the water tower are located. 
(b)  The town manager shall diligently enforce all provisions of this Code and other ordinances relating to the town waterworks and prosecute all persons who may violate any such provisions. 
(Code 1981, § 19-21) 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 7. 
Sec. 17-67. - Map of mains and extensions. 
    The town manager shall keep and preserve a map of the location of the main pipes of the waterworks and water supply system of the town, showing the course, distance and size of each of them. When there is any extension of such main pipes, he shall, as soon as possible, mark on the map the place of such extension and the size of the pipe used in making it. 
(Code 1981, § 19-22) 
Sec. 17-68. - One connection meter allowed per consumer; classification of premises. 
(a)  The owner of premises within each class established by this section shall constitute a water consumer for which a minimum charge shall be made. One (1) connection and one (1) meter shall be allowed for one (1) consumer and only one (1) water consumer shall be supplied through one (1) connection or meter. 
(b)  For the purpose of supplying town water, premises shall be placed in one (1) or more of the following classes: 
(1)  A building under one (1) roof and occupied as one (1) residence, business or manufacture. 
(2)  A combination of buildings in one (1) common enclosure and occupied by one (1) family, business or manufacture. 
(3)  Every division of a double or tenement house having a partition wall and using separate hall or entrance. 
(4)  A building of one (1) or more apartments using in common one (1) hall or entrance. 
(5)  A building of one (1) or more apartments or offices, businesses or manufacturing using in common one (1) hall or entrance, or served by common restroom facility. 
(6)  A vacant lot or tract of land. (Code 1981, § 19-23) 
(Code 1981, § 19-23; Ord. No. 2017-08 , 9-12-17) 
Sec. 17-69. - Application for service; installation of service. 
    When any person owning property in the town along the line of any water main shall desire the introduction of water into his premises, he shall make written application therefor to the town manager on forms prescribed by him. Such application shall set forth the name of the applicant, the location and description of the property into which the water is to be introduced and the purpose for which the water is to be used. Such application shall be accompanied by a fee in such amount as is in accordance with the schedule of fees for installation of water service established by the town council. 
(Code 1981, § 19-24) 
Sec. 17-70. - Record of requests for introduction of water to premises. 
    There shall be kept, in the town manager's office, a record of requests for the introduction of water to premises and the record shall indicate that the owners of property, whose names are entered therein, request that water may be introduced upon the premises mentioned opposite their names, upon the terms prescribed by the provisions of this Code or other ordinances of the town. 
(Code 1981, § 19-25) 
Sec. 17-71. - Certain work by authorized employees only. 
    No person other than an authorized employee of the town shall introduce water from the town pipes into any lot or tenement or construct or lay down or have constructed or laid down, any pipe or other work for the purpose of introducing water into a lot or tenement from the town pipes or break up any street for the purpose of constructing or laying down any such pipe or work. 
(Code 1981, § 19-26) 
Sec. 17-72. - Alterations or extensions to supply system on private premises. 
    Only a licensed plumber shall make alterations in or extensions to the water supply system of any premises or any pipe connected thereto. 
(Code 1981, § 19-27) 
Sec. 17-73. - Pipe lines laid by property owners. 
    Before the town furnishes water through pipe lines laid by property owners, such private lines, including the size, location and construction, must have been inspected and approved by the town manager or his authorized representative. Whenever the town furnishes water through any privately laid pipe lines, the town shall maintain such lines so long as it furnishes water through them. In consideration of such maintenance, the town shall have the right to connect with and furnish water to such additional consumers through such lines as the town may determine, without any charge being made by the owners of the lines to the town or to the owners of any property connected therewith. 
(Code 1981, § 19-28) 
Sec. 17-74. - Charge for restoring water after discontinuance. 
    There shall be a charge, as fixed from time to time by the town council, for turning on water to any premises after discontinuance of water service for any cause. 
(Code 1981, § 19-29) 
Sec. 17-75. - Fraudulent use of water. 
    No occupant of premises upon which water has been introduced shall permit water to be used, taken or received by any person other than the occupant or members or visitors of his family, except as provided in this chapter; provided, that this shall not be construed so as to prevent any person who has contracted for water on his own premises and whose fixtures are out of order, from obtaining water from some other person with the consent of the person occupying such premises. 
(Code 1981, § 19-30) 
Sec. 17-76. - Abandonment of service line. 
    When a property owner abandons a water service line, he shall notify the town manager of such abandonment. 
(Code 1981, § 19-31) 
Sec. 17-77. - Liability of town for temporary discontinuance, etc., of water supply. 
    The town does not, by virtue of the provisions of this chapter, assume any liability to the consumers of water for the volume or constant supply of water supplied. In the event it becomes necessary, for any cause over which the town has no control or because of the public interest, temporarily to cut off or discontinue the water supply in the whole or in any part of the town or to any particular consumer of property owner, the town shall not be liable to the consumer or property owner thereby deprived of water. 
(Code 1981, § 19-32) 
Sec. 17-78. - Leaks. 
(a)  The town shall not be responsible for any leaks which may develop or occur in water service pipes on premises of consumers of town water, whether or not such leaks occur on premises within the town or outside the town. 
(b)  If any consumer of water sold by the town is notified by the town manager that a leak or breakage of any kind exists on the water service line on the premises of such consumer of and such consumer shall fail to repair the same within twenty-four (24) hours after the receipt of such notice, the town manager shall cause the water from the town's water system to the premises of such consumer to be cut off and the same shall remain cut off until the town manager is furnished with satisfactory proof that such leak or breakage in the water service line has been completely repaired or otherwise remedied. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful if any hydrant, cock or other fixture is found leaking and the owner or occupant of the premises shall refuse or fail to have the necessary repairs made. 
(Code 1981, § 19-33) 
Sec. 17-79. - Defacing, etc., waterworks; wasting, etc., water generally. 
    No person shall deface or injure any fixture connected with or pertaining to the waterworks or place any building material, rubbish or other matter upon the stopcock of a street main or service pipe or obstruct access to any fixture connected with the waterworks or remove or injure any pipe, fire hydrant or cock or open any of them so as to waste water, nor shall any person use town water for a purpose for which he has neither paid nor obtained a license. 
(Code 1981, § 19-34) 
Sec. 17-80. - Right of entry for inspection. 
    Every person occupying any lot or tenement into which water is conveyed under this article shall permit any authorized agent of the town to enter such lot or tenement at reasonable hours to inspect the works therein or to see if the provisions of the law have been violated. 
(Code 1981, § 19-35) 
Sec. 17-81. - Prohibited activities at reservoirs. 
    No person shall bathe in the reservoirs of the town, deposit any offensive matter, sticks, mud or rubbish in the reservoirs or place the carcass of any animal or other deleterious substance on the watersheds or in any stream of any of the reservoirs. No person shall, without lawful authority, climb over or get through the enclosures of such reservoirs or hunt within such enclosures or fish in such reservoirs. 
(Code 1981, § 19-36) 
Sec. 17-82. - Size of pipes in tapping water mains. 
    In tapping the water mains for service pipes, no pipe of greater diameter than three-fourths inch shall be used, unless the owner of the property to be served, if such property to be served is within the town, has agreed in writing to pay the entire cost of the connection and has paid, in advance, the estimated cost of the installation or unless the owner, if the property to be served is outside the town, has paid in advance a fee in such amount as is in accordance with the schedule of fees for the installation of water service established by the council. 
(Code 1981, § 19-37) 
Secs. 17-83-17-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONSTRUCTION OF LINES OUTSIDE TOWN[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- When water supply system may be operated outside town boundaries, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-875. 

Sec. 17-96. - Applications to lay lines, etc., make connections. 
    Any person outside the corporate limits of the town desiring town water shall make application to the town council for the privilege of laying or having laid a water line or main beyond the corporate limits of the town and connecting the same to the town water system. 
(Code 1981, § 19-38) 
Sec. 17-97. - Liability for costs. 
    Any person exercising a privilege granted pursuant to an application made as provided in section 17-96 shall bear the entire cost of such project. 
(Code 1981, § 19-39) 
Sec. 17-98. - Specifications for lines, etc. 
    All water lines or mains laid in the exercise of a privilege granted pursuant to an application made as provided in section 17-96 shall conform with the requirements and regulations adopted by section 17-1. 
(Code 1981, § 19-40) 
Sec. 17-99. - Metering. 
    Each house or customer served by a water line or main laid in the exercise of a privilege granted pursuant to an application made as provided in this division shall be metered separately, as provided in section 17-68. 
(Code 1981, § 19-41) 
Sec. 17-100. - Installation of fire plugs. 
    At the end of each deadend water main and at such other locations as may be required by the town manager any person exercising a privilege granted pursuant to an application made as provided in this division shall, at his own expense, install fire plugs of the type and character approved by the specifications adopted in section 17-1. 
(Code 1981, § 19-42) 
Sec. 17-101. - Title to and maintenance of lines, mains and fire plugs. 
    Upon completion of work done by a person exercising a privilege granted pursuant to an application made as provided in this division, the water lines or mains and fire plugs shall automatically be and become the sole and absolute property of the town and shall be maintained by the town. 
(Code 1981, § 19-43) 
Secs. 17-102-17-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FLUORIDATION 

Sec. 17-121. - Supervision by state health department. 
    The state department of health shall have general supervision over treatments of the public water supply of the town with fluoride. 
(Code 1981, § 19-44) 
Sec. 17-122. - Duties of town manager. 
    Upon receiving a permit from the state department of health and until further direction of the town council, the town manager shall provide the means and proceed with the introduction of sodium fluoride or other suitable salt or acid of fluoride into the water supply of the town in such quantities as are required to maintain throughout the pipe distribution system a fluoride ion concentration approximately one part per million. 
(Code 1981, § 19-45) 
Sec. 17-123. - Records; testing for concentration. 
(a)  The water department shall keep an accurate daily record showing for each supply the number of gallons treated and the fluoridation concentration of the water before and after treatment. The water department shall also determine the fluoridation concentration in the water distribution system at such points and at such intervals as may be directed by the state health department. 
(b)  The water department shall furnish to the health department copies of records specified under the first paragraph of this section, at daily, weekly, and monthly intervals as may be required by the state health department. 
(Code 1981, § 19-46) 
Secs. 17-124-17-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - SWIMMING POOLS 

Sec. 17-136. - Generally. 
    Water purchased for a swimming pool shall be purchased at the regular rates applicable in the town and the consumption thereof shall be metered, if so required by the town manager. 
(Code 1981, § 19-47) 
Sec. 17-137. - Purchase of water generally. 
    So long as the water supply of the town is sufficient, any property owner or resident whose property lies in the town may purchase water for a swimming pool, in a manner and at such time as may be determined by the town manager within his discretion. 
(Code 1981, § 19-49) 
Sec. 17-138. - Emptying. 
    Swimming pools in the town shall be emptied of water in a manner to be determined by the town manager upon the application of the property owner or resident purchasing water for such swimming pool. 
(Code 1981, § 19-49) 
Secs. 17-139-17-145. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - WATER CONSERVATION 

Sec. 17-146. - Authority to declare water emergencies. 
    During the continued existence of climatic, hydrological and other extraordinary conditions the protection of the health, safety and welfare of the residents of the Town of Warrenton may require that certain uses of water, not essential to public health, safety and welfare, be reduced, restricted or curtailed. As the shortage of potable water becomes increasingly more critical, conservation measures to reduce consumption or curtail essential water use may be necessary. 
    The town manager, with the approval of the town council, is authorized to declare water emergencies affecting the use of water by persons and properties served by town water, inside and outside of the town boundaries, and to control and restrict the use of water during an emergency caused by a water shortage or other cause. 
(Ord. No. 1999-08, 8-10-99) 
Sec. 17-147. - Publication of declaration. 
    Upon the declaration of a water emergency pursuant to section 17-146, the town manager shall immediately post a written notice of the emergency at the front door of town hall, in a newspaper of general circulation in the area, announce on television and radio and use any other appropriate means of communication. 
(Ord. No. 1999-08, 8-10-99) 
Sec. 17-148. - Use of water restricted. 
    Upon the declaration of a water emergency pursuant to section 17-146, the town manager is authorized and directed to implement conservation measures by ordering the restricted use or absolute curtailment of the use of water for certain nonessential purposes for the duration of the water shortage in the manner hereinafter set out. In exercising this discretionary authority, and making the determinations set forth in section 17-150 thereof, the town manager shall give due consideration to water levels, available/usable storage on hand, draw down rates and the projected supply capability in source reservoirs in the Town of Warrenton, supply capacity, daily water consumption and consumption projections of the system's customers; prevailing and forecast weather conditions; fire service requirements; pipeline conditions including breakages, stoppages and leaks; estimates of minimum essential supplies to pre-serve public health and safety and such other data pertinent to the past, current and projected water demands. 
    All data collected and considered by the town manager shall be reduced to writing and maintained by the town manager. 
(Ord. No. 1999-08, 8-10-99) 
Sec. 17-149. - Limitation of restrictions. 
    The provisions of this division, or regulations promulgated hereunder by the town manager, which are hereby authorized, shall not apply to any governmental activity, institution, business or industry which shall be declared by the town manager, upon a proper showing, to be necessary for the public health, safety and welfare or the prevention of severe economic hardship or the substantial loss of employment. Any activity, institution, business or industry aggrieved by the finding of the town manager may appeal that decision to a water conservation appeals board appointed by the town council consisting of three members selected as follows: a single representative from the department of public utilities, and two citizens from the public at large. 
(Ord. No. 1999-08, 8-10-99) 
Sec. 17-150. - Water conservation measures. 
    Upon a determination by the town manager of the existence of the following conditions, the town manager shall take the following actions; which shall apply to any person whose water supply is furnished from the town water system: 
(a)  Condition 1. When moderate but limited supplies of water are available, the town manager shall, through appropriate means, call upon the general population to employ prudent restraint in water usage, and to conserve water voluntarily by whatever methods available. 
(b)  Condition 2. When very limited supplies of water are available, the town manager shall order curtailment of less essential usages of water, including, but not limited to, one or more of the following: 
(1)  The watering of shrubbery, trees, lawns, grass, plants, or any other vegetation, except indoor planting, greenhouse or nursery stocks and except limited watering for newly seeded lawns and watering by commercial nurseries of freshly planted plants upon planting and once a week for five (5) weeks following planting. 
(2)  The washing of automobiles, trucks, trailers, boats, airplanes, or any other type of mobile equipment, except in facilities operating with a water recycling system approved by the director of public works; provided, however, that any facility operating with a water recycling system shall prominently display in public view a notice approved by the director of public works/utilities stating that such recycling system is in operation. In lieu of the provisions hereof, the town manager may curtail the hours of operation of commercial enterprises offering such services or which wash their equipment. 
(3)  The washing of streets, driveways, parking lots, service station aprons, office buildings, exteriors of homes or apartments, or other outdoor surfaces. 
(4)  The operation of any ornamental fountain or other structure making a similar use of water. 
(5)  The filling of swimming and/or wading pools, or the refilling of swimming and/or wading pools which were drained after the effective date of the order. 
(6)  The use of water from fire hydrants for any purpose other than fire suppression or other public emergency. 
(7)  The serving of drinking water in restaurants, cafeterias or any other food establishment unless requested by the individual. 
(c)  Condition 3. When critically limited supplies of water are available, the town manager shall institute mandatory reductions on each customer as follows: 
(1)  Industrial, institutional, commercial, governmental, wholesale and all other nonresidential customers shall be allotted a percentage reduction based on that customer's average monthly and/or quarterly previous calendar year's consumption. 
(2)  Individual residential customers shall be limited to a specific volume or percentage reduction of water per quarter. 
If the allotted monthly/or quarterly water usage is exceeded, the customer shall be charged ten dollars ($10.00) for every one thousand (1,000) gallons of water consumed above the allotted volume. Where prior consumption data is not available, the town manager shall estimate allocations based upon the data available from similar activities of equal intensity. 
(d)  Condition 4. When crucially limited supplies of water are available, the town manager shall restrict the use of water to purposes which are absolutely essential to life, health and safety. 
The determination of conditions 2, 3 and 4 by the town manager shall be accompanied by a written report which shall set out the criteria utilized and data relied upon in making such determination including a narrative summary supporting the determination. Each report shall be available for public inspection in the town manager's office. The town manager shall forthwith transmit a copy of each report to the town council. 
(Ord. No. 1999-08, 8-10-99) 
Sec. 17-151. - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this division, or of any of the conservation regulations promulgated by the town manager pursuant thereto, shall, Upon conviction thereof, in addition to additional charges set forth in subsection 17-150(c) be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor more than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). Each act or each day's continuation of a violation shall be considered a separate offense. In addition to the foregoing, the town manager may suspend water service to any person continuing to violate the provisions of this ordinance or the regulations promulgated thereunder. If such water service is terminated, the person shall pay a re-connection fee of and all outstanding charges before service is restored. 
(Ord. No. 1999-08, 8-10-99) 
Sec. 17-152. - Notification of end of water emergency. 
    The town manager shall notify the town council when, in his opinion, the water emergency situation no longer exists. Upon concurrence of the council, the water emergency shall be declared to have ended. 
(Ord. No. 1999-08, 8-10-99) 
Secs. 17-153, 17-154. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SEWERS[3] 
Footnotes: 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 17-155. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abbreviations: The following abbreviations shall have the designated meanings: 
BOD: Biochemical oxygen demand CFR: Code of Federal Regulations COD: Chemical oxygen demand EPA: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency gpd: Gallons per day LC 50 : Lethal concentration for fifty (50) percent of the test organisms l: Liter LEL: Lower explosive limit mg: Milligrams mg/l: Milligrams per liter NPDES: National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System O&M: Operation and maintenance POTW: Publicly owned treatment works RCRA: Resource Conservation and Recovery Act SIC: Standard industrial classification SWDA: Solid Waste Disposal Act (42 U.S.C. 6901, et seq.) TSS: Total suspended solids USC: United States Code  
    Act or the act: The Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act, as amended, 33 U.S.C. 1251 et seq. 
    Administrator: The administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency or his agents or delegates. 
    Approval authority: The executive director of the state water control board: 
    Authorized representative of the industrial user: 
(1)  If the industrial user is a corporation, "authorized representative" shall mean: 
a.  The president, secretary, treasurer, or a vice president of the corporation in charge of a principal business function, or any other person who performs similar policy or decision-making functions for the corporation; or 
b.  The manager of one (1) or more manufacturing, production, or operation facilities employing more than two hundred fifty (250) persons or having gross annual sales or expenditures exceeding twenty-five million dollars ($25,000,000.00) (in second-quarter 1980 dollars), if authority to sign documents has been assigned or delegated to the manager in accordance with corporate procedures. 
(2)  If the industrial user is a partnership, association, or sole proprietorship, an "authorized representative" shall mean a general partner or the proprietor. 
(3)  If the individual user is representing federal, state or local governments, or an agent thereof, an "authorized representative" shall mean a director or highest official appointed or designated to oversee the operation and performance of the activities of the government facility. 
(4)  The individuals described in paragraphs (1) through (3) above may designate another authorized representative if the authorization is in writing, the authorization specifies the individual or position responsible for the overall operation of the facility from which the discharge originates or having overall responsibility for environmental matters for the company, and the authorization is submitted to the town. 
    Best management practices: Schedules of activities, prohibitions of practices, maintenance procedures, and other management practices or procedures of users to prevent or reduce the discharge of pollutants into the collection system of the town sewerage treatment system. Such practices may include, but not be limited to, notification plans of any accidental discharge, solvent management plans, operating procedures and practices to control batch discharge sludge and waste disposal, spillage or leaks, or drainage from raw material storage. 
    BOD (Biochemical oxygen demand): The quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees centigrade, expressed in terms of weight and concentration (milligrams per liter (mg/l)). 
    Building sewer: A sewer conveying wastewater from the premises of a user to the POTW. 
    Categorical pretreatment standard or categorical standard: Any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by the U.S. EPA in accordance with Section 307(b) and (c) of the act (§33 U.S.C. §1317) which applies to a specific category of industrial users and which appears in 40 CFR Chapter I, Subchapter N, Parts 405 through 471, incorporated herein by reference. 
    Collection system: All sewers which discharge wastewaters into the POTW, including the sewers of the town and those outside the limits of the town. 
    Combined sewer: A sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage. 
    Composite sample: The sample resulting from the combination of individual wastewater samples taken at selected intervals based on either an increment of flow or time. 
    Control authority: The term "control authority" shall refer to the superintendent of the municipal wastewater system, once the town has a U.S. EPA-approved pretreatment program according to the provisions of 40 CFR 403.11. 
    Cooling water: The water discharged from any use such as air conditioning, cooling or refrigeration, or to which the only pollutant added is heat. 
    Director: The engineer for the town. 
    Discharge: The discharge or the introduction of nondomestic pollutants into the municipal wastewater system by an industrial user. 
    Environmental protection agency or U.S. EPA: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, or, where appropriate, the term may also be used as a designation for the regional water management division director or other duly authorized official of said agency. 
    Garbage: Solid waste from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food and from the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
    Holding tank waste: Any waste from holding tanks such as vessels, chemical toilets, campers, trailers, septic tanks, and vacuum-pump tank trucks. 
    House drain: That part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the house sewer, beginning five (5) feet outside the inner face of the building wall. 
    House sewer: The extension from the house drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
    Indirect discharge or discharge: The introduction of pollutants into a POTW from any nondomestic source regulated under section 307(b), (c) or (d) of the act. 
    Industrial wastewater: Nondomestic wastewater originating from a nonresidential source, including any nonsanitary wastes which may be trucked into the POTW for disposal. 
    Interference: Any discharge into the collection system or the POTW, alone or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources, which: 
(1)  Inhibits or disrupts the POTW, its treatment processes or operations, or its sludge processes, use or disposal; and 
(2)  Therefore is a cause of a violation of the POTW's NPDES permit (including an increase in the magnitude or duration of a violation) or in the prevention of sewage sludge use or disposal in compliance with the following statutory provisions and regulations or permits issued therein (or more stringent state or local regulations): Section 405 of the Clean Water Act; the Solid Waste Disposal Act (SWDA), including Title II commonly referred to as the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA), and including state regulations contained in any state sludge management plan prepared pursuant to Subtitle D of the SWDA; the Clean Air Act; the Toxic Substances Control Act; and the Marine Protection, Research and Sanctuaries Act. 
    Liquid waste hauler: Any person who transports material or substances liquid in nature which, if discharged into the sewer treatment system, would constitute effluent discharge subject to the provisions of this article. 
    Medical waste: Isolation wastes, infectious agents, human blood and blood byproducts, pathological wastes, sharps, body parts, fomites, etiologic agents, contaminated bedding, surgical wastes, potentially contaminated laboratory wastes and dialysis wastes. 
    Municipal wastewater system or system or publicly owned treatment works or POTW: A "treatment works" as defined by Section 212 of the act (33 U.S.C. 1292), which is owned by the Commonwealth of Virginia or the Town of Warrenton (as defined by section 502(4) of the act). This definition includes any devices and systems used in the collection, storage, treatment, recycling and reclamation of municipal sewage or industrial wastes of a liquid nature. It also includes sewers, pipes and other conveyances only if they convey wastewater to a POTW treatment plant. The term also means the municipality as defined in section 502(4) of the act which has jurisdiction over the indirect discharges to, and the discharges from, such a treatment works. 
    National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System permit or NPDES permit: A permit issued pursuant to section 402 of the Clean Water Act (33 U.S.C. 1342). 
    Natural outlet: Any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake, or other body of surface or ground water. 
    New source: 
(1)  Any building, structure, facility or installation from which there is or may be a discharge of pollutants, the construction or operations of which commenced after the publication of proposed pretreatment standards under Section 307(c) (33 U.S.C. 1317(c)) of the act which will be applicable to such source if such standards are thereafter promulgated in accordance with section 307(c), provided that: 
a.  The building, structure, facility or installation is constructed at a site at which no other source is located; 
b.  The building, structure, facility or installation totally replaces the process or production equipment that causes the discharge of pollutants at an existing source; or 
c.  The production of wastewater generating process of the building, structure, facility or installation are substantially independent of an existing source at the same site. In determining whether these are substantially independent factors such as the extent to which the new facility is integrated with the existing plant, and the extent to which the new facility is engaged in the same general type of activity as the existing source should be considered. 
(2)  Construction on a site at which an existing source is located results in a modification rather than a new source if the construction does not create a new building, structure, facility or installation meeting the criteria of paragraph (1)b. or (1)c. of this definition, but otherwise alters, replaces, or adds to existing process or production equipment. 
(3)  Construction of a new source as defined under this paragraph has commenced if the owner or operator has: 
a.  Begun, or caused to begin, as part of a continuous on-site construction program: 
1.  Any placement, assembly, or installation of facilities or equipment; or 
2.  Significant site preparation work including clearing, excavation, or removal of existing buildings, structures, or facilities which is necessary for the placement, assembly, or installation of new source facilities or equipment; or 
b.  Entered into a binding contractual obligation for the purchase of facilities or equipment which are intended to be used in its operation within a reasonable time. Options to purchase or contracts which can be terminated or modified without substantial loss, and contracts for feasibility, engineering, and design studies do not constitute a contractual obligation under this definition. 
    Nondomestic waste: Any byproducts or discharge into the municipal wastewater system other than human excrement and household gray water (shower, dishwashing operations, etc.). Nondomestic pollutants include the characteristics of the wastewater; i.e. pH, temperature, TSS, turbidity, color, BOD, COD, toxicity, odor. 
    Operator: The person responsible for the overall operation of a facility. 
    Owner: The person who owns a facility or part of a facility. 
    Pass through: Any discharge which exits the POTW into waters of the Commonwealth in quantities or concentrations, which alone, or in conjunction with indirect discharges or a discharge from other sources, is a cause of a violation of effluent limits, water quality standards or other requirements of the town's Virginia Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (VPDES) permit, including an increase in the magnitude or duration of a violation. 
    Person: Any individual, association, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, corporation, joint stock company, trust, estate, municipality, state or federal governmental agency or entity, or their legal representatives, or any employee thereof, agent or assigns. 
    pH: A measure of the acidity or alkalinity of a substance, expressed in standard units; neutral wastewaters are numerically equal to 7 while the number increases to show increasing alkalinity and decreases to show increasing acidity. 
    Pollutant: Any dredged spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, medical wastes, chemical wastes, industrial wastes, biological materials, radioactive materials, heat wrecked or discharged equipment, rock, sand, cellar dirt and agricultural wastes. 
    POTW treatment plant or treatment plant: That portion of the POTW which is designed to provide treatment (including recycling and reclamation) of municipal sewage and industrial waste. 
    Pretreatment or treatment: The reduction of the amount of pollutants, the elimination of pollutants, or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties in wastewater thereby rendering them less harmful to the municipal wastewater system prior to introducing such pollutants into the system. This reduction or alteration can be obtained by physical, chemical or biological processes, by process changes, or by other means except by diluting the concentration of the pollutants unless allowed by an applicable pretreatment standard. 
    Pretreatment standard and requirements: Any substantive or procedural requirement related to pretreatment, including prohibited discharge standards, categorical pretreatment standards, and local limits imposed on an industrial user. 
    Prohibited discharge standards or prohibited discharges: Absolute prohibitions against the discharge of certain defined types of industrial wastewater; the prohibitions appear in section 17-223 of this article. 
    Properly shredded garbage: The wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that has been shredded to such degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half (1/2) inch in any dimension. 
    Public sewer: A sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights and which is controlled by public authority. 
    Sanitary sewer: A sewer which carries sewage and to which stormwaters, surface and ground waters are not intentionally admitted. 
    Sewage: Human excrement and gray water (household showers, dishwashing operations, etc.). 
    Sewer: A pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
    Slug load: Any pollutant (including BOD) released in a discharge at a flow rate or concentration which could cause a violation of the specific discharge prohibitions contained in section 17-203 of this article. 
    Stormwater: Any flow occurring during or following any form of natural precipitation and resulting therefrom, including snowmelt. 
    Storm sewer or storm drain: A sewer which carries storm and surface waters and drainage, excluding sewage and polluted industrial wastes. 
    Submission: 
(1)  A request by a POTW for approval of a pretreatment program to the EPA or a director; or 
(2)  A request by a POTW to the EPA or a director for authority to revise the discharge limits in categorical pretreatment standards to reflect POTW pollutant removals. 
    Superintendent: The town manager designated by the town to supervise the operation of the municipal wastewater system and who is charged with certain duties and responsibilities by this article or his duly authorized representative. 
    Suspended solids: The total suspended matter that floats on the surface of, or is suspended in, water, wastewater, or other liquid and which is removable by laboratory filtering. 
    Town: The Town of Warrenton, a municipal corporation of Virginia. 
    User: Any person who contributes, or causes or allows the contribution of sewage or industrial wastewater into the municipal wastewater system, including persons who contribute such wastes from mobile sources. 
    User, industrial: Any person which is a source of discharge. 
    User, residential: Person only contributing sewage wastewater to the municipal wastewater system. 
    User, significant industrial (SIU): Except as provided in subsection (3) of this definition: 
(1)  Industrial users subject to categorical pretreatment standards; and 
(2)  Any other industrial user that discharges an average of 25,000 gpd or more of process wastewater (excluding sanitary, noncontact cooling and boiler blowdown wastewater); contributes a process wastestream which makes up five (5) percent or more of the average dry weather hydraulic or organic capacity of the treatment plant; or is designated as significant by the town on the basis that the industrial user has a reasonable potential for adversely affecting the POTW's operation or violating any pretreatment standard or requirement. 
(3)  Upon a finding that an industrial user meeting the criteria in subsection (2) immediately hereinabove, has no reasonable potential for adversely affecting the POTW's operation or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement, the town or the state water control board if the submission has not been approved, may at any time, on its own initiative or in response to a petition received from an industrial user or POTW, and in accordance with 40 CFR 403.8(f)(6), determine that such industrial user is not a significant industrial user. 
    Wastewater: The liquid and water carried industrial wastes, or sewage from residential dwellings, commercial buildings, industrial and manufacturing facilities, and institutions, whether treated or untreated, which is contributed to the municipal wastewater system. 
    Watercourse: A channel in which a flow of water occurs either continuously or intermittently. 
This article is gender neutral and the masculine gender shall include the feminine and vice versa. "Shall" is mandatory, "may" is permissive or discretionary. The use of the singular shall be construed to include the plural and the plural shall include the singular as indicated by the context of its use. 
(Ord. No. 1993-4, 5-11-93) 
Sec. 17-156. - Flush toilet required. 
    Every building now erected or which may hereafter be erected, remodeled or repaired, whether occupied or to be occupied for any purpose, shall be provided by the owner thereof with an adequate number of sanitary flush-type toilet devices conforming to the Uniform Statewide Building Code, which devices shall be connected to the town sewer system; provided, that such building or premises are within three hundred (300) feet of a public sewer. 
(Ord. No. 1993-4, 5-11-93) 
Sec. 17-157. - Frostproof water closets, cesspools and sanitary privies. 
(a)  Any sanitary privy in existence on the effective date of this section, which is situated on a lot or parcel of land within three hundred (300) feet of the town sewerage system, shall be removed within three hundred sixty (360) days after that date and a flush-type toilet device installed. 
(b)  Any frostproof water closet and cesspools are prohibited for use in the town. 
(Ord. No. 1993-4, 5-11-93) 
Sec. 17-158. - Use of septic tanks, etc. 
    In cases where it is not practicable to make connection with the town system of sewers, the use of septic tanks or sanitary privies will be allowed, subject to the approval of the health department. 
(Ord. No. 1993-4, 5-11-93) 
Sec. 17-159. - Removing obstructions. 
    In case of any stoppage in the public mains, the town shall remove the obstruction. If the stoppage occurs in the house sewer or drain, the property owner, whose property it connects with the main sewer, shall remove the obstruction. If he fails to remove the obstruction within forty-eight (48) hours after notice from the town manager, the obstruction may be removed by the town and the cost thereof, plus twenty (20) percent, shall be paid by the owner or occupant. 
(Ord. No. 1993-4, 5-11-93) 
Sec. 17-160. - Damaging sewers, manholes, etc. 
    No person, while engaged in the construction of house sewers or otherwise, shall injure, trim, break or remove any portion of any main or lateral sewer or "Y" or manhole, lamphole or flush toilet tank or do any injury to any gas or water pipe or house sewer previously laid. No penalty fixed for violation of this Code shall prevent the town or any property owner from recovering any damages sustained by reason of such injury, by appropriate civil action or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 1993-4, 5-11-93) 
Sec. 17-161. - Liability for damages, etc. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall become liable to the town for any expense, loss or damage occasioned the town by reason of such violation. 
(Ord. No. 1993-4, 5-11-93) 
Sec. 17-162. - Notice and correction of violations. 
    Any person found to be violating any provision of this article shall be served by the town with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. 
(Ord. No. 1993-4, 5-11-93) 
Secs. 17-163-17-175. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONNECTION GENERALLY 

Sec. 17-176. - Required generally. 
    Every building in existence prior to the construction of a public sewer adjacent to the lot or parcel of land on which such building stands shall connect to the public sewer within two (2) years of the time such sewer is constructed and made available for use. If the septic tank serving such building ceases to function properly so its continued operation constitutes a nuisance or menace to health, such building shall be connected to the adjoining public sewer immediately. 
(Ord. No. 1993-4, 5-11-93) 
Sec. 17-177. - Specifications for materials and drains. 
    Specifications for materials and drains shall be as provided in the Uniform Statewide Building Code. 
(Ord. No. 1993-4, 5-11-93) 
Sec. 17-178. - Diversion of certain wastes to sewer system. 
    Upon connection of premises to the sewer system, all cesspools, septic tanks and dry closets shall be abated and all wastewater from bathrooms, kitchen sinks and other domestic uses shall be diverted into the sewerage system of the town; provided, that no downspout from any building shall be connected with the municipal wastewater system or the POTW. 
(Ord. No. 1993-4, 5-11-93) 
Sec. 17-179. - Permits generally. 
    No person shall make any connections with or opening into any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the town. 
(Ord. No. 1993-4, 5-11-93) 
Sec. 17-180. - Connections by authorized employees only. 
    The connection of the house sewer to the sewer main or lateral shall be made by no person other than an authorized employee of the town. 
(Ord. No. 1993-4, 5-11-93) 
Sec. 17-181. - Out-of-town premises not using town water. 
    Connections with the municipal wastewater system shall be allowed for premises outside the town, where town water is not used by the owner or occupant, subject to the approval of the town council. 
(Ord. No. 1993-4, 5-11-93) 
Sec. 17-182. - Fees. 
    The town council shall establish a schedule of sewer connection fees for individual residential connections made to the town sewer for premises in town; individual residential connections made to the town sewer for premises outside the town boundaries; for commercial users; and industrial users. The property owner shall pay to the finance director such sewer connection fee as established by the town council before the connection to the sewer main is made. 
(1)  Premises in town. Any sewer connection fee not paid by the property owner shall constitute a lien on such property, which lien shall be enforceable in the same manner as tax levies are enforced and collected. The town hereby reserves the right to run sewer lines from the sewer main to the line of the property owner and to charge the cost of so doing to the property owner, thereby creating a lien on such property, which lien shall be enforceable in the same manner as tax levies and liens are enforced and collected. 
(2)  Nonresidents. 
a.
